DOC.HEAD: Governor Makes Offer in Teacher Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead; INSERTS 3 grafs after 6th graf, `The governor ...,' to ADD background, UPDATE with quotes; picks up 7th graf, `More than ...' DELETES now-redundant grafs 17-18, `He said ...'; picks up 18th graf, `Earlier in ...'
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Gaston Caperton presented striking teachers Tuesday night with a seven-point plan that promises no pay raises, but calls for a special legislative session if there's enough surplus money to fund a salary increase. Caperton also offered to call an ``education summit'' in May to seek long-term solutions to the annual problem of teacher pay. Teacher union representatives left the governor's office without comment about 10:45 p.m. Tuesday following a second day of talks. Gubernatorial spokesman G.C. Morse said the administration expects an answer from the West Virginia Education Association and the West Virginia Federation of Teachers by noon Wednesday. ``The immediate reaction from these folks was favorable, but these folks need to get back and confer with whoever they confer with,'' Morse said. The governor announced his offer in a statement at 11 p.m. Tuesday. He took no questions from reporters. On March 5, when the Legislature was still in session, the governor and legislative leaders offered the teachers a 5 percent pay raise financed by a tax increase for coal producers, but that deal collapsed the next day. Caperton said Tuesday night that he would not propose a tax increase again because the public wouldn't support it. ``West Virginia simply cannot afford to do more,'' Caperton said. ``No matter how jusitifed their position may be on the matter of teacher compensation, I bear a responsibility to the taxpayers of West Virginia.'' More than 85 percent of West Virginia's 22,000 public schoolteachers walked out in the state's first such strike last Wednesday in a dispute over wages and benefits. By Tuesday, the strike had spread to 46 of the state's 55 counties. The WVEA claims 16,000 members statewide, and the WVFT had 3,000, including teachers and other school employees. In addition to the special session proposal and the education summit, the governor's proposal includes: _ An offer to work with teacher representatives to come up with legislative proposals. _ $3 million from a school computer program to be diverted to teacher pay. _ A promise to continue to work for equity funding, aimed at equalizing teacher salaries statewide, including $20 million this year. _ Full funding of the state health insurance program with no deductibles or co-payments and without benefit reductions. _ Full funding of the Teachers Retirement System. Caperton called the meetings with the teacher representatives ``cordial and fruitful.'' ``And, although we have not yet reached a final agreement on returning teachers to the classrooms, we have closed the distance between ourselves and that goal,'' Caperton said. Earlier in the day, Caperton postponed a speech on education policy he was due to deliver Tuesday because of the continuing discussions, his office said in a statement. The speech was rescheduled for Wednesday night. Morse said at least part of the reason was because the governor had very little sleep Monday night after holding talks for seven hours. While the two sides gathered around a table in the governor's conference room at the Capitol on Tuesday, teachers walked picket lines at various places around the state. The state Department of Education said schools were closed Tuesday in 25 counties, open in 19 and mixed in 11 others. The number of teachers and students affected was not immediately available, said education spokeswoman Carolyn Spangler. Teachers in Greenbrier County agreed Tuesday night to return to work beginning Monday. The school board, which had threatened to fire teachers who failed to report for work Wednesday, said it would withdraw letters threatening the dismissals. In Jefferson County, teachers face fines and a contempt of court citation if they don't return to work by Thursday. But the teachers said they would ask the state Supreme Court on Wednesday to halt an injunction ordering them back to work. Spangler said several counties have discussed seeking court injunctions to limit pickets. The state's average teacher salary is $21,904, less than teachers in every state except Arkansas and South Dakota, according to the National Education Association.

DOC.HEAD: DC-9 Runs Off Runway at Hartsfield
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to CORRECT that plane was carrying 56 people, including five crew members; picks up 4th graf, `Witnesses reported ...'
DOC.TEXT: An Eastern Airlines DC-9 carrying 56 people left the runway Tuesday night after being forced to return to the airport by hydraulic problems, an airport spokesman said. No injuries were reported. Eastern Airlines Flight 129 left the runway after the pilot began having trouble steering, apparently because a tire blew, said Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport spokesman John Braden. The plane, on a flight from Atlanata to Tallahassee, Fla. with 51 passengers and five crew members, returned to the airport around 10:50 p.m. because of hydraulic problems, Braden said. Witnesses reported seeing sparks from the aircraft as it glided along the runway, but Braden said that was because the landing gear was scraping the runway. He said the Federal Aviation Administration and the National Transportation and Safety Board would investigate the incident. Passengers were given the option of taking another flight out Tuesday night or waiting until Wednesday morning, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Former U.S. President Optimistic About Middle East Peace
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CLARIFY that Camp David accords led to peace tgreaty, SUB graf 13, `But Begin ... Arab nation.' Picks up 14th, ```So I ...' ^By NEJLA SAMMAKIA
DOC.TEXT: Jimmy Carter, the architect of the Camp David peace accords, said Tuesday he doesn't expect the collapse of Israel's government to ruin chances for a Palestinian-Israeli dialogue and eventual peace in the Middle East. The former president said he hopes a single-party government will emerge from Israel's political turmoil to avoid the ``timidity and stalemate'' of coalition government. ``I do think there is still a good chance for ... dialogue,'' Carter said after a meeting with President Hosni Mubarak. ``The basic parameters have been worked out,'' he said. ``There's agreement among the Palestinians, the Egyptians, the Americans and, I think, more than half the Israelis. So I believe it's going to happen; it may be delayed to some degree.'' Tuesday, Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir fired his Finance Minister and political adversary, Shimon Peres. Ten ministers from Peres' left-leaning Labor Party followed their leader out of the Cabinet, and the tenuous political alliance that has ruled Israel for six years collapsed. The government fell due to clashes over U.S. proposals for an Israeli-Palestinian dialogue. Labor has accepted the idea of talking to Palestinian deportees and Arab residents of Israeli-annexed east Jerusalem. But Likud opposes both ideas, saying they will lead to indirect talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization and compromise Israeli control over a united Jerusalem. Israel considers the PLO to be a terrorist group and refuses to have a dialogue with it. Following Peres' dismissal and the mass resignation of his party colleagues, Israel faces eventual elections. ``I'm no expert on Israeli politics, but I've always had the feeling that a leadership of either Likud or Labor is better than having a coalition government,'' Carter said. He said he was discouraged in May 1977 when Menachem Begin led his Likud bloc to its first electoral victory since Israel's statehood in 1948. ``I never believed that the Likud under him would move forward in a courageous way toward peace,'' the former president said. But Begin later joined Carter and Egypt's former President Anwar Sadat in signing the Camp David accords of 1978, which led a year later to the first and only peace treaty between Israel and an Arab nation. ``So I don't really think it matters one way or another which party ultimately triumphs. Even if the Likud should triumph ... I think this might bode better for a strong move towards peace than to have a stalemated coalition government,'' Carter said. Carter is on a private four nation tour of the Middle East. After leaving Egypt he is to visit Syria, Israel and Jordan. Since leaving office, Carter has visited the Middle East four times to monitor peace efforts.

DOC.HEAD: Correspondence Group Helps East Meet West _ Intimately
LaserPhoto ROC1
DOC.TEXT: Say goodbye to the Cold War and say hello to love, Soviet style. With East-West differences crumbling like the Berlin Wall, a U.S. housewife is warming up international relations with a dating service that links prospective marriage partners from opposite sides of the Iron Curtain. Marie Helbog is the founder and director of Scanna International, a ``correspondence and introduction club'' which she runs out of her suburban Rochester home. Helbog, a mother of four, started Scanna in 1980, 20 years after she and her husband moved to the United States from Denmark. The group's membership expanded from Scandinavians and Americans to other nationalities. Following the rapid changes in Eastern Europe, Scanna arranged for its first Soviet representative last fall. Already, Helbog has about 1,000 members in the Soviet Union, and airmail envelopes from Russia with love pour in at a rate of about 150 a week. ``All these Russians,'' she said last week. ``We're so overwhelmed.'' Scanna also has a large number of Polish members and hopes to begin placing ads and operating in Hungary and Czechoslovakia soon. Letters have begun trickling in from would-be suitors in other Eastern European countries who have seen Scanna ads in American magazines. Scanna, which has about 3,000 members at any one time, also matches pen pals, but most members are marriage-minded, Helbog said. Members fill out a questionnaire describing their interests and personality and explaining what they're looking for in a partner. In return, they receive photographs and profiles of prospective matches. Fees range from about $20 for a choice of pen pals to about $90 for a selection of marriage partners. Scanna's American members, most of whom are men, have shown great interest in Soviet and Polish women, apparently considering them either more exotic or more domestic, Helbog said. ``They're all checking that box off,'' she said. ``I like cleanliness and order. I cook wonderfully,'' writes Olga Z., a 31-year-old Soviet teacher from Nakhodka seeking a man with modern views. ``I would like to feel like a woman when I am near him.'' Olga K., a 28-year-old nutrition specialist from Vladivostok, also in the Soviet Union, describes herself as elegant and refined, looking for a strong-willed man who is aristocratic in character and soul. ``It is good of you if you understand that attention, admiration, care and compliments and flowers are of great importance for women.'' Helbog said recent changes have made it easy for Soviets who marry Americans to leave the Soviet Union, something that a decade ago would have meant months or years of red tape. She said she often receives letters and Christmas cards from correspondents who have decided to tie the knot, but that it is too soon to expect to hear from any East-West couples taking the plunge. Helbog employs one full-time staff member and three or four part-time helpers in the United States. A bevy of agents and affiliated groups run the overseas operations.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Lawyers to Identify Cash Clients
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge issued a limited ruling Tuesday backing the Internal Revenue Service's efforts to force lawyers to identify clients who pay them more than $10,000 in cash. U.S. District Judge Vincent L. Broderick said two Manhattan law firms must reveal the identities of five such clients, but stayed his order so that attorneys Ronald Fischetti and Paul Goldberger could appeal. He emphasized, however, that other lawyers could be exempt because of ``special circumstances.'' The judge said that as the law now stands, the issue must be decided on a case-by-case basis. He urged the IRS and the U.S. Justice Department to work with the defense bar to set up guidelines for lawyers reporting cash income. At issue is a 1984 law that requires everyone in ``trade or business'' to report cash receipts of more than $10,000 and the source of the payments. Lawyers maintain that the law violates the attorney-client privilege. Fischetti, Goldberger and their firms were the subjects of the first civil lawsuits to be brought in an enforcement campaign against lawyers by the IRS. Last week, the IRS sent summonses to 90 other attorneys demanding similar information. Both Fischetti and Goldberger, who have handled many organized crime and drug cases, filled out the required forms but refused to identify five clients who paid them more than $10,000 in 1986 and 1987. In his oral ruling, Broderick did not specify what special circumstances could exempt lawyers from identifying clients on the IRS forms. Neil Sonnett, a Miami lawyer who is president of the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers, said an exemption could be made when an attorney is actively representing a client who is under indictment. Sonnett said that in the cases of Fischetti and Goldberger, their representation of the clients whose identities were being sought had already concluded.

DOC.HEAD: Joint Chiefs Believe NATO Can Win Conventional War, Aspin Says
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon believes the United States and its allies could fight and hold off the Soviet Union in Europe without using nuclear weapons, says the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee. In an extraordinary step that drew immediate criticism from the Defense Department, Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., discussed with reporters a classified report by the Joint Chiefs of Staff on the military ``net assessment.'' ``We can defend conventionally in Europe,'' Aspin said shortly after Maj. Gen. John D. Robinson publicly discussed with the committee an unclassified version of the report. In a brief exchange with reporters, and later before television cameras, Aspin lent significance to the report's omission of the issue of when North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces would have to resort to nuclear weapons or accept defeat. Previous net assessments included a discussion of this question, he said. ``If an attack comes, NATO bends but it doesn't break. The Warsaw Pact is able to attack and it gets a lot of territory but at no point does it look like NATO can't contain the war,'' Aspin said of the classified report's conclusion. The joint chiefs based that view on Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's announcement in December 1988 of unilateral troop reductions and the U.S. intelligence community's conclusion last year that the Soviet threat has lessened. Assuming a further positive influence from a U.S.-Soviet agreement on reducing conventional forces _ a treaty not expected until later this year _ ``at that point, they (the joint chiefs) say we ought to be able to defend right at the forward line, the forward base,'' Aspin said. The congressman took it one step further, taking into account the disintegration of the Warsaw Pact and the drive for democracy in Eastern Europe. ``I look at this net assessment and I say, we win. We can go the other way. NATO wins, the good guys win,'' Aspin said. Defense Department spokesman Pete Williams said Aspin may believe he is free to discuss classified information, but ``as an employee of the executive branch, I'm not.'' Williams said Defense Secretary Dick Cheney approved the net assessment within the past two weeks and a declassified version of the full report might be released early in April. Aspin argued that the changes cited in the report should be reflected in Cheney's $292 billion defense budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. But he said the spending blueprint ``accounted for none of these.'' ``The defense budget is seriously out of date,'' Aspin said. The proposal calls for a nearly $1 billion increase in spending on the Strategic Defense Initiative, $5.5 billion for the B-2 stealth bomber and funding for two land-based nuclear missile systems. Cheney has argued that although the Soviets have cut their conventional forces, they continue to upgrade their strategic weapons. However, according to Aspin a section of the classified report states that the Soviets' ``strategic change is incomplete and may be reversible under some conceivable political and military circumstances.'' Earlier at the Armed Services Committee hearing, Gen. Robinson said the number of days the West could count on for warning of an all-out Soviet attack had increased. Previously, the United States has estimated that it would have 14 days of warning. But based on last year's intelligence community assessment and Soviet troop reductions, Robinson said that number can be multiplied ``by a factor of four or five.'' ``Post-CFE pushes it out further,'' Robinson said referring to the proposed Conventional Forces in Europe treaty.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: White House May be Setting Trap for Democrats on Taxes
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration may have enhanced prospects for a watershed budget accord in its warm reaction to a plan by Rep. Dan Rostenkowski. Or it may just have set a trap for Democrats. Either way, the White House decision to sing praises of the ambitious proposal by the Democratic chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee has congressional Democrats in disarray. By short-circuiting the budget process and responding to a plan that no committee has yet voted upon, Bush mischievously managed to put Democrats on the defensive and score points for a willingness to negotiate. In fact, there is nothing on the table to negotiate at this time. Furthermore, the administration's assertions of disagreement with some elements of the package _ its advocacy of a Social Security freeze and tax increases _ make it sound like Democrats in general have embraced such proposals. In fact, Rostenkowski thus far has mustered little Democratic support for his plan. It is not before the House and Senate budget committees, which under law must come up with their own deficit-reduction plans by next month. The administration's stance enables it to claim credit for a willingness to deal on tough budget-deficit issues, while making it appear that Democrats have proposed what Republicans always accused them of advocating: higher taxes and a desire to tamper with Social Security. ``We're not trying to be cute on this,'' insists Richard G. Darman, Bush's wily budget director, architect of this week's White House maneuvering. Darman says he wants the administration's response to be taken on its face: a hats off to Rostenkowski for putting together ``the first serious proposal that has been put in the public domain by Democrats.'' Darman concedes that Rostenkowski's proposal is not a formal Democratic plan. But, he told reporters Tuesday, the congressional budget committees ``are not yet close to being able to put together a budget resolution and it's important that there be something there to negotiate with.'' Many analysts do suggest that the administration's actions this week _ whatever the motive _ could serve as the catalyst that might lead to a long-elusive major budget compromise between the White House and Congress. Such a wide-based bipartisan compromise might be the only way that the administration could eventually sign off on a measure that included tax increases. Bush seemed to point himself in this direction at a news conference Tuesday when he was asked if he could assure Americans there would be no tax increase this year as part of a deficit-reduction package. ``I'm only one player,'' he said. He added that he has no plans to change his own views on taxes. But that's still a lot milder than his ``Read my lips: no new taxes'' of yore. Darman has a reputation as a spinner of carefully crafted webs. In fact, ``Darmanesque'' has become a standard description in the nation's capital for complicated and often vexing stratagems. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., has tried to play down Bush's unexpected receptivity to Rostenkowski's plan, suggesting it stems mainly from their personal friendship. ``That doesn't speak of any substantive change on the part of the president to consider new taxes,'' Foley said. Rostenkowski's proposal would raise the tax rate on the highest-income Americans from 28 percent to 33 percent and increase excise taxes on gasoline, liquor and tobacco. It would impose a one-year freeze on federal spending, including Social Security benefits. And it would channel ``peace dividend'' defense savings into further reducing the deficit. His plan envisions a balanced budget by 1994 and would replace the current Gramm-Rudman law which calls for graduated deficit-reduction steps. Foley asserted that winning approval for new taxes was ``politically and governmentally impossible without the prior approval and support of the president, who has ... destroyed any opportunity for a long-term deficit reduction by refusing to consider such new revenues.'' Earlier this year, the administration was caught off guard when Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., proposed a politically appealing plan to reduce Social Security taxes. Moynihan forced the administration into the awkward political posture of having to oppose conservative dogma and go on record in opposition to a tax cut. Now, with its stance on the Rostenkowski proposal, the White House has come full circle _ putting Democratic leaders in a similarly embarrassing position.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Tom Raum covers the White House for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Allied Objections Force Revamping of Plan to Monitor Soviet Arms Cuts
DOC.TEXT: The United States, yielding to the concerns of Western European allies, will propose a plan this week to reduce troops and non-nuclear weapons in Europe with a key monitoring provision deleted, a senior Bush administration official says. The abandoned provision called for stationing monitors at European ports and weapons factories to guard against violations of the 23-nation treaty nearing completion in Vienna. But the official, who outlined the verification package on condition of anonymity, said virtually all the allies objected strenuously to Soviet monitors at their plants and ports. The revised Western proposal will be presented in Vienna as negotiators for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact hold their sixth round of talks on a treaty designed for signing this year. Whether the goal is achieved could depend on how the Soviets respond to the Western proposal. ``The ball is in their court,'' the U.S. official said. The emerging accord calls for sharp reductions in Soviet tanks and artillery in Eastern and Central Europe and a ceiling of 195,000 Soviet troops in the region. There would be much smaller cutbacks in U.S. tanks and troops. The United States could keep 195,000 soldiers and airmen in West Germany, Belgium, the Netherlands, Denmark and Luxembourg, and an additional 30,000 in other NATO countries. President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev want the treaty to be ready for signing by the 16 NAT0 allies and the seven Warsaw Pact countries at a 35-nation summit meeting before the end of the year. But several issues remain unresolved. Most important among them is a procedure to guard against cheating. The task involves policing the vast expanse of Europe _ from the Ural Mountains in the Soviet Union to the Atlantic Ocean _ to make sure the limits on tanks and armored personnel carriers, antiaircraft artillery, airplanes, helicopters and troops are honored. The official said a ``web'' of safeguards would be offered by NATO negotiators in Vienna, including on-site inspection of U.S. and Soviet troops and tank deployments. Information on non-nuclear armories would be exchanged by the two alliances and then its accuracy checked by monitors who would go to the military installations. The monitoring system would be supplemented by aerial surveillance under President Bush`s ``Open Skies'' proposal as well as a second system of overflights to check on suspicious developments. And the two sides would have the right to demand to check out suspicious movements of troops and equipment under a system of ``challenge inspections.'' Agreement within NATO on these measures, and on a plan for destroying excess tanks which also will be presented in Vienna this week, would improve prospects for concluding the treaty. But, the official said, virtually all the NATO allies objected to having ``the KGB standing there'' as Soviet or other Warsaw Pact inspectors were stationed at weapons plants or checked the entry or shipment of arms from European ports. That, he said, would reveal to the Soviets information about the manufacture and delivery of Western arms that the allies wanted to keep secret. The United States accepted a similar arrangement at American plants and ports to police a 1988 treaty with the Soviet Union to ban intermediate-range nuclear missiles. But when it came to intrusive inspection in Europe under the conventional forces treaty, ``the allies felt the United States was pushing them too hard on the right of manufacturers and their national rights,'' the official said. He added: ``They were most insistent on these points ... That set of proposals went absolutely nowhere in Europe.'' Bush predicted last year that the treaty would be completed by this spring at the latest, but that prediction has proven overly optimistic. However, the official said 90 to 95 percent of the treaty is completed.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Seeks Quick Review of Flag-Burning Law
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court is likely to announce soon _ possibly Monday _ whether it will grant a Bush administration request for speeded-up review of a new law making it a crime to burn the American flag. The justices, in recess this week, will meet in a private conference Friday to consider the request and could announce a decision when they return to the bench. The Justice Department, while expressing doubts about the law's constitutionality, filed legal papers with the court Tuesday urging it to move rapidly and uphold the law. Department lawyers called for expedited consideration of the politically charged issue, proposing oral arguments before the court April 25 that would permit the justices to rule before the current term ends in July. The department urged the high court to overturn rulings by two judges, in Washington and in Seattle, who declared the law unconstitutional. The judges ``overvalued ... the narrow category of expressive conduct at stake and undervalued the compelling governmental interest that lies at the core of the statute: the preservation of the flag as the unique symbol of our nation,'' the department said. Conviction under the law carries a one-year jail sentence. The Justice Department acknowledged that President Bush allowed the law to be enacted last Oct. 28 without his signature because he questions its constitutionality and prefers a constitutional amendment to assure the same protection for the flag. Bush said he has ``serious doubts (the law) can withstand Supreme Court review'' and said ``a constitutional amendment is the only way to ensure that our flag is protected from desecration.'' A lawyer representing the defendants in both flag cases accused the administration of seeking expedited Supreme Court review so that the flag will be an issue in this year's campaign for House and Senate seats. ``If the court issues its decision in July and it's in our favor, there is no doubt a (constitutional) amendment will be introduced'' in Congress, said David Cole, an attorney with the Center for Constitutional Rights. Cole said he will ask the court not to consider the case until October because ``this is a very important constitutional question. It shouldn't be subject to political considerations.'' The Supreme Court, voting 5-4 last June, struck down a Texas law barring desecration or destruction of the flag. The court said burning the American flag as a form of political protest is protected by the Constitution's free speech guarantees. That case echoed themes from the 1988 presidential campaign in which Bush stressed patriotic values and attacked his Democratic opponent, Gov. Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts, for vetoing state legislation to require that public schoolteachers lead their classes in the Pledge of Allegiance. The June Supreme Court decision touched off a political firestorm and ultimately led to enactment of the new flag-protection law. Democratic leaders in Congress supported the law as an alternative to a constitutional amendment. In recent decisions, federal judges in Washington and in Seattle dismissed criminal charges against defendants accused of flag burning, saying the new law violated their free speech rights. In the Washington case, three demonstrators were arrested on Oct. 30 after they set several flags on fire during a protest outside the U.S. Capitol. Four demonstrators were charged with burning a flag outside a Seattle post office the previous day. The Justice Department brief was signed by Solicitor General Kenneth W. Starr, the administration's top courtroom attorney, and other department lawyers.

DOC.HEAD: Suspected Arson Attack on Building Housing Nuclear Corporation
DOC.TEXT: A fire killed a firefighter early today at a government-funded corporation that works on nuclear technology, and authorities said political extremists may have set the blaze. Koichi Fujita, a 24-year-old firefighter, suffocated while battling the blaze on a basement floor of a nine-story building housing the Power Reactor and Nuclear Fuel Development Corp., Tokyo police reported. Police said the fire, which also destroyed three cars owned by the corporation, may have been started by a time-ignition device set off by extremists who oppose nuclear projects. A police official speaking on condition of anonymity said investigators found batteries and other metal debris, apparently used for the device, near the burned cars. The corporation, set up in 1967, handles the development of a fast breeder reactor and of a recycling technology on spent nuclear fuel. It is also handling the development of technology to store nuclear waste at a facility under construction at a village in Aomori, 360 miles, northeast of Tokyo. Radical groups have opposed the project.

DOC.HEAD: Shuttle Atlantis Comes Home Piggyback Fashion
DOC.TEXT: Space shuttle Atlantis received a warm welcome home after arriving atop a modified Boeing 747 at Kennedy Space Center, the final stop on a coast-to-coast trip that was interrupted by bad weather. ``After several delays, it's good to have the bird back in the nest again,'' said NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham. The jet touched down Tuesday near where Atlantis lifted off 13 days earlier on a secret mission to put a $500 million spy in orbit. Before landing, the jet flew about 5,000 feet over the beaches south of Kennedy so spectators could see the shuttle riding piggyback on the plane. Atlantis blasted off Feb. 28 after five delays, all but one attributed to bad weather. Its trip back from Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., to Kennedy also was plagued by uncooperative weather. Rain can damage the shuttle's thermal tiles. The shuttle and jet completed the last leg of the trip home by way of Columbus Air Force Base, Miss., where the craft arrived Tuesday. The plane had been grounded since Sunday at Biggs Army Airfield in Texas by bad weather. Buckingham said the delays would not affect Atlantis' next flight, in July, another secret Pentagon mission.

DOC.HEAD: Flamboyant Former Prime Minister Fails in Comeback Effort
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with unofficial returns, Gairy loss. Picks up 8th pvs, `The election...' Minor editing thereafter to TRIM and CONFORM
DOC.TEXT: Sir Eric Gairy, the flamboyant former prime minister, failed Tuesday in his comeback attempt in Grenada's second election since the 1983 U.S.-led invasion, complete but unofficial returns indicated. However, all four political parties opposing Gairy also failed to gained a parliamentary majority, creating uncertainty over who will lead the tiny Caribbean island's next government. With final but unofficial results in from all 15 parliamentary constituencies, the National Democratic Congress of Nicholas Brathwaite led with seven seats in the House of Representatives, or parliament, one short of the necessary majority to form a government, Radio Grenada reported. Gairy's Grenada United Labor Party won four seats, but Gairy himself was defeated in his parliamentary district, the radio said, citing the Electoral Commission. Gairy had dominated the island's politics for three decades before he was ousted in a Marxist revolution 11 years ago. Radio Grenada said The National Party of acting Prime Minister Ben Jones and the New National Party led by Keith Mitchell won two seats each. Jones and Mitchell were both returned to parliament. The leftist Maurice Bishop Patriotic Movement failed to gain any parliamentary seats. Radio Grenada said the results were complete but unofficial. Official results were to be announced Wednesday. Although the outcome was inconclusive, Brathwaite, 65, a moderate who led a 13-month interim government after the 1983 invasion, was in a strong position to become the next prime minister. He said before the election that he would not be interested in forming a coalition government, but most observers thought it likely Brathwaite and Jones would merge their parties to form a government. There was no immediate comment from any of the candidates. Turnout was estimated at 60 percent of the 58,296 eligible voters, sharply below the 85 percent recorded in the 1984 election. The election happened to fall on the 11th anniversary of the Marxist coup that toppled Gairy's authoritarian government on March 13, 1979, and brought to power the People's Revolutionary Government of the late Prime Minister Maurice Bishop. A rift in Bishop's government led to his assassination, along with 10 other people, on Oct. 19, 1983. Six days later, U.S. Marines and paratroopers, along with a small regional force, invaded the island and ousted a Marxist junta that had seized power. The Reagan administration, already alarmed by Bishop's close ties with Cuba and the Soviet Union, said the invasion was necessary to protect hundreds of medical students and prevent the island from becoming a bastion of Communist aggression in the region. Gairy, 68, and apparently nearly blind with glaucoma, earlier said he would not contest the election unless a ``miracle'' improved his sight. Last month, however, he said ``a source greater than I'' ordained that he once again lead Grenada. He also said the election came on the anniversary of his ouster not by coincidence but because it had been ``arranged cosmically by a divine force.'' Gairy, who was Grenada's first prime minister after independence from Britain in 1974, was widely regarded as repressive and corrupt. As early as 1961, Britain dissolved Gairy's pre-independence government because of alleged financial irregularities. Gairy's party won 36 percent of the vote in the 1984 election but gained only one seat, which it later lost in a party defection. The merged New National Party won 14 seats, with 58.5 percent of the vote, but later split into three groups. The election followed the death of conservative Prime Minister Herbert Blaize in December.

DOC.HEAD: Study Finds Fat Arrives Between Ages of 25 and 34
DOC.TEXT: Young adults face the greatest risk of becoming fat, and black women are especially vulnerable, according to a decade-long study of nearly 10,000 people from age 24 to 74. Women of both races were twice as likely as men to gain a lot of weight, and women from 25 to 44 years who began the study overweight gained the most weight of all subjects, researchers found. Among both sexes, those ages 25 to 34 were most likely to experience a major weight gain, according to the study in this month's Archives of Internal Medicine, published by the Chicago-based American Medical Association. The findings ``suggest that among adults, those in their 20s should be in the primary target group for obesity prevention efforts,'' said the study led by epidemiologist David Williamson of the nutrition division at the U.S. Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta. Prevention, rather than treatment, is the key because so many people have trouble losing weight, Williamson said by telephone Tuesday. He recommends ``just regular sensible exercise, like walking,'' and eating a diet low in fat and high in fruits and vegetables. Williamson noted that while women may be more likely to gain weight than men, previous research has found that men face a greater risk of developing weight-related problems such as heart disease and diabetes. Women tend to carry excess weight in the buttocks and hips, while men's extra poundage usually is concentrated in the stomach area, nearer the heart and other vital organs and thus more likely to cause problems, he said. Among women 25- to 34-years-old, blacks were 40 percent more likely than whites to gain a lot of weight, Williamson's study found. For women from 35 to 44, blacks were 80 percent more likely to face a major weight gain, the researchers found. As many as one-third of the 9,862 subjects were overweight when the study began. They were measured once between 1971 and 1975, and again between 1981 and 1984. Women ages 25 to 44 years who began the study overweight gained the most weight of all subjects. Researchers defined a major weight gain as an increase of about 20 percent, or an estimated 30 pounds for a person of average height. Among all women ages 25 to 44 who were overweight at the start, 14.2 percent experienced a major weight gain, compared with 5.6 percent among men of the same age. Among women of that age group who were of normal weight when the monitoring began, 6.2 percent gained a lot of weight, compared with 2.9 percent among men. After age 55, weight levels in men and women studied began declining. The researchers did not attempt to explain the weight-gain differences among women, men and blacks, Williamson said. ``Factors related to the excess risk of major weight gain that may be different in men and women include childbearing, diet, physical activity, and patterns of morbidity and mortality,'' the researchers wrote. But they added, ``The question of why women in the United States are at substantially greater risk of major weight gain during adulthood than men warrants further study.'' Although women tend to live longer than men, they also tend to suffer more illnesses, which can affect activity and eating levels, Williamson said. Black men were not studied individually because too few of them participated in the study, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Trip: A Pair of Jaguars, an Empty Box
With PM-Quayle
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle's visit to Paraguay brought his family two new members _ a pair of jaguars named Chaco and Paloma. But the two young ones won't ever live in the vice president's official Washington residence. Quayle and his wife Marilyn were presented with the pair of 5-month-old jaguars by President Andres Rodriguez. The cats are native to Paraguay. Quayle said he would give them to a zoo in the United States. The animals seemed tame and cuddly as the Quayles played with them on the lawn at the home of U.S. Ambassador Timothy Towell. Quayle didn't get scratched but noted that their claws were very sharp. The vice president's traveling press corps didn't have the same luck. A radio reporter ended up with a two-inch scratch on his wrist when one of the cubs caught a claw on his ring and drew blood trying to free itself.

In case anyone wondered what reading material shaped Quayle as a youth, the answer is in. Like many kids of his generation, the 43-year-old Quayle disclosed Tuesday, he grew up on the children's newsletter, Weekly Reader. The subject came up after he planted a palm tree to mark his visit to Paraguay, the first such trip by an American of his rank in 32 years. The last visit was by then-Vice President Richard Nixon, Quayle recalled. ``I was 11 then. I remember reading it in Weekly Reader _ how Vice President Nixon planted a tree here. I always wanted to do that,'' Quayle told reporters. ``It's true,'' he added, laughing. Maybe his tree will fare better than Nixon's. ``It's dying,'' an embassy aide confided.

Quayle had some hindsight impressions a day after his Monday meeting with Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega _ the man conservative Republicans like Quayle have loved to hate for years. Meeting him face to face _ and talking over a 1{-hour lunch in Santiago, Chile _ Quayle came away with the observation that Ortega, defeated in the Feb. 25 election, was ``very cordial, very polite.'' He added, ``He knows what he's doing. His conversation was very direct.'' For perspective, the vice president sought the opinion of his State Department translator, Stephanie Van Reigersberg, who has been in several meetings with Ortega over the years. ``She felt there was a new sense of sincerity about Ortega,'' Quayle said. He said his talk with the Nicaraguan was ``extremely positive.'' However, Quayle quickly added, ``This is just one meeting'' and everything can't be known from only one encounter.

When dignitaries travel to foreign countries, exchange of gifts with hosts is in line with protocol. That Quayle ended up with an empty gift box in Buenos Aires, Argentina, was not meant as a slight, he was told. He got it Tuesday when he visited a tall ship that had participated in the U.S. bicentennial regatta in New York. The captain of the Libertad, Alberto Valerio Pico, welcomed him aboard, showed him around the 27-sail frigate and said he had learned only that day that Quayle would stop by. Thus, he said, he had no time to get an appropriate gift. Instead he gave Quayle a gift-wrapped box. It was empty, Pico explained, adding, ``We haven't had time to fill it with the respect a vice president deserves.'' He said he would fill it when his ship sails to Baltimore in July. Quayle answered, ``I promise I won't open it till then.''

DOC.HEAD: Tornado Kills One Person; Up to 15 Homes and Businesses Damaged
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with two fatalities, 14 injured, a dozen tornadoes hitting area, two missing in Hesston, number of businesses damaged, details on deaths, tornado damage in Iowa, other details; no pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos HUT1, DC11
DOC.TEXT: At least a dozen tornadoes Tuesday battered south-central Kansas, killing a 6-year-old boy and another person, injuring 14 others and extensively damaging more than 100 homes, authorities said. Tornadoes also blew through sections of Iowa, Oklahoma and Nebraska, causing widespread property damage, but no serious injuries, authorities said. In Hesston, authorities were searching for two missing people. The town of about 3,000 poeple ``took a direct hit and there is major damage,'' said a dispatcher with the Kansas Highway Patrol in Wichita. Gov. Mike Hayden traveled to Hesston, which was left without electricity. About 40 percent to 50 percent of the town sustained major damage from the tornado, and debris was strewn everywhere, said Phillip Kloster, manager of the nearby town of Newton who was helping at the command post in Hesston. Thirteen people hurt in the Kansas twisters were taken to the Newton Medical Center, about eight miles south of Hesston, said spokeswoman Chris McKellip. Most had scratches, cuts and bruises. A 56-year-old woman who'd been traveling through Hesston when the twister struck was treated for a broken arm at Wesley Medical Center in Wichita, said a hospital spokeswoman. A dozen tornadoes touched down within a wide area of south-central Kanas after 4:30 p.m., and continued into the evening, said Highway Patrol Trooper Martin Berneking. ``We have approximately between 75 and 100 homes that have been anywhere from completely destroyed to fairly seriously damaged,'' said Hesston city administrator Jay Wieland. At least five businesses were destroyed and 15 were damaged. ``Surprisingly, we have very few people at this point who are reported missing,'' Wieland said. ``We have temporary housing set up at the high school and at the college. We have National Guard on their way in now to help secure the area.'' About 50 people went to Hesston High School's gym to spend the night, said Principal Marvin Estes. The 6-year-old boy died at a home south of Burrton, which is about 15 miles southwest of Hesston, when a chimney and fireplace collapsed into a basement, said Harvey County Sheriff's Investigator Byron Motter. Another child suffered minor head wounds in the basement, where seven people had sought shelter from the storm. Another person died in a home near the small town of Goessel, which is about 10 miles northwest of Hesston, said Marion County Sheriff Ed Davies. The victim's name was not released. In Hesston, the home of Charla Buscher, 14, was seriously damaged by the twister. ``We're all really shook up,'' said Charla. ``A lot of the houses here are leveled ... We had a car wash. It's gone. ``The northwest corner of Hesston is just, it's gone,'' she said. ``There's nothing left. It just looks like as if it's just starting construction'' At a Pizza Hut, about 15 customers and employees took cover from the storm in a walk-in freezer and two bathrooms, ``the two safest places in the building,'' said restaurant supervisor John Anderson. The storm tore the roof off the restaurant, but no one was injured. ``I was outside and I heard it roaring,'' said Dennis Eck, an employee at a gas station, ``I flipped switches and we hit the deck. The pumps are all torn up. We've got roof damage.'' Eck said businesses north of his service station were demolished, and that the post office suffered extensive damage. Civil Defense workers were on the scene. Initial reports said the worst damage in Hesston was on the western edge of town. Wieland said power would be restored in a day and a half to two days, and that emergency repairs were being made to water service. In the small eastern Iowa town of Worthington, a tornado destroyed the fire house, 10 homes and three businesses, disaster officials said. Fifty residents left homeless sought shelter with the Red Cross. About 10 miles southwest of Worthingin, a twister leveled at least three houses and damaged 13 farms, said Disaster Services Director Dianne De Sotel. ``People were spotting them everywhere,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Subway Operators Don't Know How Fast They're Going
DOC.TEXT: Federal safety officials are calling for 6,000 New York City subway cars to be equipped with speedometers, after finding that some were going 15 miles per hour faster than the operators thought. The recommendation came in a National Transportation Safety Board meeting Tuesday on a crash in which a train carrying passengers bumped into a fare-collection train at the 103rd Street station in uptown Manhattan on March 10, 1989. Forty people were injured, one seriously. Older subway systems in New York, Boston and Philadelphia are the only ones in the country without speed indicators on the cars, said the board's senior rail accident investigator, William Pugh. More modern systems are controlled by computers that automatically report and control train speed and keep trains spaced apart. The NTSB voted 4-0 to blame the crash on the unauthorized use of a jumper cable that caused signal lights in the station to malfunction. A light had indicated the station was clear of trains, investigators said. The board said the fact the train was going faster than the posted 18 mph contributed to the seriousness of the crash. But it did not blame the operator for the excessive speed, saying the New York City Transit Authority failed to ``furnish a reasonable means for operators to determine speed.'' Damage from the crash totaled $360,000. Pugh said checks of New York subways with radar guns found that operators usually underestimated their speed, often by as much as 15 mph. He estimated that retrofitting all of New York's cars with speedometers would cost about $6 million. Equipping new cars as they are added to the system would cost less. Upgrading the 450-mile system with computer controls that operate most of the nation's subway system would cost more than $1 billion, Pugh said. Board member Jim Burnett suggested cars might also be equipped with recorders to aid transit officials and investigators in determining the speed of cars. But the board elected to ask for installation of speed indicators first. The safety panel recommended a change in the design of the operator cabin door. It said the operator was trapped inside and had to be pulled out through a window. It also called for the transit authority to develop a procedure for notifying train operators when an unscheduled train is placed in front of them. Schedules of fare collection trains, which travel from station to station to pick up cash, are not posted for security reasons, investigators said.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Votes Immunity for Ex-HUD Official in Pierce Probe
DOC.TEXT: A motion granting a former top housing official immunity to testify about ex-HUD Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. is going to a federal court following unanimous approval by a House panel. The House Government Operations Committee voted 35-0 on Tuesday to approve a motion to compel the testimony of Dubois Gilliam, now serving an 18-month federal prison sentence for a HUD-related conviction. Gilliam is expected to testify in late April or early May before the Government Operations housing subcommittee, which has been investigating scandals at the Department of Housing and Urban Development during Pierce's tenure in the Reagan administration. Gilliam, formerly deputy assistant secretary of HUD and a top aide to Pierce, has been cooperating with the committee. A special prosecutor, Arlin Adams, is looking into allegations of fraud and influence-peddling in one of the HUD programs. Subcommittee chairman Tom Lantos, D-Calif., said the federal court's approval is automatic but may take 30 days. The immunity would mean Gilliam could not be prosecuted based on his truthful testimony before Congress or information derived from that testimony. HUD Secretary Jack Kemp, meanwhile, defended the Bush administration's proposed housing legislation as ``serious and responsible'' under critical questioning from Democrats in an appearance before the House Banking Committee. Kemp has labeled his housing proposal ``HOPE,'' for home ownership and opportunity for people everywhere. Its centerpiece is Kemp's plan for encouraging home ownership among low- and moderate-income families. Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., called the proposal ``more hype than hope'' and ``long on words and short on action.'' Rep. Joseph Kennedy, D-Mass., said the administration's housing budget is ``woefully inadequate,'' and that by failing to provide new subsidized housing it would ``allow and condone homelessness.''

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Says Political Support is `Still Intact'
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry is refusing to answer questions about the cocaine possession and perjury charges he faces, but says his political support is ``still intact'' and promises to announce soon whether he will seek re-election. Barry, who returned to the nation's capital Tuesday after six weeks of substance abuse treatment, said he has no plans to resign but stopped short of announcing that he will run for a fourth term. ``I'm not going to announce any decisions today,'' Barry said as supporters chanted ``Four more years.'' ``My political organization is still intact, despite some defections ... we will announce some plans in the very near future,'' he said. Barry entered a Florida substance abuse treatment center three days after his Jan. 18 arrest on a cocaine possession charge, and enrolled in a South Carolina treatment program on Feb. 22. During his absence, a federal grand jury returned the indictments. He said Tuesday that he was suffering from alcoholism and from addiction to Valium and Xanax, two anti-anxiety prescription drugs. Top aides have said privately that Barry also was suffering from a problem with cocaine. The Democratic mayor's return to the nation's capital resembled a campaign speech in a number of ways. The address was given in a downtown municipal building packed with city employees who repeatedly interrupted Barry's address with cheering. Barry gave a generally upbeat speech in which he stressed his continuing recovery from substance abuse and desire to serve the city. However, he refused to comment on the eight-count criminal indictment, except for a confident prediction that ``the truth will come out in the trial.'' The indictment was returned on Feb. 15, nearly a month after the FBI videotaped Barry allegedly smoking crack cocaine in a downtown hotel room with a female friend. Barry's remaining supporters were taking a wait-and-see attitude toward a possible re-election campaign. ``We're supposed to meet in the next couple of days to hear what his decision is,'' said fund-raiser Jeffrey Gildenhorn. ``He did come across as very sincere, very candid and very human, but I'd have to see what kind of a platform he would have before I decided to get behind him.'' Gildenhorn will host a $100-per-plate breakfast for Barry's legal defense fund on Sunday. Other supporters have defected, however. Barry's former financial co-chairman is now a spokesman for the mayoral bid by Walter Fauntroy, the district's nonvoting delegate to Congress. Other supporters have distanced themselves, while some politicians have called for the Democratic mayor to resign. During his statement, Barry said his faith in God and the love of supporters and family members had seen him through his substance abuse treatment. ``To those persons, I am eternally grateful, moved and humbled,'' Barry said. ``I'm back and I feel good about my treatment program. I feel good about myself, about my wife, my son, and about the people of Washington.'' The mayor declined to discuss the five cocaine possession counts and three perjury charges filed against him, referring all questions to his attorney, R. Kenneth Mundy. Barry blamed his drug problems on ``repressed anger as well as prolonged and overwhelming stress'' created by his job. ``I had no idea of the depths of my problem,'' Barry said. ``For a long time, I had known there was something very wrong and I no longer felt good about myself. But I did not want to face the extent of that problem.'' The mayor said top aides, including City Administrator Carol Thompson, would continue managing district affairs while he seeks after-care. However, he said he will gradually resume his duties.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,352.13, down 268.44 points, or 0.82 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Scores of Demonstrators Arrested in Push for Rights Bill
DOC.TEXT: A House committee took this year's first significant action on a major civil rights bill for disabled Americans on the same day that scores of protesters demanding its immediate enactment were arrested and carted off in their wheelchairs. ``It is a priority for passage in this session of the Congress,'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., told unpacified demonstrators Tuesday inside the Capitol. The Energy and Commerce Committee, meantime, approved the Americans With Disabilities Act by a 40-3 vote after amending it to soften the impact on Amtrak and make other minor changes. Police arrested 104 people, many of whom had chained their wheelchairs together, after deliberate acts of civil disobedience following a confrontation in the Capitol Rotunda with Foley and House Minority Leader Robert H. Michel, R-Ill. ``I am absolutely satisfied it will reach the floor, we will have a conference with the Senate and it will become law,'' Foley told the demonstrators. ``Will it be on the floor in 24 hours? No.'' Protesters demanding that the bill be passed within one day greeted that remark with boos. Advocates say that further delays leave the bill vulnerable to ``killer amendments,'' such as one that would exempt small businesses from requirements to accommodate people with handicaps. The compromise between disabilities activists and the Amtrak passenger railroad was the first House committee vote on the bill this year. The Education and Labor Committee approved the bill last November by a vote of 35-0. The Senate, where one committee had jurisdiction, passed the bill last September by a 76-8 vote. Full hearings are expected later this month by both the House Judiciary and Public Works and Transportation committees, meaning the landmark legislation could become law this spring. The pace of the bill through Congress has slowed considerably since last fall, when supporters predicted President Bush would receive a bill by Christmas. The bill would guaranteed the rights of America's disabled population, estimated to be at least 43 million, to employment, phone service, and public and private accommodations such as restaurants, shops and shopping malls. Members of the small business community say the bill imposes an unfair and costly burden on them at the same time it sets ill-defined standards that will lead to endless litigation. Supporters point to the enthusiastic support of the White House and say the Senate version carefully phases in the requirements while exempting the smallest businesses from its employment provisions. Recent statements by the Justice Department have raised questions about White House commitment to the bill because of its relationship to other civil rights legislation that the White House opposes. Those questions, combined with delays in moving the bill through Congress, gave rise to a peaceful demonstration Monday outside the Capitol and the more boisterous one Tuesday. Capitol Police spokesman G.T. Nevitt said the protesters face possible sentences of up to six months in jail on each of the charges against them: unlawful entry and demonstrating inside the Capitol. The first charge has a maximum fine of $100, and the second, $500. All were being held while an attorney negotiated for their release, Nevitt said.

DOC.HEAD: Army Commander Endorses Defense Against Rogue Missile Attack
DOC.TEXT: The head of the Army's Star Wars antimissile research endorses the idea of building a limited U.S.-based defense against an accidental or rogue launch of Soviet nuclear missiles. ``We're very interested in it here,'' said Gen. Robert D. Hammond, commander of the Strategic Defense Command, whose antimissile work accounts for about one-third of the Pentagon's total effort to develop a defense against globe-circling ballistic missiles. Many members of Congress, including Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, have advocated a limited Star Wars defense that could protect against an accidental or unauthorized Soviet missile launch. The Pentagon has been cool to the idea, and the Bush administration has not officially endorsed it. Supporters of the Strategic Defense Initiative, the formal name for Star Wars, fear that emphasis on a limited protection system would turn the nation away from former President Reagan's grander original vision announced seven years ago of building a space-based defense against a full-scale Soviet attack. A defense against accidental missile launches would be almost totally land-based. In a wide-ranging interview with a group of reporters visiting the Army's Advanced Research Center, where SDI work is conducted, Hammond said he liked the idea of a limited defense because it would use weapons and tracking systems already under development by the Army. The Air Force is in charge of most space-based elements of Star Wars research. ``We've done considerable planning and analysis of what might be involved if a decision were made to deploy it; there has been no such decision,'' Hammond said. The main feature of a limited system would be ground-based interceptor rockets designed to destroy incoming ballistic missiles before they re-enter the Earth's atmosphere. One hundred such rockets could be deployed at a single U.S. site without violating the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile treaty. James C. Katechis, manager of the Army's land-based interceptor program, said the first flight test is scheduled for this summer. He declined to give an exact date. Other officials at the Army Research Center repeatedly discouraged reporters from inquiring about a limited missile defense. William Congo, an Army public affairs officer, said a series of briefings for reporters was deliberately designed not to focus on the subject. Asked why, Congo said, ``Because it's not a program'' _ meaning the limited defense idea does not have official Defense Department backing. Hammond stressed that he believed an accidental launch-protection system should not be the final goal of the Pentagon's missile defense research. He said it should be capable of being expanded to add space-based elements that would give broader protection against missiles. Even so, Hammond appeared to cast doubt on whether Congress ever will approve a grander Star Wars system. ``I don't know if a decision ever is going to be made to deploy a full-up'' strategic defense as advocated by President Bush, he said. In earlier comments, Hammond was more upbeat about the outlook for Star Wars. He said that despite recent cutbacks in SDI spending, Bush still should be able to make a decision soon on whether to move from research, development and testing to actual deployment. ``I believe easily within the next three years a decision could be made on deployment; yes, or no, are you going to put up a defense,'' Hammond said. He added, however, that the timetable would slip if Congress did not approve at least a modest increase in financing beyond the $3.6 billion allocated for the current fiscal year. Bush has requested about $4.5 billion for the 1991 budget.

DOC.HEAD: Powers of New Soviet President
With PM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Some of the new presidential powers included in legislation approved by the Congress of People's Deputies on Tuesday: _ To propose legislation. _ To negotiate treaties. _ To overrule decisions of the Council of Ministers and other state bodies if they violate the constitution and endanger people's rights and freedoms. _ To veto laws passed by the Supreme Soviet working legislature, which can override the veto with a two-thirds vote. _ To declare a state of emergency or martial law, but only after a warning to the area concerned, with the consent of the republic's presidium and approval by two-thirds of the national Supreme Soviet _ the standing legislature elected by the Congress. _ To declare war, with immediate consultation with the Supreme Soviet.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Approves Cabinet Status For EPA
DOC.TEXT: The Environmental Protection Agency would become the Department of the Environment under legislation approved by the House Government Operations Committee. Similar legislation elevating the EPA to Cabinet status has been approved by a Senate committee. President Bush wants Congress to pass the legislation in the coming weeks so that an announcement on creating a Cabinet-level department for environmental issues can be made in time for the celebration of Earth Day on April 22. The legislation, which passed the House committee on a voice vote Tuesday, has widespread bipartisan support in both the House and Senate. Supporters of the House and Senate bills argue that creating a Department of the Environment will put the EPA on equal standing with other agencies and departments in government and give the president's chief environmental adviser more prestige when dealing with other countries.
DOC.HEAD: Drug Official Sees New Threat: Heroin Smoking
DOC.TEXT: Increased imports of high-purity heroin have encouraged a new variant _ smoking heroin _ among American drug addictions, said David L. Westrate, in charge of operations at the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration. ``I don't want to give the impression that it's widespread,'' he said. ``We've seen some evidence over the past year in San Francisco and New York.'' American addicts have generally injected the heroin into a vein in liquid form, with a hypodermic needle. In other countries, heroin is more widely smoked, like the opium from which it comes. Westrate pointed to the increased fear among addicts of infected needles. The use of a dirty needle by several addicts is one of the most important ways in which AIDS has been spread. He also noted that many drug users in this country have become used to smoking crack, a potent form of the cocaine derived from coca leaf and grown largely in Latin America. ``They get such a stimulus from the crack, that they need to come down with a depressant _ heroin,'' he told a task force on narcotics set up by the House Foreign Affairs Committee. In a brief interview after the hearing on Tuesday he explained that a comparatively weak solution of heroin can be injected, but the human body will tolerate much purer heroin when it is smoked.
DOC.HEAD: Bork to Teach at George Mason Law School
DOC.TEXT: Former federal appeals judge Robert H. Bork will begin teaching at the Arlington Campus of The George Mason University of Law, school officials announced. Bork, whose nomination to the U.S. Supreme Court was rejected by the Senate in 1987, will teach one class of constitutional law each semester to about 40 second- and third-year students, school officials said Tuesday. ``The circumstances were right. We grabbed the opportunity,'' law school Dean Henry G. Manne told The Washington Post. Bork's appointment is the latest in a series of notable hirings by Manne, who is intent upon building up the name of the school. ``There's no question that they've been doing a remarkable job over there,'' said Thomas Morgan, a law professor at George Washington University and president of the Association of American Law Schools. ``George Mason has improved more than any other law school in the country in the last five years.'' Recognition of that came earlier this week in a U.S. News & World Report survey of law school deans that named George Mason the nation's top ``up-and-coming'' law school. Bork joins Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg, another would-be Supreme Court justice, and several Reagan administration veterans on the George Mason staff.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Announce Suspension of Attacks On Non-Military Targets
DOC.TEXT: Leftist rebels say they've called off assassination attempts on civilian officials and attacks on public transport to show they're serious about resuming peace talks with the rightist government. ``It is now up to (President Alfredo) Cristiani's government,'' Salvador Sanchez Ceren, a member of the guerrilla directorate, told a news conference in Mexico City. ``He has the ball. Let's see him play with it.'' Guerrilla commanders also said Tuesday that they have purchased arms from U.S.-supported Nicaraguan rebels and other Central American sources so they have not been affected by the electoral loss of their Sandinista allies in Nicaragua. The commanders said they would suspend the unpopular civilian attacks to try to seize the initiative against the Salvadoran government and avoid blame for extending the 10-year-old war. In a communique, the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front said that as of Friday, it would cease attacks on public transport, commercial establishments and telephone lines. The communique said the guerrilla front also would halt attacks on government officials and civilians who ``are not part of the military or paramilitary apparatus of the armed forces of El Salvador.'' Schafik Handal, another member of the front's five-person general command, said government and guerrilla negotiating positions have not changed since October, when the two sides met in San Jose, Costa Rica. ``They are setting pre-conditions that would paralyze our activity on a military and political level. That's unrealistic,'' he said. He said the guerrillas were ready to join a political process in El Salvador, but their major condition remains the same: the armed forces must be ``purified, reduced and restructured'' to get rid of those who have tried to suppress political pluralism in favor of a narrow oligarchy. The two commanders said the Salvadoran army is planning to launch attacks on the guerrillas because they believe the guerrilla front has been weakened by the Sandinista election loss in Nicaragua last month. President Daniel Ortega is to give way to President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro on April 25. ``We are not now receiving arms from Nicaragua, and we have never depended on Nicaragua for arms,'' said Handal. ``That is about to become clearer. Central America is a huge arms market.'' ``We have bought arms from the Contras and we have the chance to buy more,'' Sanchez said. The U.S.-supported Contra guerrillas based in Honduras, which lies between Nicaragua and El Salvador, have been fighting the Sandinista government since 1981 and are negotiating to disband and return to Nicaragua following Mrs. Chamorro's victory. The Contras have sold weapons to the leftist Salvadoran rebels in the past _ guerrillas encountered using the weapons in the countryside complained that they were old and beat up _ but Sanchez's was the first confirmation from a senior guerrilla commander. Sanchez called the elections in Nicaragua ``a great example of democracy that should be pursued all over Latin America.'' He added that the question for the Cristiani government is whether it will ``open up a real democratic process.'' Handal noted that although El Salvador's population is almost twice as large as Nicaragua's, the two nations have about the same number of registered voters _ more than 1.7 million in Nicaragua, about 1.8 million in last year's Salvadoran presidential election _ and that abstentions brought the total vote in El Salvador down to less than 1 million in a nation of more than 5.2 million. Handal added the Salvadoran guerrillas would not consider themselves subject to any decisions made by the Central American presidents, who are holding a summit on March 30-31 in Managua. More than 71,000 people, mostly civilians, have been killed in the decade-old war.

DOC.HEAD: Police Say Vigilante Killed Man Moments After Mall Slaying
DOC.TEXT: A man who shot and killed his former girlfriend as shoppers at a mall ran for cover was himself slain by a mystery man in the parking lot who pulled out a gun possibly fitted with a scope, police say. Police had said after the shooting Monday at Irving Mall in this Dallas suburb that they believed Eddie Edwards, 41, shot himself to death while fleeing. But on Tuesday police said witnesses reported Edwards was killed by a vigilante who chased Edwards to his automobile. Police searched for the vigilante today. Capt. Travis Hall said the man would be charged with murder. Edwards killed his former girlfriend, Demetria Yvonne Taylor, 28, after the woman, an instructor at American Airlines, had left her part-time job at a mall clothing store and was walking through the parking lot, police said. Edwards chased her toward a mall entrance and fired twice, missing her, then shot her in the head. He shot her again at close range, Hall said. Officers said one of the shots hit a wall in a video arcade only inches from where a young girl was playing a video game. Other bullets struck objects in an area containing several fast food restaurants where shoppers were eating. Hall said that as Edwards fled from the mall, a man got out of his car, brandishing a big handgun. The man fired two shots at Edwards' car as it left the mall. The man stayed around a few minutes and then drove away, Hall said. Some witnesses said the pistol was equipped with a scope, Hall said. Police found Edwards in his car on a road near the mall, a bullet wound in his side. Hall said police believe the vigilante acted on impulse after witnessing the slaying. ``Edwards violently murdered this woman,'' Hall said. ``She's down, she's wounded, and he goes and shoots her in the head again after she's down.''

DOC.HEAD: Cowboy Clayton Williams Commanded Airwaves, Attention
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf pvs, `Williams ruled ...' to CLARIFY position on abortion.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Texas Primary, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: He owns no shoes, only boots. He rides a horse like a cowhand. He admits to two fistfights since turning 50 and likes a cold beer after work. And now, millionaire oilman-rancher-businessman Clayton Williams, whose hero is John Wayne, is the Republican nominee for governor. ``When we began this journey there weren't a whole lot of folks who gave us much of a shot,'' Williams told a hotel ballroom full of whooping supporters after humbling all comers in Tuesday's GOP primary. ``In the words of that world-famous philospher Jackie Gleason, `How sweet it is.''' Williams, 58, combined his folksy humor, love of all things Texan and a multimillion-dollar TV ad campaign that rivaled a Hollywood movie to rise from an asterisk in the early polls to an outright, no-runoff victory. Throughout the primary, he showed a knack for publicity and a charisma that his trio of lawyer-challengers couldn't touch. When told that one of his Wild West-style TV commercials seemed to lack only John Wayne or Gary Cooper, Williams aide Mona Palmer seemed puzzled. ``We have Clayton,'' she said. ``Why would we need them?'' He was endorsed by retired Texas Rangers. He nicknamed his campaign's barbecue truck ``Lonesome Gov.'' Stumping in Abilene, he grabbed a sledgehammer and personally demonstrated his plan to have drug dealers ``bustin' rocks.'' As his campaign cruised to conclusion, ``Claytie'' saw supporters clamoring for autographs and TV network correspondents lining up for interviews. GOP rival Tom Luce called Williams a candidate more suited to the 1890s, saying, ``You can't ride horseback into the space age.'' Williams just laughed. ``I didn't know I had as many faults as I seem to have until I became the front-runner,'' he said. An unknown political commodity making his first bid for office, the Midland businessman spent nearly $6 million of his own money on his $8 million campaign. Williams says he founded 26 companies and created more than 100,000 jobs since his graduation from Texas A&M in 1954. Those included Clajon Gas Co., the largest individually owned natural gas company in the state, and the ClayDesta long distance phone company. Williams ruled out a tax increase and said he opposed abortion in most cases. Pledging an all-out war on drugs and promising to put a business-based balance sheet to government, Williams delighted in bashing ``career'' politicians. Opponents, including Railroad Commission Chairman Kent Hance, criticized his lack of experience in government. Williams said that was a plus. ``The biggest applause I get is when I say I'm not a politician and I'm not a lawyer. The longer politicians are in Austin or Washington, the worse job they seem to do,'' he said. The three other major Republican candidates all were lawyers. The top three Democrats were current or former officeholders. Drugs are his top issue, Williams said, and a major reason he decided to run. A son became involved with drugs in 1986. ``While he made it, a lot of those little kids didn't. And they're in my heart,'' he said. Williams said he can persuade the Democratic-controlled Legislature to do things his way, pledging to lobby lawmakers personally. A sales call, if you will. ``I am a very good salesman,'' he said, urging onlookers to study his attractive wife, Modesta. ``Take a good look at me, look at my profile. Now look at Modesta. You think I'm not the sellingest son-of-a-gun you've ever seen?''

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: The master of underwater pogo sticking, marathon yodeling and long-distance juggling has muscled his way into the Guinness record book with another peculiar pastime, cranking out 1,551 squat-thrusts in an hour. Ashrita Furman, already a Guinness world record-holder a dozen times over, performed his latest feat Tuesday before awestruck observers in a Manhattan gym. ``I don't think he's human,'' said the gym's owner, Robert Fuchs. Maybe not: After shedding two pounds and nearly passing out during his hourlong stunt, the 35-year-old health food store manager went for a run ``to loosen up.'' His hands still bore bloody blisters from slapping the mat. ``I feel fantastic,'' he said. ``The guy is amazing,'' said Fuchs, owner of the Natural Physique Centre, who kept count and monitored Furman's style. ``He's phenomenal,'' said David Boehm, editor of the U.S. edition of the Guinness Book of World Records. ``He's only one of a number of what you might call nuts setting these records. But he wanted to have more records than anybody else, and he does.'' Furman has walked, hopped, run, rowed, pogo-sticked, somersaulted, bent, balanced and yodeled his way to a dozen entries in Guinness' U.S. edition. His squat-thrusts, once certified by the editors, will make it 13. ``When you edit this book, you're never astounded at anything these people do,'' sighed Boehm. ``If you met Ashrita not knowing about the records, you'd say he was quite sane.'' Furman insists that there's a method to his madness. ``Sure, some of these things are totally stupid,'' he said. ``But it's the principle of the thing. There's a lot of determination and concentration involved.''

DOC.HEAD: Death of Psychologist Bruno Bettelheim Called Suicide
LaserPhoto NY51 sent March 13.
DOC.TEXT: Psychoanalyst Bruno Bettelheim, a student of Sigmund Freud who taught that violent fantasies and fairy tales were part of a healthy child's psychology, killed himself at a nursing home at age 86, authorities said. Bettelheim died Tuesday of suicidal asphyxiation at The Charter House in Silver Spring, Md., said Dr. John E. Smialek, Maryland's medical examiner. Smialek declined to give details. Friends said Bettelheim recently had suffered a stroke. A survivor of the Nazi death camps, Bettelheim came to the United States during World War II and became a pioneer in treating childhood mental disturbances. His vivid writings reached millions of readers. From 1944 to 1973, Bettelheim ran The Sonia Shankman Orthogenic School for disturbed children at the University of Chicago. ``He had a marvelous talent for being able to see the world through the eyes of the other even if the other was a tremendously bizzare person,'' said Jacquelyn Sanders, who took over the school when Bettelheim retired. ``He was able to see the world through that person's eyes so that person no longer became bizzare. ``And he was able to write about them in the way people could understand.'' ``The Uses of Enchantment,'' written with Karen Zelan in 1976, won Bettelheim the National Book Award and the National Book Critic's Circle Award. In it, he held that fairy tales represent the struggle for identity that children wage against their parents. Hostile fantasies toward parents can be safely channeled through enjoyment of punishment inflicted on witches and demons.
