A December review in the Chicago Tribune of his last book, ``Freud's Vienna and Other Essays,'' noted Bettelheim's ``shrewd grasp of the sometimes petty human circumstance behind the grand achievement.'' For example, Bettelheim admitted becoming interested in Freud's theories at age 13 in order to impress a girl. Bettelheim was born Aug. 28, 1903, in Vienna and studied there under Freud. A Jew, he was sent to the Dachau and Buchenwald concentration camps. After his release in 1939, he gained early fame for his study of death camp prisoners. In ``Surviving,'' an essay published in The New Yorker in 1976, he said prisoners who survived were those who lived not for life's sake but for some cultural ideal that transcended them. At the Orthogenic School, Bettelheim insisted on constant attention for severely disturbed children and stayed there from early morning until after midnight nearly every day, said Benjamin Wright, a former colleague. ``He would not take no for an answer no matter how difficult the child was,'' said Wright. The school's success stories include several college professors, authors and a stockbroker, he said. Dr. Raymond Fowler, chief executive of the American Psychological Association in Washington, said Bettelheim's 1950 book on his experiences at the school, ``Love is Not Enough,'' influenced Fowler to become a psychologist. Some of Bettelheim's theories were criticized as overly harsh on parents. He contended at one time that mentally ill mothers were responsible for autism in children. He softened his views in the 1987 book, ``A Good Enough Parent: A Book on Child-Rearing,'' which said parents are innately ``good enough'' to raise children. Bettelheim became professor emeritus at the University of Chicago in 1975. ``He told me that once you were in a camp, you could never escape the cruelty,'' a longtime colleague and friend, Rudolf Ekstein, told The New York Times. ``He turned it upside down when he started his school for disturbed children. It was a protected, caring environment, the mirror opposite of the camps.'' His other works included ``Dynamics of Prejudice'' (1950), ``Truants from Life'' (1955), ``The Informed Heart'' (1960), and ``The Children of the Dream'' (1969). Bettelheim's wife, Gertrud Weinfeld, died in 1984. He is survived by three children. Funeral arrangements were not immediately known.

DOC.HEAD: Controversy Continues over Claim to be Billy the Kid
DOC.TEXT: A retired historian-author who has been trying to prove that a Texan who died in 1950 was really Billy the Kid said he'd like to see the identity decided by a federal court. William A. Tunstill said a recent photographic study comparing a tintype of Billy the Kid and pictures of Ollie L. ``Brushy Bill'' Roberts failed to put the isue to rest. The study, part of a broader study undertaken by the Lincoln County Historical Trust, concluded 41 other people in the comparison looked more like Billy the Kid than ``Brushy Bill'' did. Roberts, who died in Hico, Texas, a week shy of his 90th birthday in December 1950, had claimed to be the legendary New Mexico outlaw. Most people, including a coroner's jury of the time, say Sheriff Pat Garrett shot Billy the Kid to death in Fort Sumner, N.M., on July 14, 1881. ``Brushy Bill died a Christian, but I'm not sure of those who accuse him (of lying),'' Tunstill said.

DOC.HEAD: Clash With Cuba Over U.S. Broadcasts Looms
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The next big clash between Cuba and the United States is just over the horizon, literally. It takes the form of a U.S. balloon floating above the Florida Keys designed to beam ``capitalist'' programming to Cuba. After years of preparations, testing of the Voice of America broadcast operation will begin shortly, and Cuban officials are guaranteeing an energetic response to what they regard as a blatant intrusion on national sovereignty. They want no part of U.S. news shows, sitcoms and soap operas. They are not convinced by U.S. arguments that the station, known as TV Marti, will not be a propaganda mouthpiece for rightist militants. ``Tele-aggression'' is just one of the epithets that Communist President Fidel Castro uses in denouncing the U.S. plan. Speaking to a gathering of 50,000 students Tuesday night, Castro said the Bush administration officials are ``not even capable of appreciating how much they offend the heart and the sentiments of our people.'' Castro said that despite setbacks in Eastern Europe and elsehwere in the socialist world, the Cuban Revolution will survive because it is based on just ideas. ``The ideals of our country are immortal,'' he said. Castro was flying today to Brazil for the presidential inauguration in that country. Ramon Sanchez Parodi, a vice foreign minister, says Cuba is considering a range of retaliatory measures for TV Marti, including curtailing travel and telephone communications between Cuba and the United States. Another possibility is that Cuba, with the use of high-powered trnasmitters, will interfere with U.S. radio broadcasts over a huge area west of the Mississippi. At a minimum, Cuba will take steps to ensure that TV Marti will not reach Cuban living rooms. ``We have absolutely no doubt we can block the signal,'' says Gary Gonzalez, a vice president of the Cuban Institute of Radio and Television. The planned jamming comes months after the Soviet Union and its former East European satellites, embracing democratic reform, stopped jamming Western radio broadcasts. Technical problems have led to repeated delays in initiating the testing phase of TV Marti. The latest target date is sometime this month. The station is seen as a televised version of Radio Marti, a VOA project named for 19th century Cuban revolutionary Jose Marti that beams news and entertainment designed for Cuban audiences. The signal for TV Marti is to be sent from a tethered balloon about 10,000 feet above the Florida Keys. A lofty perch is required to ensure the signal is not blocked by the curvature of the Earth. Part of the rationale for the TV and radio projects is that the Cuban people, U.S. officials say, have been systematically denied access to balanced information in the government-controlled media. Says Rep. John Miller, R-Wash., ``We are in a struggle of ideas, which is better than military struggle. Castro has never offered not to spread his ideas throughout Latin America.'' Some Cubans see TV Marti as a potentially bright addition to the drab fare often transmitted on their stations. But Gonzalez said the portrayal of Cuba as a country closed to outside influence is misleading. He says 42 percent of all movies shown on Cuban television are American-made. There are also a number of U.S.-made programs for American children shown in Cuba, he says. The legislation that created TV Marti permits a 90-day period after the initial testing to evaluate legal and technical considerations before actual programming can begin. But Sanchez Parodi says the Cuban response will be delivered immediately after testing begins. ``We will do more than just block the signal,'' he says. Cuban officials argue the proposed station violates U.N. agreements that protect local broadcasting systems from outside interference. They also see TV Marti as yet another element in a continuing U.S. campaign to undermine Castro's three-decade-old rule. But the Bush administration may be forced to scuttle the project because of technical problems. Some U.S. officials say there is not much the administration can do if Cuba succeeds in blocking the transmission. Beyond that, there also is concern that the project may interfere with broadcasting by south Florida stations. Under the legislation, if that problem cannot be resolved, TV Marti must be turned off.

DOC.HEAD: Urban Indian Hearse Project Helps Take Native Americans `Home'
DOC.TEXT: Indians unable to afford hearses no longer have to use pickup trucks to ferry their dead to reservations for burial. They can now turn to the Urban Indian Hearse Project, which has taken 217 people ``home'' free of charge since the non-profit organization made its first run in October 1987. The project evolved out of a small group of people who used to take the dead from the Twin Cities to reservations in personal vehicles as a kindness, said John Stone, who coordinates the effort from Indian Family Services in south Minneapolis. ``They would take them back in the back of a pickup truck or station wagon or whatever that they could, partly because the cost that a funeral home charges to transport a body from the urban area,'' Stone said. For example, the transportatio cost from a Twin Cities funeral home to the Red Lake Indian reservation in northern Minnesota, a 539-mile round trip, is around $900, Stone said. Some of the metropolitan area's 18,000 American Indians had no choice but to inter their dead in local and unfamiliar cemeteries. Without transportation, they couldn't use free plots among their relatives on tribal burial grounds, said Stone, who lives in Bloomington and grew up on the White Earth reservation in northwestern Minnesota. That changed with the donation of two used hearses by the Minnesota Chippewa tribe and the formation of the hearse project. ``It's meant that they've been able to have the type of funeral important to the Indian heritage,'' said David Karsnia, owner of the David-Donehower Funeral Home in Detroit Lakes, which serves White Earth. Charles Stately of Minneapolis is among those who have donated to the hearse project. He remembers what it did for his family when his mother, Elaine M. Stately, died in August 1988. ``It was a hard time, and my mother was a long way from where she was born and wanted to be. It was real nice to deal with Indians,'' Stately said. ``All the things that happened were hard to handle except that part of it. That went smoothly.'' With the hearse project's help, Stately was able to fulfill his mother's wish to be buried on the White Earth reservation, where she was born. ``It's where her family has their roots. She identified with the land,'' he said. The Rev. James Notebaart with the Office of Indian Ministry for the Archdiocese of St. Paul and Minneapolis sees the project in spiritual terms. ``It's not a business and it's not an attempt to be `cheap,' but it's part of their whole sense of unity and communion in life and death,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dental Needles, Drills Likely to Be Obsolete in Next Decade
DOC.TEXT: What if you don't want to open your mouth wide, have a needle plunged into your gums and feel a drill grinding the most tender of your teeth? Just be patient and look forward to that as-yet-unscheduled dental appointment in the year 2000. That's when dental experts believe the drill will be obsolete and the needle replaced with an electronic anesthesia machine. The technology will be demonstrated to 17,000 dental professionals attending the 78th annual Thomas P. Hinman Dental Meeting Friday through Monday in Atlanta. Among research to be presented is the development of a laser that experts predict will make the dental drill obsolete by the end of this decade. ``The 1990s are going to be incredible for dentistry,'' said Dr. Tom Truhe, director of the Princeton Dental Resource Center in Princeton, N.J. Forty percent of U.S. adults do not have regular dental checkups. Studies blame this failure on many people's belief that they do not need checkups, as well as on the fear of needles and drills. ``We're working on reasons two and three,'' Truhe said, adding that a time lapse of eight to 10 years exists between the time new techniques are developed and the time they are used in dental offices. The laser, being studied at the University of Detroit, vaporizes tooth decay without the noise, vibration or smell often associated with dental drills. Truhe said lasers also decrease the chances of tooth decay returning around fillings. But while lasers can penetrate dentin _ the second level of tooth covering _ they have not been able yet to pass through the hardest and outermost tooth layer, enamel. Also, Truhe said, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration so far has approved lasers only for use on soft tissues. Still, there is little doubt, Truhe said, that lasers will be the standard of care for repairing dental cavities by the year 2000. Also, electronic anesthesia machines have been developed to deaden pain through battery power. The FDA-approved machines already are in use in some dentists' offices and are still being researched at the University of Colorado. The machines employ electrical impulses that travel through battery wires to small adhesive pads attached to the patient's mouth. Truhe explained that the impulses deaden pain by flooding nerves with non-painful stimuli so that painful stimuli cannot pass through. The impulses also increase the brain's production of pain-lessening chemicals such as serotonin and endorphins.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``In the words of that world-famous philosopher Jackie Gleason, `How sweet it is,''' _ Millionaire oilman-rancher Clayton Williams, upon winning the Republican nomination for governor of Texas.

``We are standing before the greatest, most meaningful step in the history of our government.'' _ Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, speaking before winning his battle to establish the strong presidency he called vital to holding the country together.

``I felt I had played an important role in the administration. I had to stand up for reputable astrologers.'' _ Joan Quigley, the astrologer whose advice to first lady Nancy Reagan reportedly set the president's schedule, explaining why she wrote her autobiography in which she is critical of the Reagans.

DOC.HEAD: Negotiators Reported Progress Toward Possible U.N. Role
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. Security Council's five permanent members have proposed an ambitious administrative role for the United Nations in Cambodia, diplomats said today, reporting progress toward ending the country's civil war. A communique released after two days of talks in Paris appealed to Cambodia's warring factions to ``delegate all necessary powers'' to the U.N. during a transitional period in which free elections would be organized. Under the proposal, the four Cambodian factions would jointly form a Supreme National Council that would occupy the country's seat in the United Nations but cede day-to-day administrative responsibility to the U.N. U.S. diplomats said at a briefing today that the five permanent Security Council members _ the United States, Soviet Union, Britain, France and China _ had made ``significant progress'' toward agreement on details of the proposal. They said a unified approach by the U.N. would be needed to persuade the Cambodian factions to compromise after more than 11 years of civil war. Factions involved are the government of Premier Hun Sen, installed by Vietnam, and the resistance coalition of three parties _ the Khmer Rouge, a Communist group that is the strongest guerrilla organization, and non-Communist insurgent forces led by Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's former ruler, and Son Sann, a former premier. The proposal by the five Security Council members would require the Hun Sen government to yield sovereignty, although a U.S. diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity, said government employees might be allowed to remain in their posts under U.N. supervision. Details of the possible size and cost of the U.N. contingent have not been made final. An American official said there was no precedent for a U.N. force administering an entire country in addition to arranging elections. One obstacle during previous talks among the Cambodian factions was the opposition of Khieu Samphan, a Khmer Rouge leader and vice president of the guerrilla coalition, to using the word ``genocide'' to describe Khmer Rouge actions in Cambodia in 1975-78. The Khmer Rouge government led by Pol Pot killed hundreds of thousands of Cambodia's 8 million people while trying to turn the country into an agrarian commune. A Vietnamese invasion in December 1978 overthrew the Pol Pot regime. A U.S. official said the dispute over the genocide issue had been used in the past to obstruct negotiations and expressed hope that it could be set aside temporarily. ``We believe those responsible for genocidal violence presently have little electoral support,'' he said. All factions have indicated previously they would accept some U.N. role, including election supervision, but there is disagreement over how Cambodia should be governed until the elections are held. Hun Sen and his Vietnamese backers have contended that dismantling the government might open the way for the Khmer Rouge to seize power again. Attending the Paris talks were Richard Solomon, U.S. undersecretary of state; David Gillmore, undersecretary in the British Foreign Office; Claude Martin, France's director of Asian affairs; Igor Rogachev of the Soviet Union Xu Dunxin of China, vice ministers of foreign affairs; and Rafeeuden Ahmed, a U.N. assistant secretary-general. The parties plan to meet again in Paris in May, and have asked the U.N. to provide detailed logistical information for use in future discussions. On the agenda in May, according to diplomats, will be the current Cambodian military situation, the prospects for some sort of peacekeeping force, and the issue of whether Vietnamese troops have resumed military support of Hun Sen despite assurances of a September withdrawal.

DOC.HEAD: Tokyo Stocks At Lowest Level in a Year, Dollar Down
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's chief index closed at its lowest level in a year today, while the dollar declined against the yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 268.44 points, or 0.82 percent, ending the day at 32,352.13, its lowest level since March 28, 1989, when it closed at 32,306.36. Dealers attributed the index's losses to intermittent selling by arbitrageurs _ mainly foreign securities firms _ throughout the day. After a series of rises and falls, the index ended the morning session with a 8.94-point gain when index-linked buying won over artibrage selling, traders said. But it soon fell back due to selling by pessimistic institutional investors in addition to arbitrageurs, said Yasumasa Shinagawa, a Yamaichi Securities dealer. ``Investors have little interest in buying issues because economic factors around the market remain the same'' without any positive incentives, he said. ``Participants are now trying to push down the index until the market hits bottom,'' Shinagawa said. He said traders expect the bottom will lie somewhere below 31,000 points. Dealers said institutional investors were inclined to sell ahead of the fiscal year-end account settlements for company budgets earmarked for investments in financial markets. Account settlement for fiscal 1989 for most Japanese institutional investors is slated for Thursday. ``There are only a limited number of issues that participants find safe to invest in, because they think company performances have been poor due to the stock exchange's plunge this year,'' said a dealer with Nomura Securities, speaking on condition of anonymity. Analysts have blamed computer-aided large-scale arbitrage trading, in which participants profit from price gaps between the spot and futures markets, for recent sharp declines in the Nikkei index, especially when overall volume is low. Today's volume on the market's first section was estimated at 480 million shares, up slightly from Tuesday's 400 million. The Nikkei index on Tuesday registered its fourth-largest decline this year, dropping 747.66 points, or 2.24 percent, because of a wave of arbitrage selling, dealers said. Following a combined decline of 1,372.55 points on Monday and Tuesday, the Nikkei index has lost more than 6,500 points, or 16.9 percent, since the beginning of this year. In currency dealings, the dollar ended trading at 152.20 yen, down 0.47 yen from Tuesday's closing of 152.67 yen. It opened lower at 151.90 yen and ranged between 151.70 yen and 152.47 yen. The dollar weakened today mainly because of technical adjustments and profit-taking, said Kenzo Shinomiya, a trader with Fuji Bank. ``The dollar's slip is a temporary phenomenon because market players have long (over-bought) dollar positions as a result of so much dollar-buying around 152 yen,'' he said. The U.S. currency's fall today does not indicate a trend because market demand for the dollar remains strong, he said. Other traders said Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno's scheduled return to Tokyo from Europe on Thursday also was putting pressure on the dollar, since the market expects the central bank to raise its official discount rate shortly after he returns. Market players expect the bank to raise the discount rate by as much as 1 percentage point from the current 4.25 percent. ``Since it has been expected for more than a month, a discount rate hike is likely to have little impact because the figure is already factored into the market,'' Shinomiya said. Benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bonds closed at 86.19 points, up 0.13 from Tuesday's closing of 86.06. Their yield fell to 7.305 percent from the previous day's 7.325 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Pregnant Women Win Cash in Healthy Baby Lottery
DOC.TEXT: A hospital has given out the first $100 prizes to women who seek early prenatal care in a so-called Healthy Baby Lottery. It wasn't a huge jackpot, but it was fun for Hope Allen, one of the six expectant mothers who picked up their winnings Tuesday outside Memorial Hospital. ``It'll come in handy, but it's just the thrill of winning it,'' she said. Doctors and nurses hope to generate publicity with the winners to entice other pregnant women into making early visits to the hospital. ``What we're trying to do is get a message out to a group of women who normally do not listen to health care messages,'' said Dr. Larry Culpepper of Memorial Hospital's department of family medicine. Six monthly prizes from $25 to $100 will be awarded to women who have sought prenatal care before their 12th week of pregnancy. Those who seek care before the 10th week got a $50 bonus. Every six months a $500 drawing will be held for women who complete their doctor's recommended prenatal care. Deborah Piche, 26, another lottery winner, had no insurance or job but went to the doctor after reading about the lottery, and won $50 plus the $50 bonus for seeking care at her seventh week of pregnancy. Mrs. Piche, 26, who is having her first child, said she would have gone to a doctor ``eventually, but I don't think I would have gone as soon.'' Sixty-six women got prenatal checkups in February, an average number, Culpepper said. But about 55 percent of the women enrolled before their 12th week, and less than 30 percent do so normally, he said. About 6 percent of the babies born to the 1,500 women who deliver at Memorial each year are below normal birthweight. They run up an average bill of $23,000, Culpepper said. ``So, if we prevent one low birthweight baby, or one handicapped child, which I think it is likely to do, then I think it's worth it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Bar Demonstrators from National Assembly
DOC.TEXT: About 2,000 riot police carrying shields and clubs formed a human wall near the National Assembly today to block a march by demonstrators demanding the retirement of elderly lawmakers. ``It is absurd that we let these senile and selfish assemblymen run the nation's electoral body,'' shouted Hung Chi-chang, an assemblyman from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party. The 752-seat National Assembly is Taiwan's electoral college and will elect the island's next president on March 21. Like the other branches of Taiwan's tricameral Parliament, the assembly is dominated by elderly Nationalist Party stalwarts who have not faced voters since the government fled to Taiwan in 1949 after losing the Chinese civil war. They have been frozen in office to support a Nationalist claim to be China's legitimate government. The 300 demonstrators chanted slogans demanding the resignation of the aged lawmakers and the dissolution of the National Assembly before their march was halted near the assembly grounds by police behind a barbed wire barricade. They then staged a three-hour sit-in near the barricades. The demonstrators, led by Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Huang Hsin-chieh, also were angered by an assembly decision Tuesday that barred all the party's 11 assemblymen from taking their seats because they had refused to take an oath to the ``Republic of China,'' the name under which the Nationalists founded their nation in 1911. The demonstrators claimed the opposition delegates were barred so the assembly could ram through changes to the country's constitution, including an amendment that would require approval from the elderly assemblymen to any bills dictating their retirement. Reporters estimated more than 2,000 policemen guarded the grounds of the National Assembly in the picturesque mountain resort of Yangmingshan in Taipei's suburbs. During the sit-in, an assembly committee passed a controversial proposal for the National Assembly to meet annually, rather than once every six years, to review bills adopted by the lawmaking Legislative Yuan. The proposal was rejected earlier by the Nationalist Party's decision-making central standing committee because of public pressure. The National Assembly is to vote on the proposal later this month. Four independent assemblymen, angered at the committee's action, toppled the podium in the committee room and ripped out microphones before leaving the meeting in protest. ``This is a big joke, a historical blemish of this party,'' said Sun Jung-chi, a Nationalist Party assemblyman who was elected in Taiwan. Many analysts believe the annual meetings will expand the powers of the National Assembly and hinder future democratic reforms. President Lee Teng-hui, 67, and his running mate, presidential adviser Li Yuan-zu, 66, are expected to be elected to a six-year term by the National Assembly despite some opposition, even from members of the Nationalist Party. Lee became the first native Taiwanese to head the Nationalist government in 1988 when he was elevated from the vice presidency following the death of President Chiang Ching-kuo.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against most major foreign currencies in moderate European trading today. Dealers said the currency appears to be losing some of its recent bullish momentum. Gold prices rose. ``The dollar doesn't have the momentum to go much further just now,'' said Andrew Ellott, a senior foreign exchange sales manager at Chase Manhattan Bank in London. Kenji Kawahara, foreign exchange manager at Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank in London, attributed the bearish view to a decline in U.S. equity and Treasury bond prices late Tuesday. Dealers said Sunday's East German elections could set a new direction for the foreign exchange markets. ``The uncertainty about the elections and the whole political situation is a factor that people don't dare to do anything,'' said a trader at a U.S. bank in Frankfurt. ``To trade the dollar higher is also dangerous because the central banks could come in, even though they haven't done much recently.'' In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 0.47 yen to a closing 152.20 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 152.10 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: _1.7127 West German marks, down from 1.7165 _1.5232 Swiss francs, down from 1.5275 _5.7880 French francs, down from 5.7915 _1.9265 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9312 _1,264.25 Italian lire, down from 1,267 _1.1725 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1775 In London, the dollar fell against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.6077, compared with $1.6005 late Tuesday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $398 a troy ounce, up from $396.55 bid late Tuesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $398.80. In Zurich, the bid price was $399, up from $396 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 27 cents to close at a bid $399.35. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $5.08 a troy ounce from Tuesday's $5.05.

DOC.HEAD: East Has a Heat Wave; Plains Hit by Twisters
DOC.TEXT: The record-breaking heat in the East and Midwest was joined by some summer-like humidity today, while Plains states recovered from the tornadoes that cut through them. The funnel clouds plowed through Kansas, Nebraska, Iowa, Oklahoma and Texas on Tuesday, killing two people, injuring at least 22 and wrecking scores of houses. A severe thunderstorm watch was posted today for much of eastern Iowa, parts of southern Wisconsin, and a small part of northwest Illinois. Tornadoes touched down during the afternoon east of Bloomfield, Iowa, as well as east of Bettendorf, Iowa; near Castleton, Kan., south of Hutchinson, Kan., near Lindsay, Okla., north of Shelton, Neb., at Smith Center, Kan., at Wood River, Neb., near Cedar Rapids, Iowa, at Port Byron, Ill., at Dribble, Okla., at Criner, Okla., at Le Claire, Ill., near Red Cloud, Neb., north of Haven, Kan., and west of Monticello, Iowa. Thunderstorm winds gusted to about 60 mph near Freedom, Fort Supply Lake and Woodward in Oklahoma, and at Russell, Lyons and Turon in Kansas. Showers and thunderstorms continued into the evening across southwest lower Michigan, northern Illinois, central and southern Wisconsin, Minnesota, eastern South Dakota, central and eastern Kansas, Iowa, western Missouri, western Arkansas, Oklahoma, and through eastern Texas. Rain extended along the northern Pacific Coast. Snow was falling over the southwest third of Montana, eastern Idaho, north-central Arizona, the Nebraska Panhandle and northeast Colorado. Record high temperatures for the date were broken in numerous cities. Among them: Akron, Ohio 75; Allentown, Pa. 83; Alpena, Mich 63; Atlantic City, N.J. 86; Augusta, Ga., 87; Baltimore 85; Bridgeport, Conn., 84; Charlotte, N.C., 86; Cleveland, 76; Grand Rapids, Mich., 75; Lynchburg, Va., 86; New York 85; Philadelphia 84; and Wilmington, Del., 85. Today's forecast called for rain in parts of the Pacific Northwest, as well as the north-central states and parts of New England. Thunderstorms are predicted along a low front from Texas to the Great Lakes region. Snow flurries are expected in parts of Colorado, Nebraska and the Dakotas. The nation's high Tuesday was 93 degrees at the Marine base near Cherry Point, N.C. DOC.HEAD: Plane Makes Emergency Landing After Engine Catches Fire
DOC.TEXT: A Continental Airlines DC-10 made an emergency landing after one of its engines caught fire, a passenger said. There were no injuries. Flight 969, carrying 155 passengers on a flight from Guam to Australia, returned to Guam about 20 minutes after its 5:25 a.m. takeoff Tuesday, said Guy Schroeder, regional director for Continental. Bernie Klupfel, a passenger aboard the plane, said he noticed a fire in one of the plane's engines. Passengers aboard the flight were put up in hotels on Guam and Saipan, the capital of the Northern Marianas Islands, said Schroeder.

DOC.HEAD: Pipeline Blast Kills Two in New York
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 graf to UPDATE with fire out, CORRECT number of injured to four sted two, add detail on other two injuries. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `The pipeline...'.
DOC.TEXT: A second man died of burns today after a ruptured propane pipeline exploded and destroyed 10 homes in a cauldron of fire. At least four people were injured in the blast Tuesday about 40 miles south of Albany. The fire burned itself out at about 5 a.m. today and a cap was placed on the hole in the pipeline, according to Schoharie County sheriff's officials. ``Right where we're standing was just a big ball of flames,'' said Schoharie Fire Department Lt. Joe Balfe. ``You couldn't get close to anything because you weren't sure what was going to blow up next.'' The 8-inch underground pipeline exploded twice as the valley community about 40 miles from Albany awakened shortly before 8 a.m., officials said. The blast knocked out electricity and phones up to 15 miles away. Sheriff's officials said investigators would begin examining the damaged pipe later in the day in an effort to find out what caused the blast. Residents said that a fog-like vapor had rolled down a hill toward their homes just before the explosion. Ten homes were reduced to blackened debris. ``They didn't burn long, the heat was so intense,'' said Shirley Hilgers, whose convenience store escaped damage. ``They were down in 10, 15 minutes.'' Richard Smith, 43, of Central Bridge, died Tuesday. Early today, Robert Hitchcock, 53, of North Blenheim died at Westchester County Medical Center. Hitchcock's 16-year-old daughter, Roberta, was in fair condition at Ellis Hospital in Schenectady with burns on her face and hands, and Michael Kodra, 58, of Howes Caves, was treated for burns and released, officials said. Two others, Linda Huber, 31, of North Blenheim, and her 4-year-old son, Shawn, were treated for smoke inhalation and released from Community Hospital of Schoharie County in Cobleskill. The pipeline, owned by Texas Eastern Products Pipeline, is part of a system that begins in Mont Belvieu, Texas, and winds its way 4,100 miles to Selkirk, about 10 miles from Albany, said company spokesman John Barnett. More than 300 firefighters, ambulance workers and law enforcement officials descended on Blenheim and worked nearly three hours putting out fires. The propane, which is heavier than air, apparently seeped about a mile along a creek bed into a small valley where the houses were located. Virginia Noxon said she was in her kitchen when the propane washed over her house. ``I looked out my kitchen door and I saw all this white stuff building up and I said, `I've never seen fog like this before,''' she said. ``I turned around and everything blew. It got all pink and everything and at first I thought it was a tornado. Then I heard Bang! Bang! Bang! Everything blowing up.'' The force of the explosions blew her across the room, but she was not injured. ``When it first happened, we thought an airplane had crashed into the side of the hill,'' said Liz Mace. ``I was just getting ready for work and there was this horrendous explosion. It sounded like a jet when they pass the sound barrier.''

DOC.HEAD: Congress Likes Bush's Nicaragua Aid Request, But Hurdles Await
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new grafs 5-6, bgng, ``The important ... to UPDATE with Hamilton, Lugar support
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers of both parties are lining up behind President Bush's request for a quick infusion of $300 million for Nicaragua, but problems are arising that could slow the package's progress through Congress. Bush asked Congress on Tuesday to provide the money by April 5 to help incoming President Violeta Chamorro rebuild the Central American country's war-weakened economy. He added another request: that lawmakers approve a stalled $500 million in aid for Panama, which the president proposed after the United States overthrew Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. The $800 million in immediate aid for Nicaragua and Panama would be diverted from the current military budget, perhaps the first real ``peace dividend'' from the receding Cold War. ``The important thing to keep in mind is that we have an opportunity that is just unparalleled,'' Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., a senior member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said today. ``This is a tremendous opportunity to shift the global balance of power in a direction favorable to us,'' he said on ``CBS This Morning.'' Appearing with Hamilton, Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., former chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said, ``I approve of the president's plan to assist Panama and Nicaragua ... we have great opportunities to assist in building new democracies.'' Speaking at a news conference, Bush announced the lifting of the 5-year-old trade embargo against Nicaragua, which the United States had used in its efforts to dislodge the leftist Sandinista government of President Daniel Ortega. And he said he would seek an additional $200 million for Nicaragua next year. ``These nations need our help to heal deep wounds inflicted by years of strife and oppression, years of loss and deprivation,'' Bush said. ``And we must act and act soon.''' On Capitol Hill, words of support for Bush's request soon followed. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said lawmakers would need more details about where the money would come from and how it would be spent, but said, ``We want to work with them and do it as soon as possible.'' ``The people of Nicaragua and Panama have courageously opted for freedom and democracy,'' said Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. ``We can't let them down now.'' ``We express our support for both'' the aid package and the end of sanctions, the Nicaraguan embassy said in a statement. It invited U.S. experts to inspect Nicaragua's economic situation at first hand. Complications arose as well, however. Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, said he would withhold action on Bush's request for aid for the Central American countries until the administration proposes specific savings to pay for it. In a letter to Secretary of State James A. Baker III, Byrd referred to a conflict between himself and the president that has been brewing since last month. In February, Bush proposed withholding $2.2 billion in defense spending planned for this year, much of it slated for arms projects that are popular in Congress. The administration wants to spend some of that money for different weapons and use other parts of it for the Central American aid. But the president's proposal angered Byrd and the appropriations panel's ranking Republican, Sen. Mark Hatfield of Oregon. They argued that Bush's plan to stop the spending was illegal, and called on him to reverse his decision. The dispute remains unresolved. ``We have no interest in delaying action on these important matters,'' Byrd wrote. The aid measure could also be slowed by unrelated amendments that lawmakers might attach to it. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., has signaled he will seek to append a $400 million housing credit program to help Israel resettle newly emigrated Soviet Jews. And others say there may be efforts to cut or restrict aid to El Salvador over congressional concerns about human rights in that country, or efforts to use the bill to boost aid to emerging Eastern European democracies.

DOC.HEAD: Williams Gets GOP Nod for Texas Governor; Democrats Face Runoff
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3-4th grafs, `With 94...', with 2 grafs to UPDATE vote totals. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `Because no...'. SUBS 12th graf, Ms. Richards' rivals...', with 1 graf to add that drug use question came up in context of candidate's alcoholism.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos AT1, AT2, MID2
DOC.TEXT: Millionaire oilman-rancher Clayton Williams got everything he hoped for _ the Republican nomination for governor and the prospect of a bruising Democratic runoff between Treasurer Ann Richards and Attorney General Jim Mattox. ``In the words of that world-famous philosopher Jackie Gleason, `How sweet it is,''' Williams told a hotel ballroom full of whooping supporters after humbling all comers in Tuesday's GOP primary with 61 percent of the vote. With 98 percent of precincts counted, the West Texas businessman got 511,007 votes. Railroad Commissioner Kent Hance, a former Democratic congressman, was a distant second with 129,662, votes, or 15 percent. Further back were lawyer Tom Luce with 113,542 votes, or 14 percent, and former Secretary of State Jack Rains, with 80,400 votes, or 10 percent. Ms. Richards and Mattox ran neck-and-neck in the brutal Democratic race, sinking the comeback hopes of former Gov. Mark White. With 98 percent of precincts reporting, Ms. Richards had 561,080 votes, 40 percent, to Mattox's 521,494, or 37 percent. White received 274,551 votes, or 19 percent. Because no Democrat got more than half the vote, the two top vote-getters will meet in a runoff for the nomination April 10. Before the polls opened, Williams said he hoped to avoid a runoff so he could relax and ``have some fun watching each of the Democrats murdering on each other.'' On Tuesday night, he added, ``This has been a spirited primary and at times things have gotten a little testy, although looking at the Democrats' mess makes us looks like a bunch of sissies.'' Ms. Richards told her campaign workers: ``Well, this is gonna be a good night, y'all. But do you have enough money for a runoff?'' Williams, who calls himself ``just a country boy'' and admits to occasional fistfights, spent $8 million _ $6 million from his own pocket _ in rolling to victory in his first run for office. The 58-year-old combined folksy humor, love of all things Texan and a multimillion-dollar TV campaign to rise from an asterisk in the early polls. Ms. Richards, known for her caustic keynote speech at the 1988 Democratic National Convention in which she said then-Vice President Bush was ``born with a silver foot in his mouth,'' easily topped opinion polls after entering the race last June in a bid to become the state's first woman governor since Miriam ``Ma'' Ferguson left office in 1935. But she stumbled after finding herself in a race characterized by mudslinging. Rivals lashed out at Ms. Richards, a recovering alcholic, for refusing to say whether she had ever used illegal drugs; she accused them of profiteering from public service. White and Mattox, for their part, called Ms. Richards a liar. In a preview of things to come, both Ms. Richards and Mattox were at one another's throats moments after White conceded Tuesday night. ``I hope Ann gets her consultants under control. She ran some pretty harsh ads against Mark and myself and I hope it stops because I intend to discuss the issues,'' Mattox said. Ms. Richards again challenged Mattox to follow her lead and make public his tax returns. ``It's going to be a very difficult 28 days,'' she warned. ``We're going to talk about who truly believes in ethics in public office.'' In the Republican race, no challenger could match Williams' bankroll. After initially pledging to spend $3 million from his own pocket, he wound up spending far more than that on a nearly flawless campaign that included television commercials that analysts called some of the best ever. ``The Democrats are in for the contest of their life in November,'' said Luce. ``He's a superb nominee for our party.'' Turnout was estimated at 2 million of the 8.3 million eligible voters, who could cast ballots for either party. The number voting was the highest in a Texas primary in an year not involving a presidential race. Absentee balloting was expected to account for up to 25 percent of the vote. It was the first gubernatorial race in Texas since the state allowed people to vote absentee without stating a reason. Texans also voted on the U.S. Senate seat held by Republican Phil Gramm, who has no GOP opponent in his bid for a second term. State Sen. Hugh Parmer, a 50-year-old Fort Worth lawyer, easily won the Democratic nomination by defeating Harley Schlanger, a follower of extremist Lyndon LaRouche. Jim Hightower, the state agriculture commissioner who raised controversy at every turn, pulled 65 percent of the vote to win the Democratic nomination for re-election against six opponents supported by the Texas Farm Bureau. Hightower bills himself a friend of the small, independent farmer, but brought the wrath of some ranchers with his support of hormone-free beef. Republicans last year failed in their bid to have the Legislature abolish his job. State Sen. Rick Perry will meet Richard McIver, owner of a geologic consulting firm, in a runoff for the GOP nomination.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil Bars Entry of Heavy Weapons By Castro's Bodyguards
DOC.TEXT: Brazilian authorities prevented Fidel Castro's bodyguards from bringing a cache of heavy weapons into the country to protect the Cuban leader during his visit this week, the Foreign Ministry said. Castro is to attend the inauguration on Thursday of President-elect Fernando Collor de Mello in Brasilia, the capital. On Friday, Castro travels to Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo. A plane, carrying the weapons and the Cuban mission, with 83 passengers and 15 crew, arrived Saturday and was detained for nine hours at the Brasilia airport before being sent back to Havana, said Deputy Foreign Minister Paulo Tarso Flecha de Lima. The people aboard were allowed to remain in Brazil. The Rio newspaper Jornal do Brasil reported Tuesday that the plane was carrying 10 tons of heavy weapons, including machine guns, grenades, rocket launchers and an antiaircraft cannon. Flecha de Lima did not confirm the plane's exact contents but said ``there were no portable arms.'' He attributed the incident to ``an excess of zeal'' on the part of Castro's bodyguards. ``It was not a diplomatic incident, but only an operational one,'' said Flecha de Lima. He said the weapons were returned to Havana and the Cuban leader's security agents would only be allowed to carry pistols and revolvers in Brazil. Details of Castro's visit have been kept secret. The only time the Cuban leader visited Brazil was in 1959, the year he took power after overthrowing dictator Fulgencio Batista. Brasilia broke diplomatic relations with Havana after Brazil's anti-Communist military coup in 1964. Relations between the nations thawed with the return of civilian rule in 1985 and were restored the following year. The Foreign Ministry announced that 121 countries will be represented at the inauguration of Collor de Mello, Brazil's first president elected by the people in 29 years. He was voted into office in November 1989. Castro is one of 27 heads of state and government who will attend the ceremony. The United States will be represented by Vice President Dan Quayle.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Sets Trial Date, Issues Sweeping Rules on Secret Information
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Classified information...', and 8th graf, `But Hoevelor...', grafs to CORRECT spelling of Hoeveler sted Hoevelor.
DOC.TEXT: A sweeping order in the drug-trafficking case against Manuel Noriega provides ground rules for thousands of documents defense attorneys say will prove U.S. officials approved of the deposed Panamanian dictator's actions. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler also tentatively scheduled the trial of Noriega and his co-defendants for Jan. 28, 1991, a date Noriega attorney Steven Kollin called ``realistic.'' The judge capped weeks of legal wrangling Tuesday when he issued the 12-page protective order defining how the Classified Information Procedures Act of 1980 will be applied in the Noriega case. ``On the whole, I'm pleased with it,'' Noriega attorney David Lewis, an expert on classified documents, said in a telephone interview from Washington. ``In terms of which side got more, I think we did very well.'' Diane Cossin, a spokeswoman for acting U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen, said ``We're pleased that they're pleased. We're not getting the whole pie here, but we're not unhappy.'' Classified information belonging to any federal agency that deals with national security, as well as information from Noriega's private dealings with more than 20 foreign governments, must first be reviewed by the Justice Department's court security officer before it can be introduced as evidence, Hoeveler said. Information in books, newspapers and other publications are similarly restricted if the published reports include confirmation by someone with access to classified information and if the Justice Department believes it could affect national security, Hoeveler ruled. But Hoeveler denied several key restrictions sought by the government, including a demand that defense attorneys immediately submit to prosecutors, as well as the neutral court security officer, any sensitive evidence they plan to introduce at trial. The judge also refused prosecutors' requests for a lifetime gag order that would have forced anyone given access to classified documents to get prior approval from intelligence agencies before speaking about that information. Prosecutors were ``seeking a protective order that was far more restrictive than anything ever seen before. Judge Hoeveler in all respects denied those problematic requests,'' Lewis said. The order also restricts the defense attorneys for Noriega and his co-defendants from sharing information without prior approval from the government. That stipulation, Lewis said, would have little impact because Noriega is the only defendant intending to use classified information at this point. Also Tuesday, Hoeveler released Daniel Miranda, a pilot accused in the Noriega indictment of flying drug profits to Panama, on $1 million bond. Miranda, 36, is the second of the six defendants taken into custody to be released on bond. Brian Alden Davidow, a Miami-area resident, turned himself in to federal authorities immediately after the February 1988 indictment was handed up, and has been free since then. Still jailed are Noriega aide Luis del Cid, who has been negotiating a plea bargain; accused Colombian cocaine trafficker William Saldarriaga; Eduardo Pardo; and Noriega. Ten other defendants are still at large. Noriega, who is accused of accepting bribes from Colombian cocaine traffickers and turning his country into a conduit for drugs smuggled into the United States, was flown from Panama on Jan. 4 following the U.S. invasion.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Jet Returns to London With Electrical Problem
DOC.TEXT: A Northwest Airlines jet bound for Boston was forced to return to Prestwick Airport in Scotland today after reporting an electrical problem and dumping fuel off the Scottish coast, the airline said. The DC-10, carrying 248 passengers and 11 crew members, landed safely, said airline spokeswoman Sue Majors. Northwest Flight 35 left Prestwick at 12:02 p.m. and was 15 minutes into the journey when the pilot reported ``an electrical fault'' and returned to the airport at 13:15 p.m., said an airport spokesman, speaking anonymously in keeping with British custom. ``We're in the middle of a full-scale emergency here,'' an airport spokesman said as the plane circled before landing. Ms. Majors said the airline will conduct an investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Carter to Discuss Hostages with Assad
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 11th graf pvs, `Carter who...' with 3 grafs to ADD that Carter on private trip to Middle East, leaves Syria on Friday. Pickup 12th, `We hope...'
DOC.TEXT: Former President Jimmy Carter arrived in Syria today and said he expected to discuss the plight of foreign hostages in Lebanon when he meets with President Hafez Assad. ``It's obvious to me that the Syrian leaders are very eager to see the hostage question solved and so see the hostages released,'' Carter told reporters on arrival at Damascus international airport. The former president, who arrived from Egypt, was due to meet Assad and other officials before continuing his tour with visits to Jordan and Israel. Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa, who greeted Carter, said he was ``not pessimistic'' about freeing hostages in Lebanon. ``As we did exert a lot of efforts in the past to gain the release of so many hostages ... we are still continuing to exert such intensive efforts,'' Sharaa said. Syria, with roughly 40,000 troops in Lebanon, is the main power broker in that war-ravaged country. But most of the hostages are believed to be held by groups influenced by Iran and often at odds with Syria. Recent statements by some Iranian leaders urging freedom for the hostages had raised hopes that a release might be imminent. But a hard-line Iranian figure, former Interior Minister Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, recently denounced calls for the hostages to be freed. ``Those statements are equivocal,'' Carter said, referring to comments by Iranian leaders. ``One day it's a positive statement. The next day it's a rejection of a positive statement. ``But I don't think there's any doubt that the leaders of Iran have a great influence on the future of the hostages,'' he added. Diplomats and Syrian officials in Damascus have said in recent days that there are few signs that a release is imminent. Eighteen foreigners, including eight Americans, were taken hostage in Lebanon. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, who will have been held five years on Friday. Carter, who is on a private tour of the Middle East, leaves Syria for Jordan on Friday. Since he left office in 1979, Carter has visited the Middle East four times, monitoring peace efforts. In talks in Atlanta and in Africa, he also has mediated conflicts between the Sudanese and Ethiopian governments and rebels waging war against them. Carter, who sponsored the 1978 Camp David talks that led to Israeli-Egyptian peace, said he also was using his current trip to the Middle East to explore prospects for a final end to Arab-Israeli hostilities. ``We hope for a comprehensive settlement of all the issues, including that between Syria and Israel, in the future,'' he said. Carter said a proposed dialogue between Israelis and Palestinians that has split the Israeli government ``would be a precedent-setting first step which we hope would lead to even broader agreements in the future.'' Israel's coalition government collapsed Tuesday in a dispute over what sort of Palestinians Israel should agree to talk with. Carter told reporters in Egypt he thought ``there is still a good chance for ... dialogue,'' especially if a government led by one faction _ rather than a deadlocked coalition of leftist Labor or hard-line Likud _ is formed. Carter also supported President Bush's opposition to settlement of Soviet Jews in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Sharaa expressed Arab concerns that the hundreds of thousands of Soviet Jews expected by Israel would displace Palestinians from their homeland and make the return of Palestinian refugees to their homes impossible. He opposed emigration even to Israel itself. ``The Soviet Jews can go anywhere in the world ... but not to Palestine, because the human rights of the Palestinian people, of the Arabs under occupation, should be given priority,'' he said. ``There are millions of Palestinians outside their country, there are thousands of Syrians outside of the Golan Heights, and there are thousands of Lebanese outside the south of Lebanon. ``And all these are deprived of the right to return to their homes and property'' by Israel, Sharaa added. Israel seized Syria's Golan Heights in the 1967 Middle East war and later annexed it. In 1985, Israel created a ``security zone'' in southern Lebanon to protect its northern borders from attacks by Arab guerrillas.

DOC.HEAD: Afghan Foreign Minister: Government Will Remove Arms Stockpiles
DOC.TEXT: Afghanistan will destroy its huge stockpiles of Soviet-supplied weapons if the United States and other countries stop supporting the Moslem rebels, the foreign minister said today. The minister, Abdul Wakil, said the rebels also should destroy their stockpiles. Previously, the administration had called only for a halt in military supplies to both the rebels and the Soviet-backed government in Afghanistan's 12-year-old civil war. The offer to destroy the stockpiles could eventually help pave the way for peace talks on Afghanistan. Wakil made the announcement one week after forces loyal to President Najib crushed a coup attempt led by then-Defense Minister Shah Nawaz Tanai. The Soviet news agency, Tass, reported today that 200 civilians died and 500 were wounded in the failed coup. The Kabul government has said 95 civilians died and 197 were wounded. No military casualties have been released. On Tuesday, a spokesman for the Kabul government reported the Moslem guerrillas attacked the strategic southern city of Khost and also were fighting government forces around eastern Jalalabad, another key city. Since the coup attempt, Soviet aid to Najib's government has increased. More than 30 transport planes, carrying 25 tons of weapons and medicine each, land daily at Kabul's airport, Eastern European diplomats said. In addition, the government said Tuesday that 4,200 tons of goods from the Soviet Union reached Kabul by land in the last three days. Wakil lashed out at Pakistan today, accusing the neighboring Moslem nation of ``masterminding'' the coup attempt. Pakistan, which allows the Afghan rebels to operate from its territory, has denied similar charges by Kabul officials in the past. In a statement apparently released Tuesday by Tanai in Pakistan, the former defense minister said he was planning to unite with the guerrillas to topple Najib, who was installed as president by the Soviets in 1986. Soviet troops invaded Afghanistan in December 1979, and pulled out under a U.N.-brokered agreement in 1989. Tanai, a hard-line Communist, is generally considered responsible for Afghanistan's successful defense of Jalalabad against the guerrilla attacks that followed the Soviet withdrawal in February 1989. Wakil's statement on Kabul's willingness to eliminate its stockpiles of arms would apparently remove a stumbling block in negotiations over ending the war in Afghanistan. During the Soviet occupation, the country amassed huge stockpiles of weapons, including thousands of trucks, tanks, armored personnel carriers, bombs, missiles and guns. Since the Red Army's withdrawal, Western analysts said Moscow's military assistance has been about $300 million a month, including an estimated 1,000 scud missiles. In negotiations last year, the United States rejected a Soviet proposal for each superpower to stop military aid to their allies in the civil war. The United States objected because the proposal would have allowed the Communist government in Kabul to keep existing stockpiles of weapons. Washington also opposed the plan because at that time U.S. analysts believed Kabul would fall quickly to the U.S.-backed rebels.

DOC.HEAD: Aspen Mayor, Two Councilmen Survive Recall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to recast lead to reflect that fur ban was not sole cause of recall, add winner of overturned seat, turnout and weather, CORRECT number of registered voters to about 3,700 sted 2,241. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A recall election narrowly retained the mayor who led an unsuccessful campaign to ban fur sales, but ousted one of his council supporters. Mayor Bill Stirling held onto his seat Tuesday with 1,227 voting to keep him in office and 1,097 favoring a recall. He interpreted the results as support of his efforts to limit a ``feeding frenzy'' of greedy developers. What people want, he said, is to ``slow down _ not halt _ but slow down speculative development and really get going with affordable housing.'' Typical single-family house prices in the fashionable resort, a favorite skiing spot for celebrities, surpass $1 million. Voters last month rejected Stirling's ballot proposal to ban the sale of furs in Aspen, as well as another measure to limit the size of a Ritz-Carlton hotel under construction. Those hoping to oust a majority of the five-member council accused the recall targets of being rude and unresponsive to constituents' concerns. Councilman Michael Gassman kept his seat with a 1,347 to 965 vote; Councilman Frank Peters was retained by a margin of just 30 votes _ 1,142 to 1,112. Residents recalled councilman Steve Crockett by a 1,288 to 1,025 margin in favor of Margot Pendleton, a concrete contractor. Crockett's critics considered him too confrontational. The turnout was more than 60 percent, despite heavy snow and good skiing conditions. ``I think that people reacted to the very negative approach that was taken by the pro-recall people in their campaign. And I think people got a little tired of it,'' Stirling said late Tuesday. Many voters told pollsters from the Aspen Times Daily they retained the incumbents because they disapproved of the recall campaign. ``It's just been unfair,'' said 23-year-old Aspen resident Ellen Marshall. ``All the council has done is carry out the mandate they were given when they were elected ... This whole thing is sad.'' Some longtime residents believe Aspen has lost its soul in becoming a playground for the rich and famous. But recall supporters said efforts to save Aspen by limiting growth have become exclusionary and nasty. Aspen's population is said to peak at about 20,000 in the winter; it has about 3,700 registered voters. Many property owners do not live here full time, and real estate prices have skyrocketed during the past decade. Aspen, home to eccentrics like ``gonzo'' journalist Hunter S. Thompson, was the first U.S. community to pass a tough anti-smoking ordinance and the first to declare itself a nuclear-free zone.

DOC.HEAD: Vatican Rebuilds and Revives Persecuted Church in Romania
DOC.TEXT: The Vatican today restored the leadership of the long-persecuted Roman Catholic Church in Romania and revived the Eastern rite branch that was suppressed there more than 40 years ago. Pope John Paul II appointed 12 bishops to restore the strength the church enjoyed before a crackdown on religion began in 1948. It marked the biggest step forward by the Vatican in Eastern Europe since the former hard-line regimes began to crumble last year. Vatican spokesman Joaquin Navarro said the church was ``overjoyed'' by the moves in Romania and hinted that a restoration of diplomatic relations with Bucharest, cut by the Communists in 1950, was not far off. Romanian clergy have also invited the pope to visit the country, but Navarro said no date has been fixed. The appointments were made possible by the actions of Romanian authorities in January suspending 1948 decrees that sharply curtailed the freedom of Roman Catholics and forcibly incorporated the Eastern or Byzantine rite Catholic church into the Orthodox Church. Their 1,800 churches were confiscated, and bishops and priests who refused to accept the merger were jailed, a situation similar to that in the Ukraine. In recent days, Vatican officials have been in the Soviet Union to negotiate with Soviet and Orthodox Church authorities on the revival of the Ukrainian Catholic church. But there has been no action taken yet on a law guaranteeing freedom of religion, which would legalize the Ukrainian Catholic church and was promised by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev when he met with the pope here in December. Two of the new Eastern rite bishops in Romania are in their late 70s, or past the normal Vatican retirement age. Navarro said the nominations were in recognition for their suffering for the church. Both had been imprisoned for years and one of them, Bishop Alexander Todea, 77, of Alba Julia, had been sentenced to death in 1951 and freed in a 1964 amnesty. All had practiced their religion underground in what the Vatican calls the ``catacomb'' church. The Vatican estimates there are 2.8 million Catholics from the two rites in Romania. The nominations restore the Roman and Eastern rite churches in Romania to their pre-1948 strength of six and five bishops respectively. Before today, only two Roman dioceses were headed by bishops. Navarro stressed the nominations were made independently by the pope with no interference by the Romanian government. Over the past year, the Vatican has re-established diplomatic relations with Poland and Hungary. Last month, the pope also finished restoring the church in Czechoslovakia to full strength for the first time since World War II, but that was carried out over a period of time and not on a single day as in Romania. The pope is scheduled to visit Czechoslovakia next month. While there is no immediate move for the Vatican and Bucharest to re-establish full relations, Navarro said the Romanian govbernment is returning the embassy building confiscated 40 years ago. Still to be resolved is the issue of religious orders, which were banned in Romania in 1948 and all their property seized.

DOC.HEAD: `America's Funniest Home Videos' Captures No. 1 Spot
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf to CORRECT that percentage decline put at 16 percent sted 20 percent.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Nielsen-List
DOC.TEXT: ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' an assemblage of often blurry scenes of things breaking and people falling, beat out slick network productions for the No. 1 spot in the ratings. The ABC show, which uses video clips sent in by viewers, had a 24.1 rating _ its highest ever _ and a 37 share of the audience for its 8 p.m. Sunday slot, according to A.C. Nielsen Co. ratings released Tuesday. But at 8:30 p.m. viewers turned the channel away from ABC's ``Elvis'' to catch a repeat episode of ``The Simpsons,'' Fox Network's cartoon series about an off-kilter family. It was 20th in the ratings for the week. It beat the first half-hour of a repeat of CBS' ``Murder She Wrote,'' in 29th place. ``Elvis,'' tied for 47th, and the competing half-hour of NBC's ``Magical World of Disney'' landed in 71st place. For the week ended March 11, NBC was first with an average of 13.5, ABC was second with 12.2 and CBS was third with 11.0. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. Here are the top 10 shows, their network and rating: ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC, 24.1; ``Cheers,'' NBC, 23.4; ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 22.1; ``The Cosby Show'' NBC, 21.3; ``A Different World,'' ABC, 20.7; ``60 Minutes,'' CBS, 19.6; ``The Wonder Years,'' ABC, 18.7; ``The Golden Girls,'' NBC, 18.1; ``In the Heat of the Night,'' NBC, 17.9; ``Who's the Boss,'' ABC, 17.5. ABC's ``World News Tonight'' led the news ratings for the ninth consecutive week. ``NBC Nightly News'' and the ``CBS Evening News'' tied for second place. ABC said the margin of victory for ``World News Tonight'' was the highest in the program's history. Of the three newscasts, only ABC's program, with anchorman Peter Jennings, increased its audience. For the week that ended March 9, it averaged an 11.5 rating, up 0.4 point from the previous week. NBC's newscast and CBS' broadcast, which has been slumping in the ratings, each averaged 9.7. Compared with ratings for the same week a year ago, last week's ratings showed a 16 percent drop for CBS' newscast, according to ABC estimates. The once-dominant ``CBS Evening News'' with Dan Rather was third in each of the three weeks preceding the latest Nielsen estimates.

DOC.HEAD: Separate Intra-Christian, Shiite Moslem Clashes Break Out in Beirut
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th graf, `Police said ...' to UPDATE casualties.
DOC.TEXT: Shiite Moslem militia allies of Syria and Iran fought each other in the streets of south Beirut today a few blocks away from where most of the Western hostages are believed held captive. Police today also reported intermittent gunfire between rival Christian militias in east Beirut. Clashes broke out early in the day between the pro-Iranian Hezbollah and the Syrian-backed Amal militia in the slums of south Beirut, said a police spokesman, who cannot be named in line with regulations. Police said three people were killed and 10 wounded before Syrian soldiers intervened and disengaged the combatants around 1 p.m. That brought the overall toll to seven killed and 34 wounded since the Amal-Hezbollah clashes broke out Tuesday evening. Fighters of the two warring Moslem factions fired automatic rifles and rocket-propelled grenades across the narrow streets separating their positions, the spokesman said. The fighting was reported in the Shiyah, Ouzai and Bir Hassan districts, a few blocks west of Hezbollah's Hajjaj and Hay Madi barracks, where most of the 18 Western hostages are believed held. Eight of the hostages are American. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was abducted March 16, 1985. Staccato bursts of machine-gun fire accompanied by grenade explosions echoed across Moslem west Beirut as bearded Amal and Hezbollah fighters traded fire. Motorists honked horns hysterically and sped away in all directions to escape the confrontations. Hundreds of worried parents, fearing the possible spread of fighting, rushed to schools to take their children home. Amal, in a communique, blamed the escalation on ``Mohtashemi's followers in the so-called Hezbollah.'' Amal claims Hezbollah's leader, Sheik Sobhi Tofeili, supports former Iranian Interior Minister Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, a hard-liner who was ousted as government minister by President Hashemi Rafsanjani in August. Mohtashemi opposes releasing the Western hostages and reaffirmed that line in a virulent editorial published in a radical Tehran newspaper Saturday. He also opposes Rafsanjani's moves to improve relations with the West. The Lebanese Shiite mufti, or supreme religious judge, Sheik Abdul Amir Qabalan, also blamed the intra-Shiite confrontation on Hezbollah. The police spokesman said Amal and Hezbollah fighters erected several checkpoints in their respective areas of influence and were checking identity cards and kidnapping each other's followers. The two militias have been battling for more than two years for mastery of the 1.2 million Shiites, who make up the largest community in Lebanon, which has a population of 4 million. By police count, more than 1,030 people were killed and 3,046 wounded in previous Amal-Hezbollah battles. In another violent development, police said one person was killed and two wounded in an intermittent exchange of sniper fire between rival Christian forces in east Beirut overnight. That raised the overall toll to 757 killed and 2,106 wounded in the intra-Christian fighting since Jan. 30, when clashes broke out between renegade Gen. Michel Aoun's troops and fighters of Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia. The two forces, fighting for dominance of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave, accused each other of blocking efforts by a Christian mediation committee to work out a settlement to their bloody dispute. The dispute has developed into the worst confrontation among Christians in the nation's 15-year-old civil war.

DOC.HEAD: Business Inventories Rise 0.2 Percent in January
DOC.TEXT: Business inventories edged up 0.2 percent in January, the government said today, but were offset by a 0.3 percent gain in business sales. The Commerce Department said inventories rose to a seasonally adjusted $795.9 billion after falling a revised 0.4 percent in December. The December drop, originally reported to be 0.2 percent, was the first since a 0.1 percent decline in October 1988 and the largest since a 0.6 percent fall in December 1986. Business sales, meanwhile, rose to a seasonally adjusted $523.0 billion after falling a revised 0.2 percent in December. December sales originally were reported to be unchanged from November. The January business activity produced a 1.52 ratio of inventories to sales, the same as in December. That means that it would take 1.52 months to exhaust inventories at the January pace. The ratio was 1.53 in both October and November. Inventories often rise during periods of slow economic growth as output exceeds demand. If they were to pile up excessively, it could mean cutbacks in production and a loss of jobs. However, economists do not feel the ratio is at a dangerous level. Retail backlogs fell 0.6 percent in January, while sales rose 2.8 percent. Part of the improvement in retail inventories came as automobile companies temporarily laid off thousands of workers during the month to trim the number of motor vehicles stuck on backlots. Auto inventories dropped 3.6 percent. Manufacturing inventories rose 0.7 percent, while sales dropped 1.9 percent. Wholesalers' inventories edged up 0.2 percent, while their sales gained 1.4 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Sudden Democracy Spawns Dirty Campaign, Overwhelmed Voters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 11th graf, `Campaign posters...' with 1 graf to UPDATE with politician resigning. Pickup `Social Democratic...'
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: For Michael Graf, the brief and seemingly anarchic East German election campaign is too much too soon. ``Nobody knows quite what to think,'' the burly 20-year-old toolmaker says over a beer in this cheerless, decaying industrial town. ``Everything happened a bit too quickly.'' Half a year after the first wave of protests started in Leipzig, many East Germans are bewildered by the need to choose among 24 slates of candidates in Sunday's election. Thousands of contenders are running for spots in the 400-seat Parliament. A recent West German poll said a quarter of the 12.3 million voters are undecided in this country of about 16 million people. New groups are facing formidable obstacles in campaigning. The renamed Communists try to blend into the democratic landscape, stressing their defense of East Germany's cradle-to-grave social safety net. Graf says he has trouble deciding what the parties stand for. ``We'll know what we have voted for only after the elections,'' Graf says. And with non-Communist parties getting massive aid from their West German counterparts, the choices for East German voters is not entirely home-grown. ``As far as I'm concerned, these parties are being directed from the other side,'' Graf says. The choices include the conservative Alliance for Germany, the left-of-center Social Democrats and even several radical leftist splinter groups. West Germany's extreme right, which had hoped to field candidates, was barred from the campaign. Opposition activists say the country was not ready for a Western-style campaign and worry openly that unity in opposing the Communists has turned to political polarization. Campaign posters of all parties are being torn down and papered over by rivals at an increasingly frantic pace as Sunday's vote nears. Vandalism against party offices has been reported in several places. A leading conservative politician, Wolfgang Schnur, resigned after admitting he was a secret police informer. Social Democratic party chairman Ibrahim Boehme is sleeping in a different bed every night on the advice of security experts, the West German news magazine Der Spiegel reported. But apart from some defaced posters, election fever seems muted in Eberswalde, about 37 miles northeast of Berlin with a population of 45,000. As elsewhere in East Germany, the lack of big commercial advertising spaces precludes campaign publicity on a Western scale. Local opposition activists say citizens are only slowly accepting that they should control who governs them, not vice versa. ``Our biggest problem is that people continue to think in old terms. They say: Just let those `up there' do the work,'' says Bernd Christmann of the new but increasingly important Social Democrats. ``It's sad but true. The Prussian mentality has survived _ that sense of duty and subservience to the pressure of authorities,'' adds Andreas Kriesten, a 36-year-old Protestant minister heading the local office of the Christian Democratic Union. The formerly Communist-aligned Christian Democrats are in a three-party conservative election alliance. Earlier euphoria about the promise of prosperity through unification with West Germany seems to be fading. Worries are rife about the future of the state-coddled economy and social services now that West German firms are storming to convert their eastern neighbor to capitalism. Several hundred citizens have come to seek information since the Social Democrats opened a shabby two-room office on Eberswalde's main thoroughfare six weeks ago. ``They ask about social security, their jobs, kindergarten, school lunches,'' Christmann says. Steffen Joswig, Graf's drinking buddy, says he shares those worries. At the same time, the 32-year-old waiter doesn't want to risk seeking a new life in West Germany with his wife and three children. ``I don't know who I'll vote for, but definitely not the PDS (Communists),'' he says. ``All my friends have gone over,'' Graf adds. ``But I'm waiting for the elections. I'm not winding up in a refugee camp in West Germany.'' Polls suggest that neither the Social Democrats nor the conservative alliance will gain a parliamentary majority, thus forcing a national unity government that probably would be another transitional solution. The campaign has been even shorter than originally planned. Opposition groups and the government agreed to move up the planned May 6 balloting when East Germany threatened to sink into political chaos in January. Despite the current uncertainties, campaign posters saying ``Socialism, never again'' bear witness to the fundamental change since hard-line Communist boss Erich Honecker was ousted Oct. 18.

DOC.HEAD: North Korea Proposes Joint Investigation of Border Tunnel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting a0538 to fix header.
DOC.TEXT: North Korea agreed today to participate in a joint investigation of what U.S. and South Korean engineers said was an ``invasion tunnel'' dug under the border separating the two nations. U.S. and South Korean officials said they were surprised by North Korea's apparent willingness to accept a proposal by the U.S.-led United Nations Command for an investigation. The last time the two nations jointly investigated a border incident was in 1967. At a meeting of the Korean Military Armistice Commission at this truce village, North Korean delegate Maj. Gen. Choi Ui Ung denied his nation dug the tunnel and agreed to ``promptly conduct a comprehensive and scientific joint investigation of the so-called tunnel which you allegedly have found.'' Choi said he would send a 60-member inspection team made up of experts and journalists to the tunnel site via helicopter. Adm. Larry G. Vogt, the senior U.S. delegate at the armistice meeting said the offer was ``an encouraging sign and we will consider it.'' But Choi declared a late reply would mean the rejection of his nation's acceptance of the joint investigation. The North Korean general demanded an immediate investigation, but Vogt said the proposal lacked the necessary details and procedures required under the 1953 Korean Armistice Agreement. United Nations Command officials said procedures do not allow either side to send a large delegation across the border by helicopter. They also noted that the North Korean proposal was unclear as to whether it would allow South Korea equal participation in the probe. One United Nations Command official said his organization would make a counter-proposal that ``fits the framework of the armistice agreement.'' The tunnel was discovered on March 3, in a remote mountainous area along the 155-mile border. It was the fourth tunnel found since 1974 and was about two yards high and two yards wide, large enough for three armed soldiers to run through abreast. South Korean officials said a regiment could pass through in an hour. It has not been clear when the tunnel was built. North Korea denied building tunnels beneath the border that were found in 1974, 1975 and 1978 and suggested they were old mining tunnels. Meanwhile in Seoul, 13 radicals protesting joint U.S.-South Korean military exercises were arrested by police after they pushed their way inside a gate at the headquarters of the U.S. 8th Army. There was no damage to the U.S. facility and no injuries, police said. North Korea has demanded cancelation of the exercises, now under way. In the central city of Taejon, police fired tear gas to break up a demonstration of about 300 students who were march to nearby Chungnam University, throwing firebombs and shouting ``Yankee go home!'' The Korean peninsula was divided in 1945 at the end of World War II. Capitalist South Korea and Communist North Korea fought a bloody three-year war in the early 1950s and remain bitter enemies.

DOC.HEAD: Tornado Rips Through Kansas; Two Dead
