DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with town cordoned off today, quote from administrator, missing people found. Picks up 11th graf, `Authorities said...'.
DOC.TEXT: Authorities cordoned off this town of 3,000 today, and called out the National Guard to help residents recover from a tornado that killed two people and injured 19. The tornado Tuesday night carved a 100-mile path through the flat countryside for 2{ hours, leaving about 100 ruined houses in its wake. ``I looked out our back door and I saw this thing coming,'' City Administrator Jay Weiland said. ``I thought `Oh, my God, there goes my town.''' National Guard troops arrived about midnight to help with the cleanup and prevent looting. Law enforcement officers were allowing only emergency personnel, residents and reporters into the area this morning. The National Weather Service warned today of more twisters in Texas and Oklahoma. More than two dozen funnel clouds touched down Tuesday across the Plains from Texas to Iowa, including more than a dozen in south-central Kansas. The dead in the Hesston area, just north of Wichita, were a 6-year-old boy and a 68-year-old woman. A missing woman and her teen-age son were found safe. The killer tornado touched down southwest of Hesston, cut a 1{-block-wide swath through the community, then moved along to the northeast, chewing up farmhouses in Marion and Morris counties. ``I saw at least four to five houses that had roofs torn off,'' said Kenneth Kaluhiokalani in Morris County. ``Belongings were scattered through the yards and glass was shattered in houses.'' From 75 to 100 houses were damaged in Hesston; 19 farmhouses were damaged in Marion County and at least five in Morris County. Six-year-old Lucas Fischer of Burrton, a few miles south of Hesston, was pronounced dead Tuesday evening at Halstead Hospital, said house supervisor Marian Krallman. His brother, 12-year-old Garrett, was in satisfactory condition with head injuries. Harvey County Sheriff's investigator Byron Motter said the boys were among seven people huddled in a basement to escape the storm when a chimney and fireplace collapsed. ``We were in the basement no more than a minute or two, then it crashed,'' said Paul Wedel, a neighbor who had sought refuge there. Ruth Voth, 68, died when the tornado swept into her home near Goessel, about 10 miles northeast of Hesston, authorities said. Authorities said 19 people were treated at area hospitals for storm-related injuries, and at least two were in critical condition. About 50 people made homeless spent the night at Hesston High School, said principal Marvin Estes. There was no electricity or gas in the town, and workers were making emergency repairs to the water system, said Jay Wieland, Hesston City administrator. Winds from the tornado blew off the roof of a Pizza Hut restaurant, and about 15 customers and employees huddled in a walk-in freezer and bathrooms. No one was injured. Residents of Hesston had a warning. One twister dissipated before reaching the town, and sirens sounded half an hour before the second funnel entered town at 5:30 p.m. Clarence Froese was taking care of his invalid son-in-law in Hesston when the tornado struck. ``We had just put him on a sheet and drug him into the basement when the storm hit,'' said Froese. ``I didn't know what happened until I got back out. It was devastation all over.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Assures Kollek Jerusalem to Stay United
With PM-Israel
DOC.TEXT: Jerusalem's mayor said today that President Bush has written to him promising that the United States supports a united Jerusalem. Jerusalem ``must never again be a divided city,'' Bush wrote in a March 13 letter to Mayor Teddy Kollek and distributed at a news conference here. Kollek also distributed the letter he wrote to Bush on March 8. Bush warned against ``steps that could prejudice the prospects'' for Arab-Israeli negotiations on Jerusalem's future, but wrote nothing about Jewish settlement in the Arab eastern sector of the city captured by Israel in the 1967 war. Last week, Bush made a statement apparently lumping east Jerusalem, which Israel regards as its sovereign territory, with the West Bank, which is under Israeli military occupation. Israel strongly objected, saying Jerusalem was a separate issue. Asked at a news conference at the Israeli Embassy whether he believed Bush's letter canceled the president's earlier statement, Kollek said: ``That is my strong impression.'' Bush's letter, however, merely expresses support for the U.S. policy since 1967, which has been in favor of a united Jerusalem. Bush wrote: ``It is also our view that the final status of this most special of cities should be decided by negotiation, and that this negotiation would be facilitated if we were well along the path toward peace. There is thus no intention on our part to focus now on the final status of Jerusalem.''

DOC.HEAD: West German Chancellor Reassures East Germans on Savings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 4th pvs, `The alliance...' to ADD that Kohl's promise regarding currency is no guarantee because that must be decided in future negotiations. Pickup 5th pvs, `Kohl's government...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-EGermany-Campaign, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl has assured nervous East Germans that their savings will be converted one-to-one into hard West German marks in a reunified Germany. East German citizens currently get only about 0.16 West German marks for their currency at a western bank, a 6-1 ratio reflecting the relative weakness of the East German economy. Kohl's promise Tuesday night during a campaign visit appeared timed to rally support for a conservative three-party alliance competing in East Germany's free elections Sunday. The alliance is heavily backed by Kohl's Christian Democratic Union in Bonn. It is facing a challenge from the revamped Communist Party, campaigning on the idea that East Germany's social safety net and full employment are endangered by a hasty takeover by West German capitalists. Kohl's promise is no guarantee because the currency plan would require formal approval by his coalition government and the assent of the West German central bank. In addition, details of the planned unification still have to be negotiated by the two Germanys. Kohl's government is pushing for merging the weak East German mark with its West German counterpart, one of the world's strongest currencies. Among the thorniest issues in the proposed monetary union, which would be a prerequisite for full unity, is how to treat East German savings. Many East Germans, like their counterparts in other Soviet bloc nations, have compiled large savings because there have been few consumer goods to buy. Kohl's assurance echoed similar statements by members of his government. In his speech in Cottbus, East Germany, he also reiterated a call for speedy movement toward unity under Article 23 of the West German Constitution. The clause allows individual East German states to decide to join West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Airliner Blows Tires In High-Speed Emergency Landing
DOC.TEXT: An Eastern Airlines DC-9 forced to make a high-speed emergency landing because of a hydraulic system failure blew all four main landing gear tires and slid off a runway in a shower of sparks. No injuries were reported in the landing at Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport. Airport spokesman John Braden said Eastern Flight 129 returned to the airport for the emergency landing about 10:50 p.m. Tuesday after taking off on a flight to Tallahassee, Fla. Because the jet landed ``well above normal speed,'' its four main tires _ two under each wing _ blew and the aircraft skidded off the runway in a shower of sparks, said Eastern spokesman Jim Ashlock. ``We probably wouldn't have had any situation at all if he hadn't blown those tires,'' he said. The landing was at a higher-than-normal speed because the hydraulic failure left the DC-9 without flaps, which are used to slow the plane during descent, Ashlock said. Braden said the sparks were caused by the landing gear scraping the runway, and there was no fire. Emergency crews and fire trucks lined the runway, but they did not lay down fire-suppressing foam before the landing. The airplane carried 49 passengers and five crew members, Ashlock said. ``The landing was kind of bumpy, and then it was eerie,'' said passenger Rusty Nunn of Hopkinsville, Ky. ``Of course, everyone was nervous, but they remained calm.'' Ashlock said the plane was 25 minutes into its 35-minute flight, but the pilot elected to return to Atlanta because of its longer runways and better emergency equipment. Braden said the Federal Aviation Administration and the National Transportation Safety Board would investigate.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Suggests U.S. Might Consider Loan to Help Argentina
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material, editing throughout with Quayle quotes.
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle suggested today the Bush administration might consider a loan to Argentina once the country concludes negotiations to meet economic progress conditions set by the International Monetary Fund. Quayle also said during a news conference that President Bush may visit Argentina next fall. ``There is a very serious consideration'' being given to such a visit, he said. The IMF appoved a $1.4 billion loan to Argentina last September but has held up disbursement of the money because President Carlos Menem did not meet targets on controlling inflation and reducing the budget deficit. ``I communicated to President Menem and others that the United States will be full partners in the development of Argentina and other countries in the Western Hemisphere,'' Quayle said. The vice president was asked about persistent rumors that the United States is considering a $400 million bridge loan for Argentina. ``Before we discuss the bridge loan, there would have to be a `bridge' to something. That something is the conclusion of the IMF financial arrangement. We did talk in very specific terms about concluding the IMF package. I believe that ... the government of Argentina and the IMF are quite close on this and we hope that it would be resolved very soon,'' Quayle said. Quayle left for Brazil, where he will attend the inauguration on Thursday of President Fernando Collor de Mello, after meeting with Argentine business leaders and laying a wreath at the statue of Jose de San Martin, who led the independence struggles of Argentina, Peru and Chile. Menem and Quayle also talked about Cuba, and Menem said he would try to press President Fidel Castro into making democratic reforms in his Marxist nation. Castro will attend the inauguration in Brazil. ``We're not going to meet with Castro (in Brazil),'' Quayle told reporters. ``I have no desire to meet with Fidel Castro. Castro remains isolated. I had talks with the other leaders, presidents of this hemisphere, and they have conveyed to me the sense of isolation that Fidel Castro now finds himself in. Castro must back change, and sooner or later change will come to Cuba. I am convinced of that.'' Quayle asked Menem to also try to get Castro to halt arms shipments to the leftist rebels in El Salvador. The rebels have the strongest insurgent movement in Latin America, and are waging war on the U.S.-backed government of Alfredo Cristiani. U.S. officials said earlier that Quayle was encouraging Menem to take severe austerity measures to curb surging inflation, but was offering no aid. Menem told Quayle on Tuesday that he was putting teeth in his vow to make economic reforms and restore his country's credibility internationally, said one Quayle aide who briefed reporters on condition of anonymity. Argentina has been experiencing inflation of about 70 percent a month. Since taking office last July, Menem has lifted controls on wages, prices, foreign exchange and investment. He has reduced the fiscal budget, partly deregulated the oil industry, lowered import tariffs and pledged to sell a string of money-losing companies. However, the measures have failed to control the inflation that has bedeviled the country, registering triple digits in 14 of the past 15 years. ``He has to cut government. He has to fire government employees. He needs to do what he says (he will do),'' said one U.S. official traveling with Quayle. The country's economic straits, including shrinking of real wages by as much as 50 percent in the past year, have prompted looting of food stores, strikes against national banks, an ongoing teacher strike and a strike by clerks that disrupted the federal court system.

DOC.HEAD: Moderate Likely to Become Grenada Prime Minister
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 4th graf, `Complete but ...' with talks under way. Pickup 5th graf pvs, `The Grenada...'
DOC.TEXT: The man who led a 13-month interim government after the U.S. invasion of 1983 emerged today as Grenada's likely new prime minister after parliamentary elections. Nicholas Brathwaite's centrist National Democratic Congress fell one seat short of a legislative majority in Tuesday's balloting, but most observers expected him to be able to persuade at least one legislator to switch to his party to form a government. ``We have a situation where there will have to be negotiations, which I would have preferred not to have,'' Brathwaite, 64, said early today. ``But at the same time, I think it is not a difficult situation.'' Complete but unofficial results gave the National Democratic Congress seven of the 15 seats in the House of Representatives, Grenada's Parliament. With one more seat, Brathwaite would have an eight-seat majority and he held talks early today with other legislators about switching to his party. The Grenada United Labor Party of Sir Eric Gairy, the eccentric former prime minister deposed in a leftist coup in 1979, was second with four seats. Gairy, 68, who dominated Grenada's politics for nearly three decades before his ouster, lost his bid for a parliamentary seat. But his party, with the second most legislators, will likely form the official opposition, and he could still play a role behind the scenes. The National Party of acting Prime Minister Ben Jones and the New National Party led by Keith Mitchell, a former Cabinet minister, won two seats each. Jones and Mitchell were both returned to Parliament. The leftist Maurice Bishop Patriotic Movement failed to gain any parliamentary seats. Radio Grenada said the results were complete but unofficial. Official results, along with the popular vote totals, were to be announced later today. It was the second election since U.S. troops, along with a token regional force, invaded the tiny Caribbean island and toppled a Marxist junta, and there had been concern over the possible destabilizing effect of a Gairy victory. Gairy, the first prime minister after independence from Britain in 1974, has been dogged by allegations of corruption and repression throughout his career. As early as 1961, Britain dissolved his pre-independence government because of allegations of financial irregularities. Though nearly blind with glaucoma, Gairy had spoken of the possibility of a ``miracle'' cure and had declared his campaign divinely inspired. The election happened to fall on the 11th anniversary of the Marxist coup that toppled Gairy's authoritarian regime and brought to power Bishop's People's Revolutionary Government. Bishop and 10 others were assassinated Oct. 19, 1983 following a split in his government. Six days later, the U.S.-led invasion force landed and evicted the junta that had seized power. U.S. officials said the invasion was necessary to protect American lives and prevent Grenada from becoming a staging post for Communist aggression in the region. Brathwaite, an educator with no political experience at the time, was called on to head the government during the 13-month period between the invasion and the election in December 1984. Before the last election, the Reagan administration pressured three centrist parties to merge into the New National Party led by the late Prime Minister Herbert Blaize, mainly to block Gairy. Blaize won 14 seats but the piecemeal party had disintegrated by the time of his death in December at the age of 71.

DOC.HEAD: Fewer Than Two of Three Americans Favor Lunar Base and Mars Missions
DOC.TEXT: Approval of the United States space program is at an all-time high, but fewer than two out of three Americans favor the lunar base and Mars missions proposed by President Bush, according to a survey released today. Eighty percent of the American people favor the space program, said the nationwide telephone poll of 1,200 registered voters conducted by Market Opinion Research. The poll was commissioned by Rockwell International Corporation, one of the biggest aerospace manufacturers and builder of the space shuttles. The survey, which has a margin of error of plus or minus 2.8 percent, showed approval rating of the space program continuing to rise from 56 percent in May 1978. The space station, which is entering the building phase, was favored by 74 percent of those polled, up from 69 percent last March. The National Aero-Space plane, still on the drawing boards, is favored by 70 percent, up from 57 percent last year. On the 20th anniversary last July of man's first landing on the moon, Bush outlined a goal of returning to the moon and sending manned expeditions to Mars early in the next century. Only 64 percent of the poll respondents favored the lunar proposal and only 62 percent favored going to Mars. While 85 percent of the respondents believe it is important that the United States take the lead in developing new technologies for those programs and for monitoring the environment, only 56 percent agreed that the government should spend ``whatever is necessary'' to maintain its position of leadership.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Covenant House Program Plagued With Drugs and Violence
DOC.TEXT: Officials at the embattled Covenant House shelter program ltolerated crime and drug and alcohol use in a program they considered a model for training and counseling disturbed young people, a newspaper reported today. Youngsters allegedly beat girlfriends, extorted from roommates and robbed merchants without being kicked out of the Rights of Passage program, New York Newsday reported, citing internal memos and employees. Newsday reported that a female counselor in the Rights of Passage program had sex with female clients for months before being suspended recently. The newspaper said drinking and drug use were rampant in the program, and youths encouraged girlfriends and buddies to use Covenant House as a flophouse. Covenant House is the country's largest organization providing shelters for runaways. It started Rights of Passage, an 18-to-24 month training and counseling program, partly to answer criticism that the organization was warehousing rather than counseling runaways. Program Director Bruce Henry told Newsday that the program has been ``a phenomenal success'' precisely because there are no rigid rules, and that clients are treated on a case-by-case basis. ``A great many of our kids have disturbances when they come, but they are drug-free. They are, however, 20-year-old street kids and they exhibit all the problems they come in with,'' Henry said. Covenant House has been plagued in recent weeks by accusations of financial and sexual misconduct by its founder, the Rev. Bruce Ritter. The priest resigned as director Feb. 27. The Village Voice, a weekly newspaper, reported today that Ritter gave more than $200,000 in Covenant House contracts to his niece and her husband. Ellen Wallace Lolland was given the contract to decorate and furnish Covenant House centers nationwide; her husband, Tandy, managed multimillion-dollar construction and remodeling contracts, the Voice said. Stanley Arkin, Ritter's lawyer, said the Lollands got the contracts because they submitted the lowest bids. He suggested Mrs. Lolland's interest in her uncle's work led them to charitably bid low and even return some proceeds to Covenant House as donations.

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers throughout the country. March 9 Statesman Journal, Salem, Ore., on the Bush transportation plan: When candidate George Bush said, ``Read my lips _ no new taxes,'' we didn't know exactly what he meant. As President George Bush, he has spelled it out: He'll pass federal duties on to local governments and let them pay the bill and raise the taxes. That's what he and Congress already have done with education and health care, and it's what he proposes in his new ``Moving America Into the 21st Century'' plan for our transportation system. The federal government would continue paying the costs for interstate and many major highways, but it would give states and local governments the bill for building and maintaining millions of miles of other highways. And it would impose extensive user fees for motorists, truckers, air travelers and mass transit customers. This is a tax increase by another name. It's a tax increase that local governments cannot pay and probably should not have to pay for a transportation system that is national in scope. ... At the least, Washington should deal with us honestly. If our crumbling and clogged highways are a national problem, remedy it with a national program and admit that federal taxes must be increased, or that other programs must be cut back to save the money.

March 11 The Providence (R.I.) Journal-Bulletin on the Bush transportation plan: As many travelers know, parts of America's transportation network have fallen on hard times. Many highways and bridges are crumbling under heavy traffic; major airports are choked with congestion; passenger rail service is scattered and spotty, and urban mass transit is often a joke. The Bush administration has dug bravely into this thicket of problems. Its new transportation policy ... represents a sharp departure from past practice. It seeks essentially to shrink the federal role in everything from highway maintenance to mass transit operations, and to transfer many costs to state and local governments. ... (I)n a nation the size of the United States, transportation is a national concern deserving national treatment. It is by no means assured that transferring large pieces of this responsibility to local governments is the best way to restore our battered system to health.

March 13 Los Angeles Times on the Rostenkowski deficit reduction plan: For most Americans, the national debt is as abstract as the numbers that measure it _ currently about $3,000,000,000,000, as in trillion. ... Getting Washington to focus again on the debt is only one reason to cheer Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the House Ways and Means Committe, for his bold plan to slash the federal budget deficit. ... The more than $150 billion a year that vanishes into interest payments means that there is much less money in circulation for private investment and, in turn, economic expansion and job creation. This debt is of increasing consequence as the economy slows down because it severely cuts the nation's ability to bail itself out of a severe recession. Rostenkowski's plan would not wipe out the national debt but would keep it from growing after 1994. ... Where would the money come from? A one-year freeze on cost-of-living increases in all federal programs would cut the deficit by 9 percent the first year. Higher taxes on oil, tobacco, alcohol and industrial pollutants would cut it another $20 billion. Cutting the Pentagon budget by 3 percent a year would convert another $10 billion from red ink to black. Families with incomes above $185,000 a year, who now pay income taxes as a 28 percent rate, would pay the same 33 percent that families with smaller incomes pay. ... (T)he White House and some Republican leaders in Congress resisted any temptation to attack the plan. ... That, plus renewed attention to the deficit, is an improvement over recent behavior on all sides.

March 10 Kennebec Journal, Augusta, Maine, on clean air legislation: Twenty years after the Clean Air Act was first passed, the ... Senate majority leader (George Mitchell) has clinched a deal to overhaul and strengthen it. Following 12 days of closed-door meetings, Mitchell unveiled a compromise which the Bush administration supports, business is grumbling about, and some environmental groups are wild about. In the most purple prose, Mitchell is said to have ``gutted'' the bill. That's nonsense. Mitchell knows that after a decade of inaction, begun with the inauguration of Ronald ``Trees Cause Pollution'' Reagan, the nation has got to get a new clean air bill on the books. To be sure, there are disappointments. Pollution reduction techniques for cars and trucks _ contributing perhaps half of all ozone pollution _ are highly developed. But the technology has not been used sufficiently, thanks largely to Reagan. This time out, Bush's proposal for alternative fuel vehicles was cut, as were the most stringent ``tailpipe'' standards. On the other hand, the acid rain-fighting measures, cracking down on high sulfur coal burning in the Midwest, are mostly intact. The most punitive sanctions for cities exceeding federal pollution standards _ shutting down all development _ aren't going to be used anyway, so their loss is mostly symbolic. All in all, Mitchell has done well. Any comparison with the Clean Air Acts of 1970 and 1990 shows some major improvements, long overdue. Mitchell's critics ought to remember that the deadlock of Reagan years, where a president stubbornly refused to acknowledge scientific reality, is unlikely to recur. If this doesn't work, the law can be changed again. But it's still a big step forward, the first in a long, long time.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: long time.
DOC.TEXT: March 11 The Santa Fe (N.M.) New Mexican on the clean air bill: The New Clean Air Act has finally come to the floor of the U.S. Senate. But the legislation is like the senior prom _ a lot of people are unhappy with their date. Expectations were too high and now everyone's got some gripe with the bill. It's true that in a perfect world the bill would be tougher with respect to cleaning up urban smog and laying the groundwork for reducing air pollution health hazards of the future. But we don't live in a perfect world, and compromise is the order of the day in Congress. The bill nonetheless requires cuts in harmful sulfur dioxide emissions by 10 million tons by the year 2000 and caps emissions thereafter. It also requires tough new smog standards, focusing on automobile emission controls. Unfortunately, its alternative fuel provisions are weaker than they ought to be, resulting from Bush administration backpedaling. It's possible this can be strengthened with amendments on the Senate floor. But whatever its flaws, the overall concept of this legislation is a major step forward. It should be passed so the real work can begin. Holding it up is like holding your breath _ in the end, you've got to breathe the air, and it will be better with the compromise legislation than without it.

March 12 St. Cloud (Minn.) Times on the defense budget: There's a lot of talk in these ``post Cold War'' days about a so-called peace dividend. The politicians and special interest groups are lined up, waiting to claim the money they believe should be diverted from the U.S. defense budget. Certainly the Bush administration and Congress would be wise to consider the possibility of cutting military expenditures in some ares _ especially if arms control talks between the two superpowers continue to move ahead. But a wholesale slash in U.S. military personnel, equipment and maintenance would be folly. Even if reforms that have swept across Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union continue. Even if Central American nations carry off their precarious conversions to democracy. Even if worldwide relations are comfortably stable. Even when peace reigns, this country needs a strong military. The dividends of peace can be realized without making rash reductions in personnel and equipment. They can be found, instead, in conversion. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney _ undoubtedly a man driven these days by a need to justify his department's strength _ has the right idea. (Two weeks ago), the Pentagon announced a significant expansion in use of warships, aircraft and communications equipment against what many Americans consider their greatest enemy _ illegal drugs. The move is an example of how American's military power can be put to ``nontraditional'' uses. Adjusting priorities is wiser than eradicating large hunks of our defense _ at least at this point.

March 13 The News and Observer, Raleigh, N.C., on the National Guard and drugs: When the ... National Guard is called out to protect and assist the citizenry ... it bolsters law enforcement and the public's feeling that all is under control. But the planned involvement of the Guard in the drug war, in searching air and sea cargo and in riding with local law enforcement officers, goes too far. It follows, unfortunately, the mentality of too many leaders in the anti-drug fight _ that the fight is to be won on some figurative battlefield with muscle and bullets and prisons instead of in the classroom and the treatment ward. Under that mentality, the right of citizens to be free of unreasonable searches, for example, already is under strain. How much more intimidating would the authorities conducting those searches be if backed by the firepower of the Guard? Ostensibly, the Guard is only to assist civilian law enforcement agencies _ helping Customs inspectors with cargo searches. ... There's a fine line, however, between low-key assistance and a high-profile strong arm. ... The stresses of combat, for which the Guard does train people, are different from those that arise in maintaining law and order in a community. The National Guard cannot and should not train people for both possibilities. In the drug war, the Guard's place is not on the front lines.

March 10 The Phoenix Gazette on the Postal Service: In recent years, the U.S. Postal Service has eliminated Sunday mail sorting, slashed window hours at local post offices and, most recently, cut back on one-day delivery. Having thus been blessed by a reduction in services, the American people can now look forward to another increase in prices. Postmaster General Anthony Frank announced that a 30-cent stamp seems likely for first-class mail next year. Unfortunately, the Postal Service has a government-sanctioned monopoly over daily mail delivery. When forced to compete, the Postal Service has been clobbered by the competition. Consumers voted with their parcels when United Parcel Service got into the parcel business. The Postal Service now carries less than 10 percent of all parcels shipped by the public. The same is true for Express Mail. The Postal Service's share of overnight-delivery mail has declined to less than 10 percent. The Postal Service managed to operate about $404 million in the black for the first quarter of this fiscal year, but the agency expects a record $1.6 billion deficit for the full year ending Sept. 30. The Postal Service claims that it has to preserve its monopoly so that it can be a ``public service,'' but being a monopoly destroys the service incentive. It has been suggested that deregulating the delivery of third-class mail would greatly expand the network of private mail deliverers and create pressure to abolish the first-class mail monopoly.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: mail monopoly.
DOC.TEXT: March 7 The News and Courier, Charleston, S.C., on the Soviet Union: (Mikhail) Gorbachev never has been unwilling to take the plunge to a market economy principally because of his desire to seek Marxist-Leninist answers to the country's ills. But the recent explosions of ethnic and regional animosities in Azerbaijan, Armenia and Turkistan, and the growing separatist movements in the Baltic republics of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, have served only to make ... Gorbachev even more reluctant to bite the bullet and embrace market solutions. As a result, shortages of every conceivable item from food to fuel have become more severe. There are, simply, too many rubles chasing too few goods at fixed artificial prices, and the result is a populace that is hungry, angry and increasingly alienated by ... Gorbachev's promise to cleave to the Leninist path. (Radical Soviet politician Boris) Yeltsin, as his showings in the last three elections have demonstrated, has proved a master at tapping the deep undercurrent of unrest in the Soviet Union. ``This is the last chance for the party,'' he told a cheering crowd in Moscow recently. ``This is also Gorbachev's last chance. Either he acts or he loses us.'' Tough words. But ... Yeltsin has demonstrated that he has more than enough popular muscle to back them up.

March 7 Daily American Republic, Poplar Bluff., Mo., on the Bureau of Indian Affairs: The Bureau of Indian Affairs is like the Soviet economy: It's forever being repaired but never gets fixed. A new Senate committee report details the agency's record of waste, corruption and mismanagement. Indian preferences in contracting have spawned Indian-front companies. The Senate's two-year study found that 19 of the largest contractors are fronts for non-Indian businesses. Abuse is the norm rather than the exception in loan programs, management of Indian trust funds, procurement, computer services and road construction. Tribal resources the bureau is charged with protecting have been stolen or neglected. ... The Senators note that the agency has been reformed 42 times. That's more than enough perestroika. It's time for drastic action. Abused in so many ways for so many years, our native Americans deserve nothing less than a complete overhaul of this entrenched and corrupt sub-bureaucracy.

March 11 The Sun Herald, Biloxi, Miss., on better food labeling: We agree wholeheartedly with Louis W. Sullivan's description of the American supermarket as a ``Tower of Babel'' as far as food labeling is concerned and we support his announced intention of reforming labeling regulations. While Americans have become more conscious of nutritional requirements and the importance of healthy eating habits, food labels have become increasingly confusing and deceptive. What's ``low fat'' to one food producer is something else to a competitor. What ``high fiber'' means on one cereal box isn't the same as it is on the box next to it. Unfortunately, Food and Drug Administration officials estimate it will be two years before reforms are in place and consumers will benefit from them. As Secretary of Health and Human Services, Sullivan ought to use his position to shorten that period.

March 10 The Waukesha County Freeman, Waukesha, Wis., on farmers: It is high time to defend the poor farmer. Worse than plummeting land values, worse even than losing the family farm, the farmer's image, in this age of images, has suffered an unfair beating at the uncallused hands of ersatz sophisticates and rude lampooners ... at least. Continuing to receive wide currency is the notion that farmers are bucolic dopes trapped in the past. The notion is profoundly bogus. What's really past tense here is the perverted image of a dour, pitch-fork-wielding dirt farmer _ an animal husband _ whose days are divided between shoveling feed into one end of a cow and scooping up the processed feed at the other end and then completing the sod-bound cycle by sprinkling it back on the ground in time for the next planting. In fact and in truth, the modern farmer is just that _ thoroughly modern. Some might even say ``slick.'' Just to survive along the fat red edge of financial existence, farmers must spend incredible amounts of money on the best available technology. It's not just that the tractors are bigger and more complicated, air-conditioned even. There are other machines as well. And the computer has come to the farm in force. The modern farmer shovels data and lets a machine mind the manure. The roadside veggie stand has been replaced by the world market. Hybrids, hormones and genetics are the stuff of the modern farm. Yes, it's true that some have complained about library taxes being unjust to the farmer because ``cows can't read'' _ but that is really another example that farmers are getting more sophisticated: What a marvelous public relations gimmick _ illiterate cattle! Who but a farmer could have thought of it? Thus, while we agree with the good intentions of the proponents of modernity, we cringe when we hear our friends and allies besmirched with derogatory adjectives such as ``small-town,'' ``hicksville'' and ``farmer-type.'' And so it is time to give the farmer a break, to cease casting farmers as unenlightened saps and to look elsewhere for our rhetorical buffoons. Candidates abound. It needn't be a lengthy search.
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
Four Dead as Violence Spreads Throughout South Africa
DOC.TEXT: An unidentified gunman shot and killed a white riot control officer in the central Natal province today, and three blacks were killed in widespread unrest in the nation's black areas. Top police commanders flew by helicopter to the Hammarsdale area in central Natal province, and a massive search began for the gunman who police suspect shot the officer from a distance, the South African Press Association reported. Police Lt. Bala Naidoo said the officer was discovered alone in his police car with gunshot wounds to the head, neck and shoulder. He said the attack occurred close to an overhead bridge and that the shots came through the passenger window. Two black police officers were killed in the same area Feb. 25, but a similar manhunt was not undertaken. Speaking before the shooting, Maj. Gen. Herman Stadler, the police public relations chief, attributed the recent upsurge in unrest to political rivalries, socio-economic factors, crime and the ``euphoria of freedom.'' At least 200 people, mostly blacks, have been killed in unrest throughout South Africa in the last month. For the most part, the violence has been confined to black areas of the country. The escalating voiolence has coincided with President F.W. de Klerk's legalization of 60 outlawed organizations and the freeing of African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela after 27 years in prison. Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok said in a Tuesday address to parliament that ``radicals and revolutionaries who boast of victory and dream of a power takeover are in for the shock of their lives.'' Three blacks were killed in unrest reported today, including one black who was shot and killed by police and two who were killed in clashes between black groups. Police said 39 people, including 7 police officers were wounded in the unrest. They said one officer was stabbed and six were injured by stone-throwers. Police said 37 people were arrested in scattered incidents. A police report released today listed 14 attacks on police or their homes. The report said blacks used stones and gasoline bombs, and in one case iron pipes in the attacks. Most of the incidents mentioned in the report took place today or Tuesday night, but some of the attacks took place Sunday night or Monday and were first reported today.

DOC.HEAD: Castro Says Cuban Independence Necessary For Latin America
With PM-Cuba-TV
DOC.TEXT: President Fidel Castro of Cuba said his hard-line Communist government guarantees the independence of Latin American nations against U.S. domination. ``If Cuba falls, the United States will treat Latin American leaders not as leaders nor as presidents, but with less respect than American mayors,'' Castro told 50,000 students gathered to hear him late Tuesday. Cuba's official Prensa Latina, monitored in Mexico City, carried Castro's remarks. The president spoke at a celebration marking the 33rd anniversary of a botched attack on the presidential palace by militant students who hoped to depose former dictator Fulgencio Batista. In 1959, Castro led the popular uprising that toppled Batista. ``Cubans will defend their revolution like children defend their parents,'' Castro said, adding that Cuba's government would ``never fall.'' Castro said Latin American leaders are afraid of what might happen should Cuba's government fall. He did not elaborate. The Cuban leader has found himself increasingly isolated as Communist governments have tumbled in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union has expressed irritation with Castro's rigid Marxism. Castro has said his country will stick to orthodox communism even if Moscow ends all financial support.

DOC.HEAD: Imports Sparking Angry Response From Farmers
DOC.TEXT: Farmers have plowed up their fields and left crops to rot to protest an influx of cheap foreign products that is forcing down domestic prices. Radish growers in a southern region this week drove tractors over their fields and have threatened to crush nearly half their crops. Government officials promised compensation and launched an ``eat-more-radish'' campaign, but consumers appeared to be largely ignoring it. Local newspapers reported Wednesday that heaps of discarded pears have begun dotting orchards in a southern pear-growing area, as growers opt to destroy their crops rather than put up with further price decreases for their products. In recent years, farmers have staged sometimes violent demonstrations against imported products. The United States, which pressured South Korea to open its agricultural market, often is singled out by farmers. South Korea's importation of foreign agricultural products in 1989 was $6.67 billion, up 16.8 percent from 1988. The imports included items such as peanuts and grapes, which in the past were major sources of income for domestic farmers. As a result, many South Korean farmers have been forced to turn to less lucrative crops such as radishes. In addition, negotiations are under way between U.S. and South Korean officials over a U.S. request to further open the South Korean beef market. Thousands of farmers and cattle growers battled riot police in 1988 when the government first relaxed controls on beef imports. Officials of the Agriculture Ministry said about $150 million in subsidies have been set aside to help farmers. The nation's quarantine requirements also will be strengthened in an effort to curb imports, they said.

DOC.HEAD: 10 Killed, 70 Injured When Buses Collide
DOC.TEXT: Two buses collided head-on near Dhaka, killing at least 10 people and injuring 70 others, police said Wednesday. Five people were killed instantly and five died later in hospitals after Tuesday night's accident, police said. It occurred near Gazipur, 20 miles north of Dhaka. The police said at least 22 of the injured were in serious condition.

DOC.HEAD: Unexploded Head From Rocket Shell Removed From Farmer's Arm
DOC.TEXT: Vietnamese army surgeons removed the unexploded head of an M-79 rocket shell from a farmer's arm in ``an extremely tense'' operation, the official Vietnam News Agency said. Hoang Minh Son, 36, was working in a field in the central province of Thua Thien-Hue on Feb. 22 when his hoe struck the U.S.-made shell. It detonated and sent the egg-size head into the farmer's left arm. In a report dated Tuesday and seen in Bangkok on Wednesday, the agency quoted explosives and ballistics experts as saying that ``it was too risky to tamper with the shell head as it might explode at the slightest displacement,'' so immediate surgery was required. The operation was performed Feb. 26 at a military hospital in the provincial capital of Hue. Two surgeons ``volunteered for the job,'' the news agency reported. The head surgeon ``skillfully took the shell out of the victim's arm and transfered it to a bomb disposal squad,'' said the report. It did not say where the shell came from, but unexploded rounds left over from the Vietnam War have killed or maimed many people in Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia since the fighting ended in 1975. Fierce, bloody battles raged throughout Hue, the ancient imperial capital, when the Communists attacked and occupied the city in the pivotal Tet offensive of early 1968.

DOC.HEAD: Two Subway Trains Narrowly Miss Head-On Crash
DOC.TEXT: A subway train traveling in the wrong direction during rush hour nearly rammed head-on into a crowded stationary train, but quick thinking by a conductor prevented a crash, the London Underground said Wednesday. The driver of the non-moving train reached out his window and pulled together two low-voltage wires on the tunnel wall to short-circuit the electricity supply, said Neil Howard, a spokesman for the Underground. This brought the moving train to a stop, only 400 feet from the other train, Howard said. It was traveling at about 20 mph. The incident occurred at 6 p.m. Monday on the Piccadilly Line branch of the subway system. John Robson, the driver of the stationary train, said Wednesday he was ``slightly shocked'' when he saw the headlights coming toward him on the same track. ``All I could think to do was to open the cab door and pull the emergency wires to bring him to a halt,'' he said. Robson said when he turned around, all the passengers had fled the first car of his train. ``Who can blame them? They must have heard what I said over the radio to my control that a train had been approaching from the front,'' he said. There were about 800 commuters crowded onto Robson's train. London Underground has begun an investigation, said Howard. Spokeswoman Jocelyn Baker said the near-accident was the result of human error but that no decision has been made whether to take disciplinary action. She said staff have been working ``around the clock'' installing 50 red lights at crossover points in the system to prevent drivers from going the wrong way into tunnels. She said the driver of the empty train should have gone south after letting off his passengers. Instead, he switched to the car at the other end of the train and started traveling north on the southbound track.

DOC.HEAD: Rosamond Lehmann, British Novelist, Is Dead At Age 89
DOC.TEXT: Rosamond Lehmann, whose novels of love, betrayal and family rivalries were critically acclaimed from the 1920s to the 1950s and republished decades later, has died, her family announced Wednesday. She was 89. No cause of death was stated for Ms. Lehmann, who died Monday at her home in London. Her first novel, ``Dusty Answer,'' won immediate fame for the young author when it was published in 1927. The novel, about a young girl's development from childhood to maturity, was praised for its candor, wit, psychological insight and lyrical, sensuous quality of writing. She followed this with ``A Note of Music'' in 1930, ``Invitation to the Waltz'' in 1932, ``The Weather in the Streets'' in 1936, ``The Ballad and the Source'' in 1944 and ``The Gypsy's Baby,'' a collection of short stories, in 1946. Her next book was ``The Echoing Grove,'' about the relationship between two sisters and the man who is married to one and the lover of the other. With shifts of time and approach, the same incidents in the book are seen through the eyes of different people. The book was written after the bitter breakup of Ms. Lehmann's love affair with the poet Cecil Day Lewis, and critics said it carried clear traces of that time in her life. The soft-voiced author grew up in a large, comfortable home at Bourne End on the River Thames near London. She was educated at Cambridge University. She met her first husband, Walter Runciman, who was later to become Lord Runciman, at Cambridge University. They married in 1923 and were divorced in 1928. Later in 1928, she married Wogan Philipps, the eldest son of the first Lord Milford, the shipping magnate. They had two children, Hugo and Sally. That marriage ended in divorce in 1944. Her grief over the death of her daughter from polio led her to spiritualism for a time. For many of her later years she was vice president of the privately funded College of Psychic Studies in London. Toward the end of her life, the Virago Press, which specializes in publishing work by women, republished many of her novels, introducing her work to a new generation of readers. Queen Elizabeth II awarded Ms. Lehmann the Commander of the Order of the British Empire in 1982. She is survived by her son, Hugo. Funeral services were scheduled March 19 in London.

DOC.HEAD: Maine Constitution Does Not Let Felons Own Guns, Supreme Court Rules
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 3rd graf, `The justices...', with reax. Picks up 4th graf, `The amendment...'.
DOC.TEXT: A 1987 amendment to the Maine Constitution that says the right to bear arms ``shall never be questioned'' does not mean felons have the right to own guns, the state's highest court ruled today. ``Plainly, the people of Maine who voted for the amendment never intended that an inmate at Maine State Prison or a patient in a mental hospital would have an absolute right to bear a firearm,'' the unanimous Maine Supreme Judicial Court said. The justices struck down a ruling from a Superior Court judge who said last year that the amendment did not prohibit a non-violent habitual traffic offender, Edward Brown, from owning a gun. ``This is a victory for common sense,'' state Attorney General James E. Tierney said in Augusta. ``The supreme court has avoided a hypertechnical reading of the statute.'' Brown's lawyer, Daniel Bates, was out of town and not immediately available for comment, a secretary said. The amendment approved by voters said ``every citizen has a right to keep and bear arms; and this right shall never be questioned.'' It struck out the words ``for the common defense'' from the original right-to-bear-arms provision. ``Prior to the 1987 amendment the Maine Constitution afforded no absolute right to keep and bear arms and we now hold that no absolute right was created by the amendment,'' today's ruling said. The justices said ``the evident purpose of the amendment was merely to transform a collective right to bear arms into an individual right and nothing more.'' The justices also said the amendment did not invalidate a state law prohibiting gun possession by felons. ``One who has committed any felony has displayed a degree of lawlessness that makes it entirely reasonable for the legislature, concerned for the safety of the public it represents, to want to keep firearms out of the hands of such a person,'' the justices said. The case had fostered an unusual alliance among the National Rifle Association, the national Center to Prevent Handgun Violence, the Sportsman's Alliance of Maine and the Maine Chiefs of Police Association. All the groups supported the state attorney general's appeal of the lower court ruling. The amendment was prompted by a 1986 Maine supreme court ruling that upheld the illegal possession of firearms conviction of a felon who had argued that the Constitution guaranteed his right to bear arms. In that ruling, the justices found that the Constitution protected the right to bear arms only ``for the common defense.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Tours Power Plant; Says Clean Air Proposal Will Be Costly
DOC.TEXT: President Bush toured the power plant that produces the White House's electricity today and acknowledged that it will cost utilities ``megabucks'' to comply with his proposed tougher clean air rules. But Bush, speaking outside the Potomac Electric Co.'s Chalk Point Generating Station, said he was committed to giving industry flexibility in how to cut back on sulfur dioxide emissions and other pollution. He urged the Senate to pass the compromise version of the Clean Air Act recently hammered out by Senate leaders and the White House. ``We can't let this country screech to a halt, but I am determined to clean up the air,'' declared Bush. ``The bill is consistent with the need to balance environmental benefits and sustain economic growth for this country,'' said Bush, standing beside PEPCO President Edward F. Mitchell. Bush, who viewed giant twin turbines inside the plant, the largest in Maryland, said, ``Ed was telling me there's megabucks involved in all of this.'' He promised the new stricter rules would be made ``as cost-effective as possible'' with utilities given maximum flexibility to decide how to meet them. The Chalk Point plant, burning coal as well as oil and natural gas in four units, generates 2,000 megawatts at the sprawling 1,160-acre facility along the Patuxent River, 45 miles outside Washington. It now meets federal and state pollution standards. A PEPCO spokeswoman, Nancy Moses, said the utility estimates it will cost $12 million a year to bring the plant up to the first phase of the proposed new clean air standards. Then it will take a capital investment of $264 million for scrubbers and other technology plus $36 million a year in higher operating costs to meet the second phase, she said. Bush said PEPCO officials assured him their company ``is committed to take these additional steps to meet these even tougher standards. ... For that we're very grateful.'' Bush also toured the plant's ``Aquaculture Center'' where PEPCO raises 1 million striped bass or rockfish to replenish the depleted waters of the nearby Chesapeake Bay.

DOC.HEAD: Romanians Travel to Austria Hours Before Visa Requirement Takes Effect
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Romanians traveled to Austria today, many hoping to apply for refugee status only hours before a new visa requirement takes effect. Authorities and angered citizens sought to prevent a possible flood of refugees, and officials said they had begun turning back Romanians who were unable to show they had sufficient hard currency to pay for their stay. In the town of Traiskirchen just south of Vienna, where Austria's main refugee camp is located, residents blocked all main roads to the town to prevent Romanians from reaching the camp, which officials said already was filled up with refugees, many from the East bloc. The visa requirement, which goes into effect at midnight, was enacted by Austrian authorities following heated debates in recent weeks. Controversy over plans to house 800 Romanian refugees in an Austrian village of 200 further fueled the discussion. According to police in the Austrian border region of Burgenland, 7,000 Romanians entered Austria from Hungary during the night and early morning. Thousands of others _ far more than usual _ headed for the border, although travelers to Budapest did not notice unusually heavy traffic heading toward Austria. The Burgenland province police director, Johann Schoretits, said in a telephone interview that border authorities were instructed to require Romanians entering Austria to prove that they possess enough hard currency to pay for at least a 14-day stay in Austria, amounting to about $400, or that they had visas for other countries. Romanians who could not show either were turned back, he said. In Budapest, a Hungarian border guard official, Janos Cseh-Nemeth, said Austrian authorities had delayed the ``Orient Express'' passenger train traveling from the East to Western Europe and barred entry to about 175 Romanians _ 25 percent of the train's passengers. In Budapest, a border guard spokesman, Lt. Col. Janos Zubek, said traffic on the Hungarian side of the border was normal. But the Austria Press Agency reported that thousands of Romanians were waiting to enter the country before the visa requirement goes into effect. The Hungarian-Austrian border is no longer divided by barbed wire and other barriers installed during the Cold War. Hungarian authorities began removing them last year after democratic reforms, and tens of thousands of East Germans fled to the West over that border last summer. The exodus of East Germans helped cause the fall of the hard-line Communist leadership in East Germany and the subsequent whirlwind of democratic change that swept through Eastern Europe. Austria has traditionally been a haven for refugees from Eastern Europe. Tens of thousands came from Hungary in 1956, when Soviet troops crushed an anti-Communist uprising, from Czechoslovakia in 1968, when a Soviet-led invasion squelched democratic reforms and most recently from East Germany. The government says most people arriving from Eastern Europe can no longer be considered political refugees under the Geneva Convention, following the democratization in those countries. The authorities say most East Europeans coming to Austria now are seeking better living conditions than they could hope for in the ruined economies left by the ousted Communist leaderships in their homelands.

DOC.HEAD: INS Agents Find 45 Suspected Aliens on Flight in Atlanta
DOC.TEXT: Immigration agents apprehended 45 suspected illegal aliens today on an Eastern Airlines jet making a stopover on a flight from Los Angeles to New York. Agents found the 45 people from Mexico, Peru, Guatemala, El Salvador, Colombia, Honduras and Ecuador on Eastern Flight 88, said Thomas P. Fischer, district director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service in Atlanta. Three other people were detained originally but then released. ``This may be part of a massive alien smuggling operation, and our agents will continue to investigate all possible leads to finally break this large-scale, nationwide operation,'' Fischer said. Agents said the majority of the suspected illegal aliens were traveling to New York to find jobs. Those from Mexico will be taken to Brownsville, Texas, and returned to Mexico, he said, while the others will be taken to Miami for processing. The roundup at Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport was similar to one at the airport in February 1989. Then, INS agents found 79 illegal aliens aboard another Eastern flight from Los Angeles to New York. INS agents said then that they were tipped off to the possible smuggling operation by a disgruntled businessman who frequently flew the route. The aliens apprehended in 1989 told INS agents they had paid $900 to $4,000 each to smugglers to get across the border into Los Angeles and then paid other smugglers for plane tickets to New York, where they planned to find work or contact relatives.

DOC.HEAD: U.S.-Bound Jet Makes Emergency Landing
DOC.TEXT: A Northwest Airlines jet bound for Boston dumped its fuel and made an emergency landing Wednesday at Scotland's Prestwick Airport after the crew reported an electrical problem. Airline spokeswoman Sue Majors said the aircraft ``was made serviceable'' and took off again nearly two hours later. The DC-10 was carrying 248 passengers and 11 crew members. Flight 35 was headed from Prestwick to Boston but dumped its fuel into the sea and returned to Prestwick shortly after taking off, said Ms. Majors. Ms. Majors said all of the passengers reboarded the flight to Boston. An investigation was under way into the cause of the problem, she said.

It was a protected, caring environment, the mirror opposite of the camps.'' His other works included ``Dynamics of Prejudice'' (1950), ``Truants from Life'' (1955), ``The Informed Heart'' (1960), and ``The Children of the Dream'' (1969). Bettelheim's wife, Gertrud Weinfeld, died in 1984. He is survived by three children. Funeral arrangements were not immediately known.

DOC.HEAD: Exeter Officials Invite Gorbachev to Town
DOC.TEXT: School officials have invited Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev to visit their town in June and are optimistic he might come because of an American-Soviet high school academic partnership program. ``I think it's an eight on a scale of one to 10 of happening,'' school board Chairman Roy Morrisette said. Exeter High School is one of 25 U.S. high schools participating in the academic partnership exchange. Two groups of Soviet students have visited Exeter and a second group of Exeter students will go to the Soviet Union next month. Gorbachev also has been invited to New England in June as the commencement speaker at Brown University. Gov. Judd Gregg has invited him to the dedication of the Christa McAuliffe Planetarium in Concord.

DOC.HEAD: Inventories Resume Slow Growth
DOC.TEXT: Business inventories resumed their slow growth in January after a one-month decline, the government reported Wednesday, and analysts said the 0.2 percent gain confirms the sluggishness in the manufacturing economy. The Commerce Department said inventories totaled a seasonally adjusted $795.9 billion, including a steep 0.7 percent jump in manufacturing backlogs. Inventories as a whole fell 0.4 percent in December, the first drop since a 0.1 percent decline in October 1988 and the largest since a 0.6 percent fall in December 1986. The December drop was originally reported to be 0.2 percent. The January report is ``confirming what we already know, that the area of manufacturing is beginning to slow,'' said economist Thomas Runiewicz of the WEFA Group in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. ``We're starting to see rises in paper and chemicals and a lot of basic commodities that are used daily throughout the whole manufacturing industry,'' he said. ``What we're seeing is that as the industry slows down, the demand for commodities slows down.'' The Commerce Department also reported a 0.3 percent increase in business sales to a seasonally adjusted $532 billion in January after falling a revised 0.2 percent in December. December sales first were reported unchanged from November. The January report resulted in a 1.52 ratio of inventories to sales, the same as December but down slightly from a 1.53 ratio in both October and November. The ratio means that it would take 1.52 months to exhaust inventories at the January pace. Inventories often rise during periods of slow economic growth as output exceeds demand. If they were to pile up excessively, it could mean cutbacks in production and a loss of jobs, possibly leading to a recession. But Runiewicz said current inventory levels are not indicative of negative economic growth. ``If anything, when comparing what we've experienced in previous recessions, we've been able to maintain or get more of a grip on inventories,'' he said. ``Previous recessions were accompanied by some inventories becoming out of control.'' Retail backlogs fell 0.6 percent in January, while sales rose 2.8 percent. Automobile inventories dropped 3.6 percent as auto manufacturers temporarily laid off thousands of workers during the month to trim the number of motor vehicles stuck on backlots. But while manufacturing inventories grew 0.7 percent, sales dropped 1.9 percent. Wholesalers' inventories advanced 0.2 percent, while their sales gained 1.4 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Sammy Davis Jr. Leaves Hospital After Cancer Treatment
DOC.TEXT: Sammy Davis Jr. has been released from a hospital and sent home after treatment for a recurrence of throat cancer, his publicist said. ``The initial chemotherapy has been completed. His spirits are up and he continues to fight,'' said spokeswoman Susan Reynolds. Davis, 64, was released Tuesday. He was first diagnosed as having carcinoma of the throat last September and was forced to drop out of a concert tour with Liza Minnelli and Frank Sinatra so he could undergo radiation treatment. Davis was admitted to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in mid-January for treatment of a gum infection and doctors later found that he had a recurrence of throat cancer. Ms. Reynolds said no further treatments were planned. ``Right now the doctors want him to concentrate on building his strength,'' she said. Davis, the versatile singer-dancer, most recently appeared in the 1989 movie ``Tap,'' playing an old-time tap dancer named Little Mo.

DOC.HEAD: Former Bush Press Secretary Named to Post
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Wednesday named his former press secretary as U.S. representative on the executive board of the United Nations Children's Fund. Peter B. Teeley, 50, a political consultant, succeeds Rita Di Martino. Teeley was Bush's press secretary and spokesman from 1980-85 and served as communications director during the early stages of Bush's 1988 presidential campaign.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David Dinkins says there was a method to his acting debut: let Dinkins be Dinkins. The mayor starred as himself in a cameo role in a new made-in-New-York action adventure show called ``H.E.L.P.'' The series is about folks who answer 911 calls and bail people out of a myriad of urban disasters. Dinkins said playing himself was a snap. ``I know me well,'' he said. The mayor's part called for him to present a medal for bravery to a heroic firefighter. In the role, Dinkins strides into City Hall's Blue Room _ site of daily mayoral news conferences _ and utters 56 words. The mayor was paid union scale, $414, for his 30-minutes work Tuesday. He said he plans to donate it to the Harlem Junior Tennis Program, which teaches the sport to indigent youth. Director Janet Greek gushed over Dinkins' moonlighting: ``He was really great.'' Still, the mayor said he has no plans to give up his day job.

Two-way wrist TV-radios will still be tough to find, but this summer's suave man-about-town hunting for the Dick Tracy look should be able to get the comic book sleuth's trademark fedora. George W. Bollman Co. Inc., a hatmaker in Adamstown, about 20 miles west of Philadelphia, is pinning its hopes on the success of a new movie about the square-jawed crime fighter. The movie starring Warren Beatty and Madonna is to be released June 15. The company, which claims to be the world's largest maker of wool felt hats, is busily turning out 40,000 pale yellow hats with wide black bands. The hats will be shipped to stores next month. The company is the sole contractor for Dorfman Pacific, the Stockton, Calif., firm that owns the license for Dick Tracy hats, and Bollman hopes they become a fashion craze. ``Dick Tracy could be as important as Indiana Jones,'' said Bollman president Curtis A. Glass. After Indiana Jones captured moviegoers' imaginations in ``Raiders of the Lost Ark,'' Bollman sold more than 300,000 hats styled after the archaeologist's fedora. Several other companies also made the hats.

DOC.HEAD: Three Dead, 44 Hospitalized in Blaze at Nursing Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Forty-three nursing...', with two grafs to ADD total number of residents, some taken to other nursing homes. Picks up 5th graf, `Sgt. Albert...'. SUBS last graf to ADD conditions.
DOC.TEXT: Fire that consumed one wing of a nursing home killed three patients, officials said today. Two firefighters suffered smoke inhalation fighting Tuesday night's fire, and one was hospitalized, officials said. Forty-three home residents were also hospitalized, but many of them were being treated for problems unrelated to the fire, officials said. The blaze broke out in the west wing of the two-wing Dardanelle Nursing Center about 9:30 p.m. and was extinguished two hours later, said Betty Smith, a police dispatcher in the town 70 miles west of Little Rock. The center had 87 residents. Forty-three nursing home patients were kept overnight at three hospitals, spokesmen said. Twenty-six patients were housed at a National Guard armory, where the nursing home set up temporary operations. Some were taken to other nursing homes in the area. Sgt. Albert Moats said the patients at the armory were devastated by the tragedy. ``There were a lot of wet eyes here last night,'' Moats said. ``There were a lot of people that were upset. You don't expect it to happen in our town, something like this.'' Police Chief Montie Sims said a preliminary investigation by state fire officials was inconclusive. ``It appears from their investigation that the fire started in and around a living area of the building. As to what the exact cause is, we don't know,'' he said. Authorities did not immediately release the names of the dead. Yell County Coroner Mike Cornwell said they were two men and a woman. Donald T. Cline, administrator at Dardanelle Hospital, said most of the 27 people hospitalized there were being treated for medical problems unrelated to the fire. Four patients, including the firefighter, were taken to Baptist Medical Center in Little Rock, where they were in satisfactory condition with smoke inhalation. One also had burns. Thirteen others were at St. Mary's Regional Medical Center in Russellville, where spokeswoman Cindi Chase said all were in stable to fair condition. Three people were treated at the hospital and released, Ms. Chase said.

DOC.HEAD: West Germans Want Nazi Documents Now in U.S. Hands
DOC.TEXT: West Germany is urging the United States to turn over hundreds of thousands of original Nazi documents, but a leading Jewish organization said Wednesday it would try to persuade Congress to stop the move. The Berlin Documents Center, in the American sector of West Berlin, is the biggest repository of Nazi documents in the world. A delegation from West Germany held talks with State Department officials in Washington on March 1-2 about the prospects of transferring the center, which is run by the State Department, officials said. ``We would be happier if the U.S. government tells us we can have them (the documents) in the foreseeable future,'' said Henning Horstmann, a spokesman for the West German Embassy in Washington. ``It is a part of German history.'' West Germany's parliament, the Bundestag, passed a resolution last year calling for the center to be turned over as soon as possible. The resolution was given impetus in recent weeks by the moves underway to unify East and West Germany. Talks began Wednesday in Bonn among the two Germanys and the four Allied powers with residual control of Berlin _ the United States, the Soviet Union, France and England _ about the unification process. A unified Germany could result in the withdrawal of the U.S. presence from Berlin, leaving the fate of the documentation center uncertain. The United States has agreed in principle to hand over the center to the Germans, but only once the original documents have all been copied on microfilm, said a State Department official who spoke on the condition of anonymity. The copies would be brought to the United States. That process, begun several years ago, could be completed by 1994, the official said. But the West Germans want the archives much sooner than that, said another official, who also asked not to be named. The World Jewish Congress announced it would start a drive in Congress to prevent the State Department from handing over the originals. ``This would be a catastrophe if it happened,'' said Kalman Sultanik, vice president of the organization. ``These documents are irreplaceable. Copies can't substitute for originals,'' he said. The center, which houses such items as membership cards in the Nazi party and dossiers on members of Adolf Hitler's elite SS units, has been used extensively over the years to prepare prosecution cases against suspected Nazi criminals in West Germany and elsewhere in the world. It also serves thousands of scholars of the Nazi era. The Justice Department's Office of Special Investigations, which makes heavy use of the center to prepare cases against suspected Nazis, opposes turning over the documents, sources said. The OSI cannot rely on microfilmed documents because it often needs the originals to authenticate copies in court, said the sources. Even if West Germany guarantees access to the documents, the OSI is worried that that process could mean bureaucratic hassles and delays, the sources said. When the United States handed original documents to Austria in 1955, which included files on Austrian members of the Nazi party and dossiers on their activities, the records disappeared, the sources said. Austria said the documents were lost but U.S. officials believe they were destroyed. The disappearance came to light during the 1986 investigation of the Nazi past of Austrian President Kurt Waldheim. In 1987, Waldheim was barred from entering the United States because of his alleged involvement in the persecution of Jews and Allied prisoners of war.

DOC.HEAD: Twisters in Texas, Kansas, Heat Wave Elsewhere: Make Way For Spring
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to recast and update with Texas tornadoes today, Kansas barricades and disaster declarations, picking up at 8th graf previous, ``Wind flattened.''
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos KO8, GR1
DOC.TEXT: More tornadoes struck today in Texas, a day after swarms of tornadoes veered across the Plains and smashed farmhouses while the East had a second day of a winter heat wave. Thunderstorms brought flood warnings today to Oklahoma, Texas, Illinois, Iowa and Wisconsin. Four to 5 feet of water stood in an Interstate 43 underpass on Milwaukee's north side. ``We're on alert,'' said Milwaukee County emergency director Lev F. Baldwin. ``Let's face it, there could be some worse problems today. Rivers and creek beds are all swollen. And if we get this additional rain we could have some more flooding.'' Snow was the problem today in Wyoming. Ground blizzards stirred up by wind gusting to 50 mph forced the Wyoming Highway Patrol to close a 45-mile stretch of Interstate 80 between Cheyenne and Laramie. Several jackknifed trucks also contributed to the closure. At least two tornadoes caused an undetermined amount of damage today in central Texas, while wind of more than 50 mph blew over trailers and highway signs and downed power lines across northern parts of the state. No injuries were immediately reported from a twister which hit the small community of Mitchell, Texas, south of Hillsboro. Authorities said another tornado flipped over a mobile home, uprooted trees and toppled power poles near Belton, Texas. ``We have fire trucks en route. There is damage _ to what extent I do not know,'' said Joe Creamer, a Hill County sheriff's dispatcher. On Tuesday, tornadoes touched down in Kansas, Nebraska, Iowa, Oklahoma and Texas. At least two people were killed, 29 injured and scores of houses wrecked. ``The damage is about twice of what we thought it was last night,'' Civil Defense worker Leo Zadina said today of tornado damage in Lawrence, Neb. He estimated more than 50 houses were damaged in the town of about 350 people. One tornado ripped a 100-mile path in a 2{-hour tear through southeastern Kansas. It lingered in Hesston, Kan., a town of 3,000 people, long enough to damage 75 to 100 houses. A 6-year-old boy died. A mother and her teen-age son, originally listed as missing, were found safe. Extensive damage prompted authorities to cordon off the town of 4,000, barricading all roads and guarding heavily damaged residential areas and businesses. A Highway Patrol officer stood guard outside the Hesston State Bank, which lost its roof, windows and part of a wall. Kansas Gov. Mike Hayden declared eight counties disaster areas today. Wind flattened several farm buildings in southern Wisconsin. Dan Roeske, a fence company worker who rode out the storm in a metal building about 15 miles south of Madison, said: ``It was like being inside a drum that someone was banging on.'' Walnut-size hail fell at Groom, Texas. Wind blew over a trailer and knocked out power to many residents today at Ennis, about 45 miles south of Dallas. The funnel-spinning warm front brought balmy weather to much of the country east of the Rockies. ``I always feel confused when I feel good in the unusually warm weather we're having nowadays, because I know it's related to the greenhouse effect,'' said Ellen Spiro, a New York video maker. The National Weather Service said the heat came from a high-pressure system pumping Gulf of Mexico air northward. A full week before the first day of spring, summer came to New York City. The high of 85 was 38 degrees above normal and 15 degrees higher than the 1929 record. Lenny and Robin Wayne, tourists from Los Angeles, took a few spins around the Rockefeller Center ice skating rink and left early. ``It's too hot to ice skate,'' Wayne said. ``It makes you want to fall on the ice,'' his wife said. The warmth was expected to last until Thursday, then ``it'll just get a little cooler,'' said meteorologist Robert McElhearn. Michigan hardware stores that were selling rock salt and snow shovels two weeks ago shifted gears Tuesday, as customers started buying fertilizer and seeds. ``But they aren't buying fans yet,'' said Mike Manning, a salesman at Pointe Hardware store in Grosse Pointe Park. Record highs for the date were registered in Atlantic City, N.J., where it was 86; Baltimore 85; Charlotte, N.C., 86; Chicago 71; Cleveland, 76; Concord, N.H., 69; Detroit 73; Indianapolis 75; Montgomery, Ala., 85; Norfolk, Va., 84; Philadelphia 84; Providence, R.I., 77; Raleigh-Durham, N.C. 88; Richmond, Va., 89; Rochester, Minn., 63; and Washington, D.C., 87. In Hesston, the 6-year-old who died was one of seven people huddled in a basement when the chimney and fireplace crashed through. The boy's 12-year-old brother was injured. The same tornado killed an elderly woman near Goessel, Kan., 10 miles from Hesston, and damaged 19 farmhouses in surrounding Marion County, said Sheriff Ed Davies. Twenty-five National Guardsman were called out Tuesday night to prevent looting in Hesston, said city administrator Jay Wieland. The guardsmen or replacements may be used in the cleanup today, he said. At a church in the north Texas town of Elbert, officials monitoring the gubernatorial primary vote took a breather Tuesday to watch a tornado. ``We just stood in the rain ad watched it go by,'' said election judge Bernard Gilmore. The twister caused no major damage. At least nine Iowa counties were visited by twisters, including one that destroyed a firehouse, 10 homes and three businesses in Worthington, near Dubuque. Fifty residents were given shelter by the Red Cross. Tornadoes wrecked part of Lawrence, Neb., injuring three people, and derailed 24 empty Burlington Northern Railroad cars near Grand Island. Authorities declared a disaster area at Sutton, Neb., after a twister ruptured a tank of dangerous anhydrous ammonia. Meanwhile, up to 8 inches of snow fell late Tuesday in the Nebraska Panhandle. Snow also blanketed parts of Montana, Idaho, Arizona and Colorado.

DOC.HEAD: Preliminary Round of Six-Nation Unification Talks Begins in Bonn
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with delegates agreeing to invite Poland to border talks. Pickup 4th graf, `The one-day...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-EGermany-Campaign, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The two Germanys and the four World War II Allies formally agreed today to invite Poland to talks on German unification when that country's western border is discussed. The decision came a day after West Germany said Poland, which is concerned about possible German designs on its territory, could join discussions on a united Germany's borders. The first formal talks on German unification between the six nations lasted about seven hours. Officials from the two Germanys and the Soviet Union, the United States, Britain and France held the one-day talks to lay groundwork for future discussions on unification, which faces enormous complexities. Dieter Kastrup, head of the West German delegation, said the officials had agreed Poland should be included during some parts of the talks. ``The participants agreed that Poland should be invited as soon as questions are discussed that especially concern its border,'' Kastrup said. The one-day talks are part of the ``two-plus-four'' formula of unification discussions agreed on last month in Ottawa. There has not been any announcement on the timing or place of the next round. Today's discussions were expected to be mainly procedural. East Germany is holding its first free elections on Sunday, and there is uncertainty about who will represent it at the next round of talks. After their morning talks, the delegates began a meeting with West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher.
