Eighteen officials from the six nations began the meeting at an enormous round table inside the West German Foreign Ministry. No opening statement was made to reporters. West German TV said the officials would discuss alternating the sites of the next meetings in the capitals of the ``participating countries.'' The television gave no details. The chief East German delegate, Deputy Foreign Minister Ernst Krabatsch, made a few comments to journalists as he was sitting at the table. He reiterated that East Germany favors the participation of all concerned nations in unification talks at some level. ``We've always favored ... including neighboring countries, all interested countries, including Poland,'' he said. On Tuesday, West Germany said Poland could take part in discussions on a united Germany's borders, but it remained unclear whether that meant Poland would actually have a voice in the six-power talks or whether it would be involved in discussions in some other way. Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany heightened international jitters by at first refusing to state unequivocally that a united Germany would not claim lands ceded to Poland after the Third Reich's defeat in 1945. He has since said a united Germany must sign a border treaty with Poland, but the Poles are not satisfied with his stated position. Kohl has come under intense international scrutiny for trying to push unification at a pace that has worried the Soviets as well as some of West Germany's close friends and neighbors. During the past few days, Kohl has launched a campaign aimed at soothing any bad feelings his handling of the unification process may have created, vowing unity will not occur behind other nations' backs. Volker Ruehe, general secretary of Kohl's Christian Democratic Union, told reporters Tuesday that unification cannot be completed ``as long as the external questions ... are not settled.'' Ruehe said unification would likely come ``in steps'' under Article 23 of West Germany's constitution, which allows for East German states to decide to join with their western neighbor. He also said all-German elections would not be likely until next year some time, at the earliest. Ruehe said that because of enormous complexities, the unification process may require three or more years to complete. Also Tuesday, officials of Kohl's party said it favors drastic cutbacks on social benefits for East Germans who move to West Germany in the future. More than 130,000 East Germans have resettled in West Germany this year alone, joining 344,000 who arrived last year. Christian Democratic officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said it is possible they may have to face shortened benefits for a certain period of time. West Germany's opposition Social Democrats have already urged that benefits be curtailed for the resettlers as a means of discouraging them from leaving their homeland, but up until now Kohl had opposed such an idea.

DOC.HEAD: Historic East German Elections Setting Tone for Unification Pace
DOC.TEXT: Forged by the pro-democracy movements that shook the Soviet bloc last year, East Germany's historic weekend elections will help set the pace of reunification with West Germany. What started with thousands of pro-democracy activists taking to the streets of Leipzig in September has led to Sunday's nationwide balloting for a 400-member Parliament. Voters in the nation's first free elections are being presented with a dizzying array of 24 slates of candidates, ranging from conservatives to radical leftists. In one region, the new Beer Drinkers' Party is running candidates. The once-hardline Communists, struggling for a strong opposition role, have changed their name, lightened their image and tried to wipe out the memories of the regime that killed would-be escapees and crushed dissent. But polls show the Communists with 18 percent support or less, despite the popularity of Communist Premier Hans Modrow. ``Now we're out in the open dueling with swords,'' said Jens Reich, a co-founder of the New Forum opposition movement that led the fall protests. ``Before it was a slaughter with clubs behind closed doors.'' ``What we have accomplished is a more open, democratic process,'' said Reich, the top candidate for New Forum. ``This process cannot be reversed.'' Very few East Germans have tasted true democratic government. Forty years of iron-fisted Communist rule replaced the Nazi dictatorship, which followed the chaos of the Weimar Republic. Soon after the Berlin Wall was opened Nov. 9, the Leipzig protesters again took the lead, this time with tens of thousands chanting ``Germany United Fatherland'' and waving West German flags. Almost overnight, the West German conservatives' dream of reunification loomed as a reality for Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Both Kohl and his detente-minded foreign minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, now routinely attract huge crowds at East German election rallies. ``God bless our German fatherland,'' Kohl says at the end of each of his campaign speeches, drawing wild cheers. International concerns over West Germany's possible claims to part of Poland may slow down the reunification process. But another main signal will come from the ballots cast by the 12.3 million eligible voters. Virtually everyone in East Germany agrees that historical forces, a common language and the ties of kinship make German reunification inevitable. The issue sets the changes in East Germany apart from those in Hungary, Czechoslovakia and other parts of Eastern Europe that have undergone pro-democracy movements. Now, the main question is ``when,'' made even more pressing by the continuing exodus of East Germans to the West. Communist leader Gregor Gysi, an affable, 42-year-old lawyer, is trying to block the leftist Social Democrats and the conservatives from getting a two-thirds majority coalition. That would allow them to vote for quick reunification. Polls suggest that such a broad-based majority is a possibility. Gysi has been stumping nationwide _ at one point jumping from an airplane in a skydiving stunt _ as he attempts to drum up votes and support for slowing reunification. The Communists insist that moving too quickly would mean the end of the socialist system's cradle-to-grave safety net that for 40 years guaranteed jobs, a place to live and other benefits. At a rally Tuesday night in the southeastern town of Freiberg, Gysi said quick reunification would mean ``the loss of many of the rights of our citizens, such as property rights, women's rights, rights of young people and others, things that most people take for granted now.'' The party repeatedly has urged against a ``sellout'' to the West. But already contracts worth billions of dollars have been signed between the two German states, though that's only a small fraction of what is expected to come. ``The big fish that's never satisfied wants to swallow the little fish,'' said West Germany's Der Spiegel magazine in its latest issue. At the same time, even East Germany's Social Democrats are starting to snipe at Kohl's handling of the reunification issue. Kohl heightened international concerns by at first refusing to state unequivocally a united Germany would not claim lands given to Poland after the Third Reich's defeat in 1945. He now says a united Germany must sign a border treaty with Poland, but the Poles are still not satisfied with his stated position. In addition, many Europeans fear that Kohl is allowing the unification process to distract him from plans for tighter European integration. ``Life punishes whoever goes over to Kohl,'' said Ibrahim Boehme, chief of the Social Democrats. It was a play on words from a Russian proverb used by Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev in October, when he tried to urge East Germany's hard-line leader to make political and economic changes. ``Life punishes whoever comes late,'' Gorbachev told Erich Honecker in his unsuccessful attempt to push reforms. Less than two weeks later, the 77-year-old Honecker was ousted and now faces indictment for high treason. ``The chances for survival (of East Germany) are very small,'' said Guenther Buch, a leading West German government expert who keeps track of East Germany. Buch added in an interview with The Associated Press: ``There is only one reason to have this election, and this is to legitimize the government so that a decision can be made on unification. Modrow's government wasn't legitimate.''

DOC.HEAD: Militia Battles in Area Where Hostages Believed Held
DOC.TEXT: Iran's Shiite Moslem militia allies battled with rival fighters in the slums of south Beirut on Wednesday, close to where the Western hostages are believed held. Police said three people were killed before Syrian soldiers broke up the battle. The fighting lasted five hours between the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, and the mainstream Shiite Amal militia in the slums of Shiyah, Ouzai and Bir Hasan. The three densely populated districts are a few blocks west of Hezbollah's Hajjaj and Hay Madi barracks, where most of the 18 Western hostages are believed held by Hezbollah-affiliated kidnappers. A police spokesman, who cannot be named in line with regulations, said Syrian troops moved in and disengaged the combatants in the afternoon. ``The Syrian Arab forces are moving in! We have shoot-to-kill orders! Any fighter spotted will be shot at!'' shouted a Syrian captain as he walked down Ouzai's main street, which separates Amal and Hezbollah fighters. Syria has about 40,000 soldiers in Lebanon. They were deployed in 1976 under a mandate to quell civil war fighting. The combatants did not shoot at the Syrian captain, who was followed by about 50 heavily armed soldiers advancing slowly along both sides of the street, police said. The thuds of exploding rocket propelled grenades and bursts of machine gun fire, accompanied by the wailing of ambulance sirens, echoed across west Beirut before the Syrians moved in. Fighters of Hezbollah and the Syrian-backed Amal, Arabic for hope, remained on maximum alert in their respective areas of influence throughout west and south Beirut, as well as south Lebanon and the eastern Bekaa valley. Witnesses said the rival militias stocked up on ammunition and weapons. The two factions have been fighting on-and-off for more than two years for control of the 1.2 million Shiites, the largest community among Lebanon's 17 sects. The latest battles erupted Tuesday. Most schools in west Beirut suspended classes Thursday amid fears fighting would flare again. Hundreds of worried parents rushed to schools shortly after the 8:30 a.m. outbreak of clashes and brought their children home. Meanwhile, Former President Jimmy Carter arrived in Syria on Wednesday and said he expected to discuss the plight of foreign hostages in Lebanon when he meets with President Hafez Assad this week. ``It's obvious to me that the Syrian leaders are very eager to see the hostage question solved and so see the hostages released,'' Carter told reporters on arrival at Damascus international airport. Syria is the main power broker in Lebanon, but most of the hostages are believed to be held by groups influenced by Iran and often at odds with Syria. The hostage held longest is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. In the eastern part of Beirut, rival Christian forces exchanged sniper fire Wednesday, and one person was killed, police said. That raised the toll in east Beirut since Jan. 30 to 758 killed and 2,107 wounded. The casualties have resulted from clashes between renegade Gen. Michel Aoun's troops and Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militiamen. The factions are fighting each other for control of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave.

DOC.HEAD: Economy Continues Slow Growth
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. economy continues to grow slowly, although there is widespread weakness in the automobile industry, the Federal Reserve said Wednesday in its latest survey of economic activity across the country. ``Most Federal Reserve districts describe economic activity as expanding slowly,'' the central bank survey found. ``Consumer spending varies from moderate to strong, except for auto sales, which have slowed after a January rebound. ``The manufacturing sector is soft, but is improving in some districts,'' the report said, noting that the Boston, Philadelphia and St. Louis district banks reported declines. ``The weakness in autos and auto-related industries, however, is widespread,'' according to a summary of the study. However, it found auto dealer inventories improved after sales incentives were restored in January. The survey was prepared by the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago based on information gathered before March 6. The survey found sluggish construction activity in most districts except Chicago and San Francisco, which reported relatively strong activity. It said agricultural conditions were generally good, although concern over lack of soil moisture was expressed in the Midwest and West. Actual drought damage was reported in the Dallas district. ``Freeze damage to fruits and vegetables caused some problems in the Atlanta and Dallas districts,'' it said, with Atlanta reporting that citrus prices are likely to remain high throughout 1990. The Dallas district also reported that ``it may be two years before marketable citrus can again be produced in the Rio Grande Valley of Texas.'' Other natural resource-related industries, such as forestry products, mining and oil and gas drilling, were reported to be ``generally very strong.'' ``Banks have become less aggressive in making new loans, and demand for most types of loans has softened,'' the summary said. ``Most districts report that financial institutions are either less willing to extend credit or actually tightening credit terms.'' But the report did not mention any inflationary problems that prompted the Federal Open Market Committee to tighten credit a year ago. The move drove up interest rates and slowed the economy. Interest rates have edged down gradually since last summer. The Fed survey is conducted eight times a year in preparation for meetings of the FOMC, the Fed's monetary policy-setting arm. The next meeting is March 27.

DOC.HEAD: Reformer Chosen New Party Leader of Mongolia
DOC.TEXT: Mongolia's ruling Communist party agreed Thursday to give up its monopoly on power and selected its youngest leadership in years, including a reformer to head the party. The party _ which has ruled Mongolia for 66 years _ met virtually all the demands made by newly formed opposition parties in recent weeks. The opposition groups' protests since January led to the special Central Committee meeting, which opened Monday and ended early Thursday. The Central Committee of the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party named 61-year-old Gombojavyn Ochirbat its new general secretary and chose an entirely new five-man Politburo. ``This is the beginning of real change,'' said Foreign Minstry spokesman Tepbishiin Chimeddorj. Former party leader Jambyn Batmonh remains Mongolian president even though he lost his party job. In another dramatic repudiation of its past, the policy-making Central Committee voted to expel former party leader Yumjaagiyn Tsedenbal from the party. Tsedenbal, 73, presided over purges of the party during his 31 years in power that ended in 1984. He now lives in Moscow. Ochirbat spent the last two years as party representative to the World Marxist Review based in Prague, Czechoslovakia. He had been a member of the Central Committee but had not played an active role in Mongolian politics for the past two years. He returned to Mongolia in the past few days when he was invited to attend the committee meeting. Ochirbat had been head of the Mongolian trade unions in the early 1980s, but was ousted in 1982 and indirectly criticized by the Central Committee under Tsedenbal. It offered no specific public criticism. A government official speaking on condition of anonymity characterized Ochirbat as a reformer and indicated he was not closely linked to Batmonh. The Central Committee proposed an extraordinary party conference on April 10 that will select a new Central Committee. Most elderly members of the current Central Committee offered their resignations. More than half of the committee's 174 full and non-voting members are 60 years old or more. Besides Ochirbat, the other four members of the new Politburo all are reform-minded and less than 50 years old, giving the party its youngest leadership in years. The new leaders include L. Tudev, director of the party newspaper Unen and chairman of the Mongolian Union of Journalists; Foreign Minister Ts. Gombosuren; M. Michigdorg; and Ts. Oold, chairman of the party's Control Commission. It was not immediately clear whether the new Politburo would serve after the party congress. The new Central Committee elected by the Congress has the right to choose a new Politburo. Party leaders also have agreed to hold early elections this year for a new legislature. Oppostion groups want elections this summer, but no date has been set. Elections originally were scheduled for 1991. Chimeddorj said many Central Committee members criticized themselves during the meeting for having failed earlier to reform the country's centralized economic and Stalinist system of government. The policy-making body voted to rehabilitate all party leaders purged from 1962 to 1964 on charges of being against the party. The number of people affected was not immediately known. The party already has begun the work of rehabilitating those purged from the 1930s to 1950s under Tsedenbal and his predecessor, Marshal Horloogiyn Choybalsan. Meanwhile, government leaders held a third meeting with representatives of opposition groups. Opposition participants said later they agreed to set up a new commission to rewrite the constitution, with one representative each from the ruling party and four major opposition groups.

DOC.HEAD: Border Guards Attacked, Three Killed
DOC.TEXT: A platoon of border guards was attacked Wednesday from across the frontier with India, and at least three soldiers were killed, officials said. The officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said a group of border guards on routine patrol in the southeastern Rangmati district were fired at by ``uniformed personnel'' from Indian territory. The officials said at least three soldiers were killed and ``several others'' wounded. They spoke on telephone from the town of Rangmati, 135 miles southeast of Dhaka. Government officials in New Delhi, the Indian capital, said they had not received information about the incident.

DOC.HEAD: Commercial Rocket Launched; Lack of Satellite Signal Raises Concern
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with industry sources saying satellite was not deployed as company had said. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `We think...'.
DOC.TEXT: Martin Marietta Corp. today launched a powerful commercial rocket to boost a $140 million communications satellite into orbit, but the uninsured satellite did not immediately signal that it was working. The big Titan 3 blasted off at 6:52 a.m. EST into a cloudy sky from the Cape Canaveral Air Force Station. Intelsat, the international communications company, hoped for confirmation the satellite was working on its third expected pass over a tracking station on Hawaii, at about 11 a.m., but no signal was confirmed, said Don O'Neal, a spokesman for Hughes Aircraft Co., which built the satellite. At midday, the Washington, D.C.-based Intelsat issued a brief statement saying that the satellite ``is encountering difficulties,'' adding that company officials hoped to have more information later. The North American Aerospace Command in Colorado, which tracks objects in space, said it was asked by Martin Marietta to locate the satellite. The satellite separated from the rocket 25 minutes after launch, said Judy Stowell, a Martin Marietta spokeswoman. But satellite industry sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the separation had not occurred. ``We think we did a very good and a very accurate job,'' said Edward M. Browne, president of Martin Marietta Commercial Titan Inc. But no data was received from the satellite when it passed over Hawaii. At midmorning, Hughes said it also was not clear if an on-board rocket motor fired to send the satellite into a higher orbit. That should have occurred before the satellite sent its first signals back to Earth. ``I don't know where the problem is at this point, but I can say we've not gotten a firm signal yet,'' said O'Neal. ``It has happened in the past, but it is unusual.'' He was not certain whether the problem was on the ground or on the satellite. The commercial launch of the Intelsat VI satellite, owned by a not-for-profit, international consortium, is the fourth by an American company. The 5-ton satellite, nearly four stories tall with its antennas and solar panels deployed, was intended to transmit up to 120,000 telephone calls and three television channels for more than 13 years. The satellite was to replace two older satellites over the Atlantic Ocean. It was scheduled to reach final orbit 22,300 miles above Earth on Sunday, and then was to undergo tests before being placed in service in late May. The first Intelsat VI, launched in October by the European Space Agency's Ariane rocket, is being tested in orbit and will be placed in service April 7. Frederick Ormsby, spacecraft mission director for the International Telecommunications Satellite Organization, or Intelsat, said last month's explosion of an Ariane rocket should not affect plans to launch two more Intelsat VI satellites on Ariane boosters next year. The unmanned Ariane rocket carrying two Japanese communications satellites blew apart over the Atlantic shortly after taking off from Kourou, French Guiana. The accident prompted Arianespace, which runs the program, to suspend all Ariane launches pending an investigation. Intelsat did not insure the satellite launched today, Ormsby said, because the Ariane explosion put already high insurance prices out of range. The launch and satellite together cost an estimated $270 million. Intelsat, a Washington, D.C.-based commercial cooperative of 118 member nations, owns and operates a global communications satellite system used by more than 170 countries. Today's launch is its 44th. The first Intelsat communications satellite was launched 25 years ago next month. The Titan 3, built at Martin Marietta's Denver plant, is the most powerful U.S. commercial rocket. Martin Marietta's first commercial launch of the Titan 3 on Dec. 31 propelled British and Japanese communications satellites into orbit. McDonnell Douglas launched the first U.S. commercial rocket, the Delta, which took a British Satellite Broadcasting satellite into orbit last August. General Dynamics plans to enter the competition in June with its Atlas rocket.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Meet with Thatcher, Mitterrand
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to include Mitterrand meeting
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will meet separately next month with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and French President Francois Mitterrand to discuss issues facing NATO, the White House announced today. Bush will meet with Mrs. Thatacher in Bermuda on April 13 and with Mitterrand in Florida on April 19. ``As the year unfolds, the president will continue to consult closely with his counterparts in the Atlantic community on the historic changes in Europe,'' presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said in a statement. After Bush and Mrs. Thatcher hold their informal meeting in the British colony, the president will spend the night on the island, returning to Washington on April 14. Bush met with Mrs. Thatcher in London last year and again in 1989 when she visited him at Camp David, the presidential retreat in Maryland's Catoctin Mountains. ``The president and the prime minister will discuss a wide range of issues related to events in Eastern Europe, NATO and bilateral relations,'' a White House statement said. In London, a spokeswoman for Mrs. Thatcher said she was due to meet Bush in July but the April meeting was set up ``by mutual agreement because of the pace of world events.'' Mrs. Thatcher will spend two nights on the island, a self-governing British colony, the spokeswoman added, speaking on condition of anonymity. Mitterrand and Bush met last December on the French Carribbean island of St. Martin. The president also invited Mitterrand to his oceanside home in Kennebunkport, Maine, last May and the two met during last July's seven-nation economic summit in Paris. White House aides said the session with Mitterrand would take place in South Florida, but an exact location has not yet been detrmined. Bush had been scheduled to be in Islamorada, in the Florida Keys, on April 20.

DOC.HEAD: Policeman Sentenced For Beating Demonstrator
DOC.TEXT: A police officer was convicted and sentenced to 4{ years in prison Wednesday for his part in the bloody crackdown on dissent that began the uprising against Communist rule, news reports said. First Lt. Jaroslav Oudran was the first of 25 police officers to be tried for assaulting demonstrators in Prague. On Nov. 17, 1989, riot police in the city brutally dispersed tens of thousands of people marking the 50th anniversary of the death of Jan Opletal, a student who died while protesting the Nazi occupation of Czechoslovakia in 1939. The crackdown triggered protests that eventually swept the hard-line leadership of Milos Jakes from power and ended four decades of Communist rule. Playwright and one-time dissident Vaclav Havel was later elected president. Oudran was accused of beating an onlooker, Katerina Vavrova, 29, causing brain a contusion and neck injury and making her unfit to work for three months. Oudran pleaded guilty of ``abuse of power of an official,'' CTK said. The crime is punishable by up to 10 years in prison. Oudran was convicted and sentenced by the court in Terezin, 40 miles north of Prague, the news agency said. Both the prosecution and defense said they had not decided whether to appeal the verdict. ``I have pronounced a sentence approximately identical to the one demanded by the prosecution, and I am of the opinion it is a just verdict,'' Judge Miroslav Janzura told CTK. During the trial, Oudran repeatedly expressed regret over his actions, claiming he was in severe emotional distress. According to the prosecution, Oudran took Ms. Vavrova by the hair and beat her head against a pillar four times before she fell to the ground. Then he allegedly kicked her in the hip. ``Mr. Oudran apologized to me and expressed sincere regret. I have accepted his apology, because I no longer feel anger or need for revenge ... I consider the sentence appropriate,'' Ms. Vavrova told CTK after the sentencing. According to the government, 590 people were injured during the crackdown, including dozens of foreign journalists. Miroslav Stepan, Prague Communist Party boss at the time of the demostration, was arrested Dec. 23 in connection with the police actions and is being held pending trial. Stepan is the only civilian in custody in connection with the Nov. 17 events. It was not immediately clear when the 24 other police officers charged would be tried.

DOC.HEAD: Bid to Streamline Appeals Needs Work, Judiciary Panel Says
DOC.TEXT: A proposal to streamline death penalty appeals should be changed to provide greater legal protection for people accused or convicted of murder, the federal judiciary's policy-making arm recommended Wednesday. The 27-member Judicial Conference of the United States proposed modifying a plan by a committee appointed by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and headed by retired Supreme Court Justice Lewis F. Powell. The conference proposals, which will be submitted to Congress, are aimed at assuring competent legal help for all defendants who face the death penalty _ from the initial trial through successive rounds of appeals. The conference adopted the report at a private meeting Tuesday; the results were announced Wednesday. David Sellers, a spokesman for the conference, said the judges were divided over the issue. He declined to reveal the vote. The announcement was hailed by civil libertarians who have attacked the the Rehnquist committee's plan. Leslie Harris of the American Civil Liberties Union said the proposed changes were ``a stunning departure'' that could go a long way toward protecting the rights of defendants in capital punishment cases. The judicial conference urged that any state choosing to adopt the streamlined procedures must adhere to a proposed national standard for determining which lawyers are qualified to represent defendants in capital cases. The judges endorsed a proposal by the American Bar Association, which recommended softening the impact of the Rehnquist committee's plan. The judges, whose views are expected to carry considerable weight in Congress, also proposed changing the plan to make it easier for death row inmates to file repeated appeals challenging their death sentences. The Rehnquist committee proposed that states limit death row inmates to two rounds of appeals in state and federal courts. One round would challenge a verdict directly; a second would be based on alleged violations of the condemned individual's rights. If the plan is approved by Congress, states that decide to go along would be required to assure legal help to death row inmates at taxpayer expense throughout the appeals process. That is not the case now. The ACLU and other groups that attacked the original plan said its promise of more legal help for death row inmates is an empty one because it offers no assurance that state-appointed lawyers will be competent. There are more than 2,200 convicted murderers on death rows nationwide. Only 121 executions have occurred since the Supreme Court reinstated capital punishment in 1976. The average delay between conviction and execution is more than eight years. The judicial conference also announced it is giving news organizations more time to present their views on letting television cameras into federal courtrooms. The conference will postpone until September its report on televising federal court proceedings. ``Basically, the door is still open on this issue,'' Sellers said. The conference has opposed such televised coverage.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Targets Base Construction Money to Help Fund Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is targeting planned construction at several military bases slated for closing or realignment to help finance a $300 million aid package for Nicaragua. The letter detailing the proposed sources for the assistance caused consternation Wednesday among lawmakers who complained in January when Defense Secretary Dick Cheney announced his candidates for closure that the list was partisan. Cheney recommended closing or scaling back more than 72 domestic facilities and 14 overseas installations, but faces an uphill fight trying to persuade Congress to accept that list. Complicating the situation is the administration's decision to include several of those facilities on its list of possible sources for Nicaraguan aid. The list was sent to members of Congress this week; The Associated Press obtained a copy Wednesday. A total of $31 million would come from canceling or delaying work on an automated record fire range at Fort Ord, Calif.; the Porter River road bridge and physical fitness training center at Fort Knox, Ky.; and barracks modernization, battalion headquarters and a vehicle wash facility at Fort Hood, Texas. Savings from canceling plans to build a hazardous and flammable storehouse at the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard would total $10 million. Rep. Thomas Foglietta, D-Pa., complained to Pentagon officials that the Congress included money for the warehouse in last year's budget, and questioned whether officials ``cared about safety.'' David Berteau, a deputy assistant secretary of defense for production and logistics, told the House Armed Services subcommittee on military installations and facilities that the shipyard is part of the proposed list for closure. ``This is based in part on a force structure reduction,'' Berteau said. Pentagon officials believe studying ``candidates is the right way to go.'' The president's list to help finance aid to the Central American nation also includes $11 million that had been slated for repair of the No. 2 gun turret aboard the USS Iowa. The turret was destroyed in the April 19 explosion that killed 47 sailors.

DOC.HEAD: More Taxpayers Designating $1 for Campaign Fund
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 25 percent of taxpayers are designating $1 of their federal taxes this year for the presidential campaign fund, the Internal Revenue Service said Wednesday. That's up from last year, when about 20 percent used a checkoff box on their returns to earmark $1 _ or $2 in the case of a couple _ for the fund. The $32 million designated in 1989 raised the total collected since the fund was created in 1972 to $567 million. Earmarking the $1 does not reduce a refund or increase a taxpayer's liability. The IRS said that through Friday, it had received 44.8 million returns and processed 33 million. Filings are up 3.5 percent from a year ago and processing is 12.5 percent ahead of last year's pace. Nearly 3.3 million couples and individuals have filed their returns electronically this year, compared with 861,916 during the same period a year ago. This is the first year that electronic filing, in which returns are sent via computer by businesses certified by the IRS, is available in every state. Only returns due a refund are eligible for electronic filing. Through Saturday, the IRS had certified 21.5 million refunds, up 16.7 percent from last year, totaling $18.3 billion, up 20.3 percent. This year's average refund is $852, compared with $827 a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Tom Cruise, who got stopped for speeding while in town to film a movie on car racing, was allowed to plead guilty to a lesser charge and pay a decreased fine. City officials even discussed dropping the charge against the 27-year-old actor, but decided not to in fear of adverse publicity, Mayor Ronnie Ward said. Cruise was charged with driving 66 mph in a 35 mph zone on March 2. He could have paid as much as $237 in fines and fees and had six points lodged against his South Carolina driving record. Instead, he paid a $125 fine Monday after City Judge Dan Causey reduced the charge to careless operation of a vehicle, which carries no point penalty. Cruise was able to pay the fine before his case came up in court, and not miss any time filming ``Days of Thunder'' at Darlington International Raceway. Ward called the plea bargain ``sort of a happy medium.'' He said Cruise was not driving drunk or recklessly, but ``you don't want him to get off scot-free.''

Jay Leno was too busy to write back to an elementary school pupil doing a report on comedy _ so the comedian called. Zachary Hoover, 10, a fifth-grader at Brentwood Elementary, wrote to Leno, well known as a substitute host on ``The Tonight Show,'' with some questions. A teacher discouraged Zachary from writing, saying Leno would be too busy to respond. He called March 1. ``It was pretty amazing,'' said Zachary's mother, Janet Hoover. ``When you think that a kid admires someone famous and that person takes a personal interest in the kid ... Zach's bouncing off the walls, he's so excited.'' The family met Leno at Indianapolis International Airport March 2 as the comedian passed through the city on the way to a show in Fort Wayne. Zachary got the comedian's autograph and the family took pictures. A spokesman for Leno in Los Angeles says the comedian ``does this sort of thing all the time. He and his special assistant go through his fan mail and if there's a request that touches him in some way he will call. That's Jay's style.'' Zachary had not gotten his grade yet Wednesday on the comedy report.

Former ``Partridge Family'' star Danny Bonaduce said he felt suicidal when his drug arrest in Florida made national news. Bonaduce, 31, was arrested last weekend for allegedly buying crack in Daytona Beach, Fla. The actor who played Danny Partridge on ``The Partridge Family'' sit-com from 1970-74 feared losing his job as a disc jockey for WEGX-FM, known as Eagle 106. ``I was totally suicidal. I was having heart attacks about being fired. I couldn't believe I hurt the Eagle,'' Bonaduce said. He managed to keep his sense of humor, though. Bonaduce told The Philadelphia Inquirer he called his girlfriend and told her, ``I'm going to blow my brains out, but this is my favorite shirt.'' Station manager Dave Noll suspended Bonaduce from his $75,000-a-year job, but agreed to company-paid drug treatment and weekly drug testing that could lead to his return. ``I feel like a monumental fool,'' Bonaduce said. ``Even Carl Sagan couldn't figure out how stupid I am. I screwed up completely. I can barely look at myself. It's all my fault. I don't even know why. To anyone who believed the Danny Partridge myth, I'm sorry.''

Expenses such as theater and equipment rental ate up more than three-fourths of the $141,000 proceeds of a Dionne Warwick AIDS benefit last November, disappointed beneficiaries said. ``I think its unfair to people to say you're doing a fund-raiser for children and trying to appeal to their emotions, and then spend that much money on expenses,'' Judy Lipshutz, who heads United Community Services' AIDS Care Connection in southeast Michigan, said Tuesday. The benefit provided the Dionne Warwick Foundation in Washington, D.C., 45 percent of the proceeds after expenses and Detroit area AIDS groups 55 percent. About $12,000 will go to Warwick foundation, $15,000 to area groups, and the remaining $114,000 to expenses, said Georgella Bascom Muirhead, the city's director of public information.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version moving on some sports circuits.
DOC.TEXT: Olympic silver medalist Linford Christie has been awarded damages from London police for unlawful arrest and libel. ``He's pleased the suit is behind him and he can get on with his life,'' Christie's coach, Ron Roddan, said Wednesday. The award's amount was not disclosed in court documents, but British news reports put it at more than $48,000. Christie was arrested in July 1988 and accused of stealing a rental car that had wrongly been reported missing. Budget Rent-A-Car International had loaned cars to all members of the British team for the 1988 Olympics in Seoul, South Korea. Christie's lawyer, Geoffrey Bindman, told the High Court a police press officer informed a reporter of the arrest three days after the 29-year-old sprinter was sent a letter telling him he was cleared. The athlete, who is black, was quoted as telling The Independent newspaper after Tuesday's court decision that the police action ``was a thing of blatant racism.'' Christie placed second in the 100-meter event in Seoul two months after his arrest and won the gold medal at the Commonwealth Games in Auckland, New Zealand, last month.

DOC.HEAD: Tornado Takes Policewoman for a Ride
With AM-Storms Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A tornado showed one off-duty policewoman a real walk on the wild side. ``All I could think of was this is like the Wizard of Oz,'' Sgt. Paula Shaw said Tuesday after a tornado picked her up and threw her 10 feet as she clung to her pet dog. ``Like Superman,'' Ms. Shaw said. ``It sucked us up, literally sucked us in there, along with tree branches, and mud and leaves. It was incredible.'' Ms. Shaw reported only a few aches and pains Wednesday. The dog also wasn't hurt. Ms. Shaw and her dog had walked outside their home in southeastern Oklahoma City about 6 p.m. Tuesday, at the height of a tornado-riddled thunderstorm, police said. Ms. Shaw never saw what hit her, police said. ``She'd gone out in the back yard to view the storm, to see what was going on,'' said Sgt. Janet Hogue. ``It picked her up and kind of tossed her around with the lawn furniture and stuff.'' ``She just said it felt real weird,'' police spokesman Maj. Bob Taylor said. Ms. Hogue said the rough ride was ``probably the worst thing that ever happened'' to Ms. Shaw, a more than five-year veteran of the police force. ``We all get in minor scuffles, but nothing serious.'' Ms. Shaw picked herself up after her flight, went around to check on neighbors and then radioed for help, Ms. Hogue said. ``She said she wasn't really scared at the time, she was shocked,'' Ms. Hogue said. ``It shook her up a little bit, but she wanted to get to her neighbors. She was concerned about their welfare.''

DOC.HEAD: Senators Criticize Soviets for Denying Visas
DOC.TEXT: Two-thirds of the members of the Senate have sent a letter to Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev, criticizing his government for continuing to deny exit visas to some longtime refuseniks, sponsors said Wednesday. ``In the spirit of the continuing renewal of cooperation between our two countries, we are writing to express our concern about the problem of Soviet citizens who have been refused permission to emigrate,'' the letter said. The letter, dated March 2 and circulated by Sens. Bob Graham, D-Fla., and Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., was signed by 67 senators. The senators said in the letter that they found it ``extremely disturbing'' that many families remain trapped in the Soviet Union. They praised Gorbachev for moving quickly to grant visas to some refuseniks, generally Soviet Jews who were barred from practicing their faith in the Soviet Union. Other, they said, have seen their cases languish. More than 20 people on a list submitted to Gorbachev first applied to leave the Soviet Union more than a decade ago. ``For these people, and for all those arbitrarily denied the right to leave their country, we request your careful attention,'' the letter said. Those who are kept in Soviet Union are often denied visas on the grounds they had access to state secrets at some time. The state secrets law is simply an excuse, the letter said. The senators cited the case of Vladimir Raiz, who first applied to emigrate 25 years ago. Stacy Burdette, a spokeswoman for the Union of Councils for Soviet Jews, a group that presses for looser Soviet emigration policies, said Raiz and his wife, Carmen, were granted exit visas within the last few days. While thousands of Jews have moved to Israel and the United States in recent years, Burdette said there are an estimated 850,000 still trying to leave the country where anti-semitism has flared. About 71,000 people emigrated last year. Moreover, she said President Bush gave Gorbachev a list of 20 people the United States would like to see given permission to leave when the two met at the Malta summit in November. Of those, 17 cases have not been addressed. Burdette said there is legislation pending in the Supreme Soviet that would reform the emigration process and limit to five years the time a person could be blocked by the state secrets act.

DOC.HEAD: Civil Rights Lawsuit Pits Biker Club Against Police
DOC.TEXT: Seventy members of a bikers group are seeking $3 million in damages from a police force they claim violated their rights during a 14-city hunt in 1983 for a biker suspected of stabbing three bar patrons. The Vagos, which was formed in the 1960s to rival the Hells Angels, alleges Hawthorne Police Department used unnecessary force, brandished guns in children's faces and confiscated personal property during raids on 43 homes on Aug. 9 and Sept. 7, 1983. The lawsuit, filed jointly by the American Civil Liberties Union, alleges emotional distress and civil rights violations. The jury trial before Superior Court Judge Maurice Hogan Jr. opened last month, and will hear from nearly 200 witnesses during the next two months, court officials said. Ed ``Fat Eddie'' Serna, who has since retired from the Vagos, testified that his restored 1948 Harley Davidson was confiscated and returned months later with a rusted motor and broken shift rod, the chrome pitted and the paint scratched. ``It was in real bad shape,'' he testified. ``I felt very angry. I worked four years on it and was that close to driving it and it was taken away.'' About 50 police officers from various departments across southern California took part in the hunt for Vagos member Raymond ``South Bay Ray'' Malloy. Some of the homes were occupied by former and current Vagos members, and others by people who said they had never heard of the group. Molloy was not found, and later surrendered. He pleaded guilty to a reduced assault and battery charge and was sentenced to 142 days in jail. Molloy stabbed three men in a bar brawl, but none was seriously injured. The defendants were named as former Hawthorne Police Chief Kenneth R. Stonebraker, three lieutenants, a sergeant and numerous unidentified officers. The ACLU alleges Hawthorne police lied in affidavits to obtain search warrants and harassed the families to make Malloy surrender. Hawthorne police denied the allegations and say they believed the Vagos group was hiding Malloy. ``Vagos were known violent people, and the police were knocking on doors with the expectation of finding Malloy, who had been accused of three vicious stabbings,'' said John Daly, an attorney for the city.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Says No to Request For Foreign Secretary's Visit
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd's request to visit Iraq to ask for mercy on behalf of a journalist condemned to death has been rejected, the government said Wednesday. A Foreign Office spokesman said Hurd asked Britain's ambassador to Iraq to arrange a meeting for him with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. The Foreign Office announced that the Iraqi government responded ``this would not be the right time for a visit.'' ``It was made clear that the Iraqi government did not feel able to discuss these cases in the present atmosphere,'' said the spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity. Iraqi Embassy spokesman Wajdi Mardan said Wednesday that Iraq considered a visit by Hurd ``rather inconvenient in view of the probability that this visit could be seen as part of the current media campaign, which is presumably intended to bring pressure on the Iraqi government.'' Britain has been waging a diplomatic and media campaign seeking clemency for the London-based journalist Farzad Bazoft, who was convicted of espionage by an Iraqi court last week and sentenced to death. Britain is also trying to win clemency for a British nurse sentenced to 15 years in prison for allegedly helping Bazoft. The nurse, Daphne Parish, 52, was charged with driving Bazoft to Iraq's Al-Iskandaria military complex in September where he was investigating reports of an explosion at the complex. Iraq has not set a date for the execution. The Iraqi News Agency reported Tuesday that Hussein said he will not decide whether to commute the death sentence ``while under political and media pressure.'' British officials said the government will continue to campaign for clemency. But they acknowledged privately they faced a problem in striking a balance between keeping up the pressure and creating what one called a ``counterproductive'' reaction in Iraq. A delegation of human rights groups and media unions met with the Iraqi ambassador in London on Wednesday to express their concern over Bazoft's death sentence. Requests for a reduction of the sentences have already been sent by U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, Amnesty International, the European Community and international press groups. Bazoft, a stateless Iranian, has lived in Britain since 1975 and travels on British documents. He is a reporter for The Observer, a British weekly. Mrs. Parish is a senior nursing administrator for an Irish-run hospital in Baghdad.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Wants Role in Study of Veterans Hospitals
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers who last year refused to touch legislation that would have led to an outside study of the veterans' health care system were ready Wednesday to tell the Department of Veterans Affairs how to run a similar internal study. ``Congress must also play a role in the future of the VA health care system,'' Rep. G.V. Montgomery, D-Miss., said at a hearing of the Veterans Affairs subcommittee on hospitals and health care. ``After all, the legislative branch is the policy making body,'' said Montgomery, chairman of the full committee and the subcommittee. Montgomery last summer rejected a proposal by Veterans Secretary Edward J. Derwinski for legislation that would have created an outside review commission to study the department's health care network. Montgomery said at the time that Congress was ``not in the mood'' for such a commission, which was proposed as lawmakers were considering recommendations from a commission to close military bases. Derwinski, acknowledging the poor political timing of the legislative proposal, last January said he would appoint his own commission. Derwinski pledged Wednesday that the commission he was proposcing would be independent and he had no intention of recommending that facilities be closed. Still, VA facilities could undergo important changes in a status-conscious health care industry. For example, only one facility in a group could offer open-heart surgery, or some hospitals could be converted to clinics or long-term care facilities. The department operates 172 medical centers as well as 233 outpatient clinics. Derwinski said the system has not been examined in 25 years. Six medical centers were closed as a result of the last study. Veterans groups expressed concern at Wednesday's hearing that the proposed study would be used to cut back on health care. ``All too often in the past, when there was talk of re-examining the VA's mission, reducing services was the hidden agenda,'' said Dennis M. Cullinan of the Veterans of Foreign Wars. He noted a General Accounting Offce study that recommended shrinking the VA medical care system. Both Cullinan and Rep. Joseph P. Kennedy II, D-Mass., also cautioned the department not to confuse monetary problems with system problems. ``We shouldn't blame the victim here,'' Kennedy said, explaining that some hospitals may have unused beds because they can't afford to care for more patients. Montgomery said he would like to recommend someone to be appointed to the commission, which would report its findings no later than October 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Makes Offer That Includes No Pay Raises
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with union rejecting offer. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `More than...'.
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Gaston Caperton all but ruled out an across-the-board raise in an offer to West Virginia's striking teachers that was quickly rejected by the state's largest education union. Caperton made the proposal, described by the governor's education secretary as his ``last, best and final'' offer, late Tuesday after a second day of talks aimed at ending the state's first teacher strike, now in its sixth school day. Among other things, the governor proposed an ``education summit'' in May, adjustments in pay aimed at equalizing teacher salaries statewide, and full funding of health insurance and pensions. But in a reversal from last week, he said he would call a special legislative session to consider a raise only if the state develops a big enough surplus. This year's budget is running $29.5 million behind estimates. The West Virginia Education Association said today that Caperton's proposal to call a special legislative session only if the surplus is high enough was ``too vague.'' As for the proposed May summit meeting on education, WVEA President Kayetta Meadows said in a statement that it was ``positive but lacking in substance.'' ``Teachers have been on the picket lines for concrete improvements. For years they've heard promises, and those promises have been consistently broken,'' she said. ``The education summit will simply be another study if it is not backed by a special legislative session.'' Gubernatorial spokesman G.C. Morse called the union's decision ``sad.'' ``The governor is very disappointed,'' Morse said. ``He feels like a tragedy is being worked out here by some folks that really don't understand West Virginia's fiscal situation and the strains we're operating under.'' In announcing his propossal, Caperton said the state ``simply cannot afford to do more. No matter how justified their position may be on the matter of teacher compensation, I bear a responsibility to the taxpayers of West Virginia.'' Meadows' group, the 16,000-member WVEA, is the larger of the two groups that went on strike last week. The smaller union group, the 3,000-member West Virginia Federation of Teachers, promised a response to Caperton's proposal later this afternoon. More than 85 percent of West Virginia's 22,000 teachers walked out March 7 for higher pay and benefits. By Tuesday, the strike had spread to 46 of the state's 55 counties. Steve Haid, secretary of education, called the governor's proposal ``his last, best and final effort which he could legitimately undertake.'' If the teachers do not accept the proposal, decisions on whether striking teachers lose pay for days they were off work, are suspended or dismissed rest with the county school boards and school superintendents, Haid said at a briefing this morning. ``The legislature will likely adjourn tonight or Thursday. They're going home,'' Haid said. ``The governor's authority in the matter is very, very narrow.'' The number of teachers and students affected was not immediately available, but on Monday the strike idled nearly 150,000 of the state's 328,000 school students. About 3,000 of the state's teachers are not unionized. In Wood County, where teachers have voted to remain on the job, about half of the 800 students at Parkersburg South High School left class today when roving pickets set up a strike line in front of the school, Principal Tim Swarr said. On March 5, the governor and legislative leaders offered the teachers a 5 percent raise financed by a tax increase for coal producers, but that deal collapsed the next day. On Tuesday he said he wouldn't offer an across-the-board raise because it would require a tax increase. The state's average teacher salary is $21,904, less than every state except Arkansas and South Dakota, according to the National Education Association. That figure does not include a 5 percent raise teachers received in February. Caperton called the meetings with the teacher representatives ``cordial and fruitful.'' ``And, although we have not yet reached a final agreement on returning teachers to the classrooms, we have closed the distance between ourselves and that goal,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Mongolians Must Turn Yesterday's Dreams Into Tomorrow's Realities
DOC.TEXT: Three weeks ago, a Mongolian opposition leader predicted that the pace of political change in Ulan Bator would be faster than in Moscow. The events of the past week have proved Sanjaasuren Zorig right. The leadership has bowed to opposition demands for sweeping political changes, and those who just a few weeks ago talked about the ideal government and economy for Mongolia must now find ways to realize those dreams. On Monday, the Communist Party Politburo decided to abolish its constitutional guarantee on power, replace the Politburo and party general secretary Jambyn Batmonh, hold early legislative elections and write a new constitution. The Central Committee on Thursday approved ending the 66-year-old guarantee on power, chose a reformer to lead the party, and installed its youngest Politburo in years. These changes come less than three months after Mongolia's first opposition group _ the Mongolian Democratic Union headed by Zorig _ came on the scene, staging peaceful rallies urging political reform. Since then, a half-dozen other political groups have emerged, and three political parties have formed _ the latest Tuesday. The groups have joined together to urge faster, sweeping political reform even though they disagree on what type of government and economy would be best for Mongolia, a nation of 1.9 million. In late February, Zorig sat beneath a portrait of Karl Marx in a classroom at the Mongolian State University in the capital, Ulan Bator. He told a small group of reporters what he envisions for Mongolia's future. ``The most important thing to be carried out is political changes. The main methods to carry out this political construction (is) first to create a multiparty system, introduce a parliamentary system and have presidential rule,'' he said. ``Also to give political freedom to the people.'' Zorig, a 27-year-old post-graduate student of scientific communism and a former university lecturer, envisaged a collective, not state-owned, economy. Zorig said he wanted ``to turn this `credit-fed' economy into an independent economy.'' Mongolia has been economically dependent on the Soviet Union for decades, and Western economists put the debt at close to $6 billion. Land would be leased for cultivation, and there would be no limits on the number of privately owned cattle in this nomadic society where 70 percent of the population still are herdsmen. Enterprises would be decentralized and leased to workers, and those operating at a loss would be shut down. The main goal is that ``those who are working should taste the real fruits of their work,'' Zorig said. If the current leadership steps down, Zorig said a coalition government probably would be formed. ``Surely we will be members of that,'' he said. ``Even in this year, the Mongolian Democratic Party will be member of parliament.'' Such hopes for change were not limited to those in the opposition. Even a herdswoman who lives outside Ulan Bator and had only heard of what was happening in the capital asked: ``Why shouldn't these parties all co-exist?'' A ranking government official who has visited Western countries and observed the workings of those government said he dreams of ``a new look for Mongolia.'' After a five-year period of transition and learning, he predicted, Mongolia would have ``a parliamentary democracy with a presidential system like the United States _ that is the most effective and least costly way.'' The economy would be dynamic, export-oriented and ruled by market forces, and Mongolians would have ``heightened nationalism and self-esteem,'' said the official, who spoke on condition he not be identified.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Meets Next Month with Thatcher, Mitterrand
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout to UPDATE with separate Mitterrand meetings. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, stepping up his personal diplomacy, will meet separately next month with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and French President Francois Mitterrand to discuss the dramatic changes in Eastern Europe, it was announced Wednesday. Bush also will confer with Polish Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki next Wednesday at the White House. Bush will meet with Mrs. Thatacher in Bermuda on April 13 and with Mitterrand in Florida on April 19. ``As the year unfolds, the president will continue to consult closely with his counterparts in the Atlantic community on the historic changes in Europe,'' said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. ``This is part of the consultations he's doing with Western allies and as well as Eastern European leaders,'' said Roman Popadiuk, White House deputy press secretary. Major issues are expected to be the rapid move toward reunification of Germany and the emergence of democractic governments from former communist states in Eastern Europe. Since the beginning of the year, Bush has met with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, Czechozlovakian Prime Minister Vaclav Havel, Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti, former Japanese Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita and Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey, who is president of the European Council. In addition, Bush held a December summit with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. After a day of talks with Mrs. Thatcher, Bush will stay overnight on Bermuda, a self-governing British colony in the Atlantic Ocean 570 miles off the coast of North Carolina. He will return to Washington on April 14. Fitzwater said the precise location of the talks with Mitterrand had not been determined, although it probably would be somewhere in southern Florida. On April 20, a day after the meeting with Mitterrand, Bush is scheduled to make a speech in Orlando and then fly to Islamorada in the Florida Keys for three days of vacation. The meeting with Mrs. Thatcher will be their third one-on-one meeting following talks last year in London and at Camp David, the presidential retreat in Maryland's Catoctin Mountains. Bush saw Mitterrand during the economic summit in Paris last summer and again in December on the French Caribbean island of St. Martin. In London, a spokeswoman at Mrs. Thatcher's 10 Downing Street office said the prime minister had been due to meet Bush in July, when a seven-nation economic summit is planned in Houston, but the April meeting was set up ``by mutual agreement because of the pace of world events.'' Mrs. Thatcher will spend two nights on the island, the spokeswoman added, speaking on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Settlement Reached in USAir Discrimination Case
DOC.TEXT: In a victory for immigrants who lack permanent residency visas, the Justice Department on Wednesday announced a settlement with USAir over a discrimination charge filed by a would-be flight attendant who didn't have a ``green card.'' USAir had refused to interview Monique L. Stennett, a Jamaican citizen, for a flight attendant job because she didn't yet have a green card, an alien registration card allowing a person to work in the United States, even though her passport contained a stamp from the Immigration and Naturalization Service showing she had been granted permanent residence, the department said. The Arlington, Va.-based carrier, which has about 52,000 employees, denied that its practices or involvement with Ms. Stennett violated the Immigration Reform and Control Act, enacted in November 1986. However, under the agreement reached with the Justice Department, USAir agreed to compensate Ms. Stennett for the lost opportunity to interview, to revise its corporate policy manual and its employment application, which asked whether the applicant is a U.S. citizen, and to educate employees regarding the requirements of the act, the department said. Ms. Stennett, who now lives in Florida and who has found other employment, was no longer interested in an interview with USAir. She did receive a $1,000 payment from the airline, said Andrew M. Strojny, acting special counsel for immigration-related unfair employment practices. Asked whether the settlement would have a major impact in reducing discrimination against immigrants, Strojny said: ``I would hope so. Since we've now entered into settlements with five airlines, I would hope we could get it resolved.'' The other four airlines with which the Justice Department has reached settlements are Pan Am, America, Northwest and United. The department won a case against Mesa Airlines. Congress created the Office of Special Counsel to enforce the law's prohibitions against employment discrimination. The office has received more than 830 charges of discrimination _ 112 are now under investigation _ reached 95 settlements and filed 23 complaints before an administrative law judge.

DOC.HEAD: Najib: Afghanistan Rejected Soviet military Aid During Coup Attempt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union offered Afghanistan emergency military support during last week's coup attempt, but the Communist government turned down the aid, President Najib said in a speech obtained Wednesday. Najib also disclosed that two days before the failed takeover, he suspected the defense minister, Shah Nawaz Tanai, was plotting a coup and offered him the post of presidency. ``It is yours if you think you can rule,'' Najib said. Tanai launched his raid Tuesday. He fled to Pakistan when the takeover failed but is now believed to be back in Afghanistan, teamed with a radical guerrilla leader. Najib made his remarks in a speech Sunday to tribal elders from Paktiya province. An Afghan official provided an English translation Wednesday of the speech, which was given in Pushtu. Both Najib and Tanai are from Paktiya. The speech was seen as an attempt by the president to nullify Tanai's influence among the tribes of the southeastern province. Earlier Wednesday, Foreign Minister Abdul Wakil said Afghanistan will destroy its huge stockpiles of Soviet-supplied weapons if the United States and other countries stop supporting Moslem rebels. The offer could help pave the way for peace talks on Afghanistan after 12 years of civil war. During the Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan, the country amassed huge stockpiles of weapons, including thousands of trucks, tanks, armored personnel carriers, bombs, missiles and guns. In negotiations last year, the United States rejected a Soviet proposal for an end to military aid to the warring sides, because this would have allowed the Kabul government to keep those stockpiles. Najib did not specify the type of aid offered by the Soviets during the coup attempt. ``I told them, `thank you for your offer but there's no need now,''' Najib said. ``But,'' he said, ``if we face a foreign attack, that will be different.'' Soviet troops were withdrawn in 1989 from Afghanistan after about a decade supporting Najib's troops. Moscow still gives Kabul about $300 million monthly in military aid, and this has increased since the bloody coup try. In a dispatch Wednesday, the Soviet news agency Tass said 200 civilians died and 500 were injured in the attempt. Najib's government has reported only 95 civilian deaths. No military casualties have been given. In his speech, Najib said he feared Tanai, a hard-line Communist, would unite with guerrilla leader Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, a radical fundamentalist, to take the strategic city of Khost. The Afghan government has reported increased fighting around Khost in the past two days. Throughout the speech, Najib referred to the defense minister only by his first name, an insult to Afghans. The president said two days before the coup attempt he invited Tanai to his office. ``I had heard rumors that he wanted something, so I said, `Take the presidency. It is yours if you think you can rule,''' Najib said. Tanai refused the post and pledged loyalty to Najib, the president said. ``Two days later he was bombing me,'' Najib said. Meanwhile, in the capital, three rockets fell Wednesday, killing one civilian and wounding 11, government spokesman Naqib Sameer said. It was the first fatal rocket attack in more than one week. Pakistan's Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto called for an end to U.S. and Soviet arms shipments to Afghanistan. ``It is time for all concerned to stop having favorites and leave it up to the Afghans,'' Mrs. Bhutto said in Islamabad. ``Let them decide what they want.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Tours Power Plant, Talks Clean Air With Officials
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, touring a power plant that helps keep the lights on at the White House, was told by an official Wednesday that utilities will have to come up with ``megabucks'' to comply with proposed new pollution rules. But Bush pledged that Clean Air Act revisions working their way through Congress will allow smokestack industries maximum flexibility on how to meet the stricter new standards. ``We can't let this country screech to a halt, but I am determined to clean up the air,'' declared the president, exhorting senators to pass a compromise hammered out recently by White House and Senate leaders. The compromise recognizes ``the need to balance environmental benefits and sustain economic growth for this country,'' said Bush. Bush traveled 45 miles by helicopter to visit the Potomac Electric Power Co.'s Chalk Point Generating Station, which churns out 2,000 megawatts of electricity for Washington and the Maryland suburbs. The Chalk Point plant, now in compliance with federal and state standards, is among 107 across the nation that would be forced to reduce emissions sharply under the new rules. Bush said utility president Edward F. Mitchell, his tour guide, ``was telling me there's megabucks involved in all of this.'' Nancy S. Moses, the utility's manager of media relations, said its officials estimate a cost of $12 million a year to meet the first phase of the clean air rules in 1995, primarily by burning more oil and less coal. To meet the second phase standards for the year 2000, the utility envisions bills of $264 million in capital costs for scrubbers and other new technology and $36 million in recurrent operating costs. Bush promised that industry would get ``the flexibility to make emissions reductions in the most cost-effective manner possible.'' The president donned a white hard hat to inspect two giant turbine-generators, each capable of turning out 340 megawatts. With an assist from plant manager Hula Edmonds, Bush turned a dial that boosted output by 10 megawatts. Bush said utility executives assured him they were ``committed to take these additional steps to meet these even tougher standards. ... For that we're very grateful.'' Bush also toured the plant's ``Aquaculture Center'' where the utility raises striped bass, or rockfish, to replenish the depleted waters of the nearby Chesapeake Bay. It has already released 1 million fingerlings. Bush plucked two adult rockfish out of a net. He also peered through a microscope at yellow perch eggs, and afterward applauded the utility's efforts on the environment. On Tuesday, in another pitch for the Clean Air Act, Bush made a shorter hop by car to Dave's Sunoco Station a mile from the U.S. Capitol to pump methanol fuel into an experimental car.

DOC.HEAD: House Democrats Willing to Wait for Deep Defense Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Most House Democrats want to cut President Bush's proposed $303 billion defense budget for 1991 but are willing to wait to make really deep slashes, party leaders said Wednesday. After a closed-door discussion about defense spending attended by many of the House's 257 majority Democrats, ranking lawmakers conceded that they had not decided how much military spending the party should seek. However, they said, a consensus was clear. ``I think everybody understands this is not the same game on defense,'' said Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. ``This is a changed ballgame, because it's a changing world situation.'' ``Whatever happens in the Soviet Union, you aren't going to get that Humpty Dumpty back together again'' to become the military threat it once was, said Armed Services Committee Chairman Les Aspin, D-Wis. The leaders said, however, that their goal was to reduce defense spending gradually. ``Democrats want a long-term defense policy,'' said Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo. Lawmakers who attended the session attributed that tack to two factors: a desire to arrive at a figure that would attract enough votes to pass Congress, and the way military spending works. ``The leadership is still trying to figure out what number is going to get to 218 votes,'' the total required for House passage, said Rep. Jim Slattery, D-Kan., a member of the Budget Committee. The mechanics of the budget are also playing a role. Because much military spending occurs gradually over several years _ such as the construction of a submarine _ it can take years for a cut made in one year to be fully reflected in the budget. ``What you have to reverse is what took place over the last eight or nine years,'' said Panetta, referring to the arms buildup under the Reagan administration. ``That means you're looking at another four- or five-year path'' in the opposite direction, he said. Since Bush submitted his fiscal 1991 budget proposal to Congress in January, most Democrats have argued that the president did not go far enough in shrinking the Pentagon's budget in response to the thaw in the Cold War. Bush's proposal was $7 billion more than this year's figure, but $3 billion below what would have been needed to match inflation. Conservatives have argued that uncertainty about the future political situation in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe make it unwise to cut too deeply into Bush's plan. Liberals have sought deeper cuts _ to as low as the high $280 billion range _ arguing that the money would be better spent for deficit-reduction and social programs. Congress' budget committees are nearing the time when they will have to write a spending blueprint for the next fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1. Wednesday's Democratic skull-session, which lasted about two hours, was an effort to begin translating party-members' criticisms into a solid dollar figure that would win enough votes for passage.

DOC.HEAD: Two Hazelwood Defense Witnesses Dispute Prosecution's Alcohol Expert
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with this morning's testimony. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `Was the...'.
DOC.TEXT: Two of Joseph Hazelwood's expert witnesses took aim at the prosecution's alcohol expert, testifying that belated blood-alcohol tests cannot prove the Exxon Valdez skipper was drunk when his ship went aground. Alcohol experts Michael Hlstala and Thomas Burr cast doubt Tuesday on testimony by prosecution expert Richard Prouty that Hazelwood probably was drunk when his ship rammed a charted reef a year ago. ``It's virtually impossible to go back and get meaningful information about blood-alcohol levels,'' said Hlstala, a professor of physiology at Washington State University in Seattle. ``Once you are beyond a few hours, it's impossible to make any sense of an extrapolation.'' In this morning's testimony, an expert said an audio tape the prosecution wants jurors to hear is actually a poor copy of a Coast Guard tape. Edward Siedlick, a former police detective and now a consultant in New York, said he analyzed the tape and found that its quality was so poor that it probably speeded up Hazelwood's voice. The expert was called after prosecutors indicated they wanted jurors to hear Hazelwood's voice on a tape made on the Exxon Valdez's trip into Valdez, before the tanker went aground March 24 on the outbound trip. They suggested it would show the skipper's voice was much different from when he reported the grounding to the Coast Guard, and would help prove he was drunk on the later tape. Siedlick said he went to Valdez last month to listen to the original of the tapes, but when he got there, Coast Guard officers told him the original had been destroyed. He said he subsequently learned that the copy in evidence was made by a Coast Guardsman holding a microcassette recorder up to another recorder. ``This tape led me to the conclusion that this microcassette copy was not an accurate reproduction of the conversation,'' Siedlick said. ``The pitch of the tape seemed to exceed that of the normal talking voice of Capt. Hazelwood.'' Also this morning, Hlstala testified that listening to someone's voice was not a very good way to judge whether the person was drunk. In his prosecution testimony, Prouty indicated he calculated Hazelwood's level of intoxication by calculations in a method called ``retrograde extrapolation.'' He concluded the skipper probably had a blood-alcohol reading of .14 at the time of the shipwreck. But he based his opinion on a blood test taken 10{ hours afterward, which showed Hazelwood had a blood alcohol level of .061, lower than the Alaska state limit for drunken driving. Was the skipper drinking after the wreck? Nobody knows and Hazelwood isn't expected to testify about it. The lack of a timely blood test has been a prosecution problem from the beginning of the case, providing no direct evidence that the skipper was tipsy. Circumstantial evidence includes testimony from crew members who saw Hazelwood drinking in Valdez that day. But they said he negotiated a precarious gangway to the ship without a misstep and appeared sober as he gave orders. Three witnesses, two of them Coast Guard investigators, have said they smelled alcohol on Hazelwood's breath, but defense lawyers suggest that was the result of the skipper's having drunk a low-alcohol brew called Moussy Beer while on the ship. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., was the only crew member from the Exxon Valdez charged criminally in the wreck, which spilled nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska North Slope crude oil into the crystal waters of Prince William Sound. He is accused of criminal mischief, reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. If convicted, he faces a maximum penalty of 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. Hlstala testified Tuesday that most experts consider the technique of ``retrograde extrapolation'' used by Prouty, the prosecution expert, useful only for calculating back two to three hours _ not 10{ hours. In Hazelwood's case, he said there would be numerous variables such as the rate at which his body absorbs and eliminates alcohol, the exact times the captain started and stopped drinking and whether he ate anything in the 14 hours after boarding the ship. Testimony in the trial has not established conclusive levels for any of the variables. The prosecution says Hazelwood spent seven hours drinking in a Valdez bar before he set sail. The defense says he was in the bar no more than three hours. Prosecutors say he had five drinks; the defense says he had two or three. Burr, an alcohol consultant and former police crime lab specialist from Minneapolis, disputed Prouty's findings, saying that if Hazelwood drank anything after the accident, ``there's absolutely no validity'' in Prouty's results. But he conceded on cross-examination by Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole that experienced drinkers often are able to ``mask'' the effects of alcohol. Cole challenged the qualifications of both experts, suggesting their credentials were inferior to Prouty's experience as a toxicologist in Oklahoma.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Links Isreali Aid More Closely to Settlements
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration appears to be making a stronger link between U.S. aid to Israel and its opposition to Jewish settlements in the occupied territories, some members of Congress say. The issue surfaced recently when Secretary of States James A. Baker III was questioned about the administration's position on a congressional proposal to help Israel raise $400 million to settle Soviet immigrants. Under the proposal, Israel could borrow $400 million from commercial lenders at below-market interest rates. The United States would guarantee repayment of the 30-year loans. Baker told the House appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations that the administration might be able to support the legislation ``if the government provides some assurance it would not be engaging in any new or additional settlement activity in the territories.'' The occupied territories are in the West Bank and Gaza, lands seized by Israel after the Six-Day War in 1967. Arab leaders have voiced concern that the thousands of Soviet Jewish immigrants flocking to Israel might move to the territories. Rep. David Obey, D-Wis., the subcommittee's chairman, said Israeli officials have said ``they don't feel they can give those flat-out assurances.'' But Obey said the Israelis have promised that ``very, very few refugees, less than 10 percent'' would move to the territories. President Bush says he will endorse the housing investment guarantee proposal only if the United States and Israel ``can work out assurances'' that satisfy Washington on Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza.
