DOC.HEAD: You're Under Arrest, Being Filmed, and Have the Right to Remain Silent
DOC.TEXT: ``Cops'' producer Paul Stojanovich was out of breath as he whispered the cryptic instructions. ``We're about to do a drug bust,'' he told a reporter. ``I'll meet you at the Peter Pan Motel, Room 38.'' Minutes later, in a seedy area bathed by the neon glare of the downtown area's Glitter Gulch, Las Vegas Metro Police burst into Room 38. A startled drug seller and his customers found themselves under arrest _ and the subjects of the ``Cops'' film crew. ``Cops'' is a new genre of cop show: live-on-tape action, courtesy of the culprits. Boy, wouldn't Joe Friday have been jealous. The half-hour series is leading Fox Broadcasting's Saturday night lineup, averaging a 7.0 Nielsen rating and a 13 percent share of the viewers in its time period, according to the network's audience estimates. It still lags well behind its competition _ which currently consists of ABC's new ``H.E.L.P.,'' NBC's ``ALF'' and CBS' ``Paradise'' _ but Fox ratings tend to be lower because the network has fewer stations carrying its programs, a total of 130, compared to more than 200 stations for each major network. The evolution of ``Cops'' dates to 1981, when Stojanovich tailed a narcotics unit to produce a show called ``Cocaine Blues.'' He approached the networks with the ``Cops'' idea two years ago, and Fox bought the concept, airing the first episode in January 1989. ``Cops'' since has visited a host of cities, including Miami, Portland, Ore., New Orleans, San Diego and Los Angeles, and recently filmed a series of shows in the Soviet Union. Police departments across the country kept suggesting Las Vegas _ the neighbor of North Las Vegas, the locale of NBC's new ``Nasty Boys'' police series _ so Stojanovich and company came here in January for two weeks of filming. The results of their visit will air as a one-hour ``Cops'' special April 7. The officers bursting through the Vegas motel room door found a gun on the premises, but no shots were fired. The ``Cops'' camera crew, wearing bullet-proof vests, was right behind as officers broke into the room. ``Most of our guys have done combat or heavy news,'' Stojanovich said of the crew members. ``These guys are good.'' Across the nation, the crews have put on film a wide spectrum of an officer's tour of duty, from domestic disputes to drug deals, car chases to homicide investigations. Stojanovich said he's found himself in some touchy situations since taking on ``Cops.'' ``We were shooting a multikilo drug bust in Florida with the DEA when things got out of control,'' he recalled. ``It took 10 officers to take this one guy down, and I'm caught in the middle. Suddenly, I find myself standing next to one of the suspects and the other officers were involved with trying to control the one guy. I just stared at the other suspect. I hoped he thought I was a cop or something.'' The worst injury to a crew member so far was an ankle broken in a foot pursuit in Miami, Stojanovich said. While shooting in Las Vegas, the ``Cops'' crew went along on a call from a battered wife and had to watch as two young children screamed while their feuding parents were taken away. ``That can be really upsetting,'' Stojanovich said. On another night, the crew happened on a car accident. As they were filming, the traffic officer on the scene was run down and badly injured by a drunken driver in a pickup truck. ``You never know what the next call is going to turn into,'' Stojanovich said. The message of the show? ``We try to show that so many cop shows are unrealistic, the guys are glorified, they're heroes. In reality, police work is often very tedious,'' he said. ``We hope to educate the public on what the police are up against. We try to make some sanity out of the insanity.'' Homicides are some of the toughest crimes to film _ and to work, Stojanovich said. ``Most people don't realize how grim it is until they see it from a cop's perspective,'' he said. ``The detectives have to make some sense out of it. It explodes the myth of `Colombo' _ you don't always get the guy. Cops don't have screenwriters to write their scenario, their finish.''

Elsewhere in television ... JACKSON MINISERIES: Motown Productions will produce an ABC miniseries on the musical Jackson family, from its beginnings as the Jackson 5 in the early 1970s to the latter-day superstardom of Michael and Janet. The project, which has the family's full support, is in the early stages of development under the guidance of Motown producer Suzanne de Passe, who co-produced last year's CBS miniseries hit ``Lonesome Dove.''

DOC.HEAD: Partisanship Checked At Door For Bible Study Class
Laserphoto
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers, governor's aides, lobbyists and government workers gather once a week in the room used as the state's nerve center during Hurricane Hugo for an activity they say goes beyond politics and eases Statehouse stress. Instead of discussing an upcoming bill, they reviewed a passage from Matthew during a recent Bible study session in the governor's conference room in the Capitol. The 20 participants who came to the 7:30 a.m. meeting on a drizzling Wednesday put aside any political differences for 45 minutes and left with a sense of spiritual fulfillment. ``God is not a politician. This is fellowship,'' said Elliott D. Thompson, former chairman of the Alcoholic Beverage and Control Commission who is now a lawyer and lobbyist. For the past three years, Gov. Carroll Campbell's deputy chief of staff, Bob McAlister, has organized the informal Bible study sessions. Campbell, a Republican, does not attend but several Democratic lawmakers do. ``I think it indicates that there are more important things in life than politics, and that the pre-eminant question of life is spiritual,'' McAlister said. Participants bring their well-worn Bibles, grab a cup of coffee in the governor's office and sit around the large wooden table usually host to Budget and Control Board meetings. The room also is used by Campbell for news conferences and served as one of his command posts during Hugo in September. Sen. Yancey McGill, D-Kingstree, joined at the start of the legislation session in January and said he has grown close to the others in the group. Lawmakers ``have a lot of pressure on us from day to day, not only here in Columbia but in the district at home,'' McGill said. ``I think the study of God's word is the most important thing to me and it certainly strengthens and really assists me in making decisions on a daily basis.'' McGill said he feels ``total relaxation'' during the gatherings. Rep. David Beasley, D-Society Hill, said ``an inconsequential benefit'' from the meetings is a better look at how the governor's office works. Beasley said he has learned more about some of Campbell's staff through Bible study. ``The only people who go ... are pretty committed to Christian causes, Christian ethics ... and that tells you a lot right there about someone,'' Beasley said. ``If they're in that posture, they're more apt to do what's right. Then it opens up an automatic friendship and we can just sit down and discuss things because there's automatically a mutal respect.'' The Rev. Donald L. Burnett, pastor at St. Andrews Evangelical Church, moderates. ``There are many issues we disagree on but we can agree on essential things,'' he said. McAlister, however, is the driving force behind the Bible study, which began three years ago with three others as the original members. McAlister's religious beliefs earned public attention in the days before the scheduled execution of inmate Rusty Woomer in 1989. McAlister, who has ministered to inmates over the past five years, befriended Woomer as a result of visits to death row to share Christian fellowship. Campbell rejected Woomer's appeal for clemency but the U.S. Supreme Court has delayed the execution. Campbell knows about the Bible study meetings but has chosen not to attend, McAlister said. ``I've never asked him to because the dynamics of the group would change,'' McAlister said. ``I think he and I talked about it and his presence'' might mean ``you'd have others coming for the wrong motivation.''

DOC.HEAD: Oil Conservation No Longer High on the Transportation Agenda
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Tucked away near the end of the administration's 129-page transportation policy is a brief and general pledge to work for oil conservation _ a faint echo of the energy crisis that dominated the national agenda not so long ago. In the era of the oil embargo, of gasoline lines and rocketing prices that spiraled inflation, energy was a major problem for two presidents and a dominant political issue during much of the 1970s. Now it is back-of-the-book stuff despite increasing U.S. dependence on imported oil. Imports, an embargo and a cut in foreign oil supplies were components of the energy crises that confronted Richard M. Nixon and beset Jimmy Carter. They advocated policies to make sure it couldn't happen again. But it could. Oil imports in January were the highest in 12 years. Imports have been rising, domestic oil production falling. Prices are down, which makes foreign oil less expensive than the alternatives. But it certainly isn't inexpensive. Oil imports account for about $50 billion of the persistent U.S. trade deficit. According to the American Petroleum Institute, imported oil accounted for 54 percent of U.S. consumption in January, a record high. CIA Director William Webster has told Congress that reliance on Persian Gulf oil is likely to increase markedly over the next several years. Nixon launched Project Independence, seeking to end U.S. dependence on foreign energy sources after the Arab oil embargo. It didn't happen. Carter said in 1977 the nation should declare the moral equivalent of war to master its energy problems. Carter later was taunted with his program's acronym: MEOW. Parts of his program were shelved; as some others expired they were not renewed. The crises eased, foreign oil became plentiful and relatively cheap, and Ronald Reagan's administration pushed the whole issue far down the agenda, slashing the energy conservation budget and proposing, unsuccessfully, that Congress eliminate the Department of Energy. Now Bush's Department of Energy is at work on a new national energy strategy, with the initial version due next month and the final report before the end of the year. It will have to be a companion piece to the transportation policy statement, which observes: ``Transportation accounts for more than a quarter of total national energy consumption and close to two-thirds of the petroleum used in the United States each year.'' It goes on to say that conservation and more efficient motor vehicles have led to significant energy savings in the past two decades, and that there is more to come. The transportation policy pledges ``to foster development and use of more fuel-efficient vehicles and transportation operations.'' There are no specific recommendations on the politically and economically sensitive issue of future fuel economy standards to be required of U.S. automobile manufacturers. The requirements were relaxed during Reagan's second term; Secretary of Transportation Samuel K. Skinner reinstated them for the 1990 model year, requiring that cars produced by each U.S. manufacturer get an average 27.5 miles per gallon of gas. Congress may act later this year on amendments to the fuel economy rules set after the 1973-1974 Arab oil embargo. Noting that some forms of travel are more energy-efficient than others in meeting the same needs, the transportation policy says that mass transit and inter city rail service can serve as fuel-saving alternatives to the private automobile in heavily populated areas. It also proposes to end operating subsidies and reduce other federal spending for mass transit and rail passenger service, so that passengers, cities and states will pick up the cost. The theory is that those are local and regional, not national facilities, and so should be paid for locally and regionally. That may not mesh with a transportation strategy in which conserving oil is a national aim. But then, there's no crisis now.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 26 years.

DOC.HEAD: Outrage Over Spills Spurs Crackdown On Oil Industry
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The safety measures set up in Prince William Sound since the wreck of the Exxon Valdez are impressive: oil skimmers lie waiting in remote bays, and powerful tugs trail every tanker leaving port. The hostile glare of publicity forced the improvements in Alaska, but critics say the oil industry has a long way to go toward preventing and cleaning up spills elsewhere in the nation. ``What oil companies do best is discover, produce, ship and market oil. Cleaning spills is not their bag,'' said Walt Parker, chairman of an Alaska state task force that studied the Valdez spill. ``They'll do as much as they have to, and no more.'' The U.S. House has passed a bill that would allow states to adopt stricter spill liability laws than the federal government and require double hulls on all tankers in U.S. waters. A conference committee now is trying to reconcile differences with a weaker Senate bill, which calls for more study on double hulls and leaves the final decision up to the secretary of transportation. Legislatures in nearly every seaboard state are considering proposals to increase tanker and oil barge safety or improve spill cleanup capabilities. ``Large spills are something we face in all our port areas,'' said Sarah Chasis, attorney for the Natural Resources Defense Council, a New York-based environmental group. ``There will always be a certain number of oil spills, but many measures can be taken to reduce their likelihood.'' Oil companies hoped to head off some of the legislative furor last June by announcing a $250 million, five-year plan to create a nationwide network of spill-response teams, but it has stalled as the companies watch what action Congress and the states take. The public outrage over the Exxon Valdez accident last March 24 has been kept alive by a string of messy fuel spills around the country. In the past year, at least 81 spills of more than 5,000 gallons occurred in the United States, said spill expert Richard Golob of Cambridge, Mass. The most significant ones, according to his newsletter, Golob's Oil Pollution Bulletin: _June 23: The Greek tanker World Prodigy hit a reef off Rhode Island, spilling 420,000 gallons of heating oil. The same day, a barge collided with a tanker in Texas, spilling 252,000 gallons of slurry oil into the Houston Ship Channel. The next day, a Uruguayan tanker ran aground in the Delaware River, spilling 300,000 gallons of fuel oil. _Jan. 1: An underwater pipeline running from an Exxon refinery ruptured, spilling 567,000 gallons of heating oil into Arthur Kill, a busy industrial waterway between New Jersey and New York's Staten Island. _Feb. 7: The American Trader, chartered by British Petroleum, was gored by its own anchor and spilled nearly 400,000 gallons of Alaskan crude oil off Huntington Beach in Southern California. _Feb. 28-March 6: Three accidents within a week leaked a total of 160,000 gallons of crude, fuel and heating oil into New Jersey's Arthur Kill and adjoining Kill Van Kull. Except for the massive Exxon Valdez spill, which totaled about 10.8 million gallons, the accidents were business as usual for the oil transportation industry, Golob said. ``Professionals in the oil-pollution field know that oil spills take place on a regular basis,'' he said. ``The main difference this year is the extensive media coverage of oil spills. In 1988, a spill of 1 million gallons might have occupied a one-inch story in the New York Times. In 1989, a spill that large would have taken over half the page.'' As oil from the American Trader washed up on Southern California beaches, stores sold T-shirts proclaiming ``Crude Is Rude, Dude,'' and campaigning politicians held so many shoreside press conferences that the mayor of Huntington Beach asked for advance notice so they wouldn't interfere with cleanup efforts. An oil-spill measure previously given little chance of passage was put on the fast track in the California Assembly. It would tighten control of tanker traffic and create a $500 million cleanup fund from a 50-cent-a-barrel tax on crude oil brought into the state. Other states considering strengthened controls include Louisiana, where state wildlife officials want double hulls on all tankers using state waters, and Rhode Island, where a bill introduced with the state attorney general's blessing would make oil shippers assume unlimited liability for damages caused by spills, even if no negligence is proved. Environmentalists are cheered by the explosion of legislative action _ especially the U.S. House proposal for double-hulled tankers, a requirement repeatedly defeated by the oil industry for nearly 20 years. The oil industry argues that double hulls could make ships more unstable in major accidents, and says the cost of building new tankers or retrofitting old ones would be high. Only 10 percent of the world's fleet of 3,200 large tankers have double hulls or double bottoms, said American Petroleum Institute spokesman Bill Taylor. But Chasis, the attorney for the environmental group, said studies have shown double hulls or bottoms would prevent or greatly limit most spills. ``The cost of one major oil spill like the Exxon Valdez _ which is $2 billion and mounting _ could pay for the increased cost of building 100 or more tankers with double hulls,'' she said.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: David Foster is the AP Northwest regional reporter, based in Seattle.

DOC.HEAD: If Broker Goes Under, Investors Are Protected
DOC.TEXT: Marilyn Helding, 65-year-old widow of a Wisconsin vegetable farmer, thought the money from her husband's estate vanished like crops in the Dust Bowl when Windsor Capital Corp. went out of business. ``I nearly went crazy when they went under,'' Mrs. Helding said from her home in Franksville, Wis. ``I didn't know what to do.'' A few months after the small Milwaukee brokerage collapsed under apparent mismanagement in March 1988, Mrs. Helding regained her entire stock portfolio and $45,000 in cash the firm owed her. The message: If your broker goes bust your investment doesn't have to. With the recent collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., two other brokerage bankruptcy court filings in the last year and widely publicized problems at several Wall Street firms, the safety of customer accounts is drawing attention. An agency established by Congress after a rash of brokerage house failures in the late 1960s protects investors who may have thought their account went down the drain with the company that managed it. The Securities Investor Protection Corp. has a $485 million fund that insures individual accounts for up to $500,000, including up to $100,000 in cash. Large brokerages also have insurance for larger amounts. Tapping into the protection fund is a last resort. If a brokerage firm goes belly up, SIPC first tries to arrange a transfer of customer accounts to another firm. ``The basic intention is that a customer should not lose assets or property because the broker with whom (he is) doing business has encountered financial difficulty,'' said Theodore H. Focht, SIPC's president and general counsel. SIPC _ pronounced sippick _ covers all forms of stock and bond holdings but not commodities. It also does not guarantee the underlying value of a customer account. For example, if XYZ Co. is trading at $50 a share when a brokerage folds but falls to $5 at reimbursement time, the customer loses the difference. ``It does not insure you for market losses,'' said Irving Picard, a New York bankruptcy lawyer who has served as a court-appointed SIPC trustee in three liquidation cases. ``If you think the broker defrauded you ... that's not protected by the SIPC fund.'' In the 19 years since its creation, SIPC has handled 212 cases and paid $185 million to satisfy customer claims. If a firm can't immediately pay, SIPC will advance the money to customers and try to collect later. SIPC officials estimate that cash and securities worth $1.4 billion have been returned to about 240,000 investors, mostly through account transfers. A total of 305 claims worth $31 million have not been satisfied, primarily because of legal challenges. The SIPC fund, comparable to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. for commercial banks, is fed by required contributions from the nation's 12,000 or so registered broker-dealers. The Washington-based agency also has $500 million in bank credit and a $1 billion line to the U.S. Treasury. Neither resource has been tapped. On top of that, about 25 firms have private coverage of up to $5 million per account. Before SIPC was signed into law by President Nixon on Dec. 30, 1970, self-regulatory organizations _ the National Association of Securities Dealers and the stock exchanges _ set aside funds to protect customers of collapsed firms. But in the late 1960s, Wall Street was hit with a rash of failures when the market slumped as firms spent large sums to computerize. When its customer protection kitty dried up, the New York Stock Exchange was forced to dip into a building fund to safeguard investors. Fearing the worst, the exchanges lobbied Congress for help. There were six SIPC cases last year _ five involved a total of under 50 claims. The most cases in one year was 40 in 1972, during a recession. A rash of financial fraud was partly responsible for 46 cases from 1981-85. SIPC's largest payout, $32.5 million, involved the 1983 criminal fraud-related collapse of Bell & Beckwith of Toledo, Ohio. The demise of Fitzgerald, DeArman & Roberts Inc. of Tulsa, Okla., involved the most customer accounts, 50,000. SIPC has doled out $5.5 million since that case began in June 1988. SIPC can get involved when a broker-dealer enters bankruptcy court proceedings, when a trustee or receiver is appointed to run a firm, when a firm fails to meet federal requirements or when it can't demonstrate compliance. A brokerage can request a SIPC-run liquidation or SIPC can ask the Securities and Exchange Commission to seek a court order for one. Drexel, for example, was not placed in a SIPC proceeding because only its parent company filed for federal bankruptcy court protection and the firm is liquidating orderly. Plus, Drexel sold most retail accounts to Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. last year and the rest went to Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. after the bankruptcy filing.

DOC.HEAD: Letters to Sartre Tarnish French Feminist's Image
DOC.TEXT: Two volumes of letters from Simone de Beauvoir to her lifetime companion, Jean-Paul Sartre, provide graphic details on the famous couple's private life, and critics say the French feminist philosopher emerges as predatory, opportunistic and macho. ``Lettres a Sartre'' (``Letters to Sartre''), published in February by Gallimard along with de Beauvoir's ``Journal de Guerre'' (``War Journal''), recount in the most minute detail the daily routine of the author of ``The Second Sex,'' the bible of feminists around the world. The letters are responses to Sartre's own letters to de Beauvoir, which were published in 1983 as ``Lettres au Castor,'' the title Sartre's favorite term of endearment for de Beauvoir _ beaver. Her correspondence was thought to have been lost until the couple's adopted daughter, Sylvie Le Bon de Beauvoir, found the letters by chance in a closet, still wrapped in their original envelopes addressed to ``Monsieur Sartre'' or ``Soldier Sartre.'' Some French critics wish the letters had stayed in the closet. ``This asphyxiating outpouring is a crime against the Castor,'' wrote Marianne Alphant in the daily Liberation. ``What do the letters teach us?'' she asks. ``That the pioneer of feminism only liked women she could dominate? That this austere muse was as moody and jealous as a simple housewife? That the novelist so thrilled with her `little inventions' was only a master recycler?'' The letters also prove, Alphant wrote, that de Beauvoir's successful autobiography, ``La Force d'Age,'' was rigged and full of falsifications. Other critics were less harsh. Josyane Savigneau of Le Monde argued that the letters show how the couple respected the ``contract of transparency'' _ complete honesty at all costs _ which became their credo in 1929 and endured until Sartre's death in 1980. In the letters, de Beauvoir details her love affairs with a male student of Sartre's and with some of her own women students, including Louise Vedrine and Nathalie Sorokine. Hoping to ``add a little spice'' to Sartre's dull life as a German prisoner of war in 1939-40, she provides graphic _ and sometimes sordid details _ about what her lovers wore, what they said, how they behaved in bed, and even how they smelled. ``In bed, Vedrine throws herself passionately in my arms, these sensual swoonings seem so terribly organic,'' de Beauvoir wrote. ``When I wake up, I feel like a fat, sated man because I avoid caresses, I think only about breakfast and about my work.'' De Beauvoir wrote that sex was a chore, yet she was fascinated with brothels, prostitutes and other forms of low life that her buttoned-up bourgeois upbringing had made taboo. At times, she comes across as downright conniving. ``If Wanda says anything about me, be sure to tell me so I can know if my charm offensive is working,'' she wrote. For Alphant, de Beauvoir's behavior towards women was ``predator and macho ... linked to an ambiguous desire to play the role of the man.'' But she was equally aggressive with men. ``Something extremely pleasant has happened to me, something I never expected _ I slept with the little Bost three days ago _ naturally I was the one to suggest it,'' she wrote to Sartre in 1938. Bost's first name was not given. ``I'm very fond of him. We spend idyllic days and passionate nights together ... (the relationship) is something precious, and strong, but superficial, too, and easy, just an agreeable fulfillment of relations that had always been pleasant.'' Nonetheless, the overriding theme in the letters is de Beauvoir's undying love and respect for Sartre. She addresses him as ``my dear little being,'' and she loves everything about him, from his ``little arm'' and ``little lip,'' to his ``little round-neck pullover sweaters'' and ``little face.'' ``When I'm with you, nothing seems so terrible as leaving you, yet faraway, the least little fear is unbearable. I love you passionately. I'm empty and unhappy without you. ... I love you with something tragic and with complete abandonment,'' she wrote. Le Bon de Beauvoir justified publishing the letters. She said the whole truth _ regardless of how shocking or unsettling _ is better than myths and part truths. ``Isn't it preferable to say everything in order to reveal the truth. And avoid, by the force of first person narrative, all the cliches, myths, lies, and allow the real person in, all its entirety to emerge,'' Le Bon de Beauvoir wrote in the preface. Readers may be surprised to learn how little de Beauvoir worried about or even thought about World War II. She was too busy rushing from one Left Bank cafe to another, meeting friends and lovers, analyzing their relationships and writing it all in letters to Sartre _ all in the name of honesty. ``From a distance, this was a grand task,'' Alphant concluded. ``Up close, it looks more like a hamster running on a wheel.''

DOC.HEAD: Church Survives Closings and Other Troubles To Start Its Second Century
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Thomas J. McAnoy wept when he saw what vandals did to his church. Broken stained glass lay in puddled foam that had been sprayed about the sanctuary from a fire extinguisher. Banners were torn from their posts, liturgical vestments splashed with wine and tossed in an alley. That desecration last September and other troubles threatened the life of Our Lady of Rosary Church in downtown Detroit. But while many inner-city Roman Catholic parishes here and elsehwere have closed, the century-old Rosary is making it. The battering from vandals occurred only three weeks before the church marked its 100th anniversary and while its continued existence was considered uncertain by the Detroit archdiocese. Rosary was among 24 inner-city churches whose futures were labeled questionable in the second stage of the largest Catholic church retrenchment in U.S. history. Thirty other parishes had been closed earlier during phase one in early 1989. Similar difficulties strained other urban parishes. Chicago's big debt-burdened archdiocese said in January that 30 financially strapped parishes with declining congregations and at least six schools would be closed. The possibility of that fate hung over Rosary, a red sandstone building that rises grandly above Interstate 94. The vandalism worsened the anxieties; parishoners feared the $8,000 repair bill would be the final blow. Rosary already was struggling with other hardships: the loss of an organist who moved away, the pastor's failing health. McAnoy, 60, had recently lost his second leg to amputation because of poor circulation. But when the verdict came in February on the archdiocese's phase two, only five more parishes were closed, bringing the total in Detroit to 35 in a year. Cardinal Edmund Szoka said Rosary would stay open. Parishoners said the past year would be remembered as ``the year of the milestone,'' not the tombstone. ``I think we are more focused now,'' said Norbert Kidd, president of the parish council. ``I think a lot of people sat down and said, `This church, the people in it, the family that gathers here, we mean something to each other.''' The closings of other parishes, blamed on dwindling resources caused by three decades of Catholics migrating to the suburbs, brought angry protests from some parishioners. ``It did serve as a heck of a motivator,'' said Jay Berman, spokesman for the archdiocese. ``It woke a lot of people up where things were in the doldrums.'' In 1989, Rosary, with its self-assigned mission of reaching out to mentally and physically disabled people in the neighborhood, increased its membership from 477 to about 560. Kidd said he expects the number to grow to 600. Rosary also nearly tripled its weekly collection, bringing it into compliance with the archdiocese's directive that $50,000 of the church's $100,000 annual budget come from donations. Kidd said he told parishioners $961 had to be collected each week. ``Since July there have been only two weekends we fell below that,'' he said. ``It used to be if we broke $300, we were congratulating ourselves.'' Some of Rosary's new members came from St. Theresa's, a church about 10 miles from Rosary that was closed under Szoka's order. One transplant, Idell Lee of Detroit, said the transition was difficult because ``St. Theresa's was home and there was no other place to turn.'' Lee said on her first visit she looked inside Our Lady of the Rosary, which has neither pews nor elaborate paintings on the walls, and thought, ``This is it?'' Then one of the blind parishioners tugged at her dress and asked her if she would bring him a cup of coffee. ``I knew then I was in the right place,'' Lee said. The church, which is about 60 percent white, 25 percent black and 15 percent Asian, also proved its viability by certifying its speakers and eucharistic ministers through the archdiocese. It also increased evangelical services and received an acceptable, though critical, report from two people who paid an unannounced visit on behalf of the archdiocese. Their report recommended the church use more approved texts, train lay ministers on the meaning of liturgical symbols and gestures and re-evaluate the practice of allowing parishioners to dip communion hosts into the wine, which is supposed to be sipped. Overall, Kidd thought the report was fair. ``It's like they wanted us to hear the lecture and once we heard the lecture it was OK, just so that we knew what should be,'' he said.

DOC.TEXT: Three people are seeking top offices in the Southern Baptist Convention to try to steer the 14.8 million-member denomination away from its fundamentalist path of the past 11 years. Steve Tondera, a layman and senior engineer at Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala., last week announced his candidacy for a vice presidency on a moderate slate at the denomination's convention in June. Also running as moderates are the Rev. Daniel Vestal of Dunwoody, Ga., seeking the presidency, and Carolyn Weatherford Crumpler, former head of the Women's Missionary Union, running for another vice presidency. Together, they seek to unseat a fundamentalist administration that came into power in 1979 and began appointing others with similar views to key posts on the boards of Baptist colleges and agencies. The fundamentalist wing, which this time is backing the Rev. Norris Chapman of Wichita Falls, Texas, for the presidency, gained control under the banner of biblical literalism.
The North Carolina Civil Liberties Union has filed a lawsuit demanding that U.S. District Judge H. William Constangy stop praying aloud at the start of each court session.
The National Association of Evangelicals reported at its annual convention that 11 more denominations became members last year, raising the total to 44 with a combined membership of 4.1 million.

A poll by the St. Paul Pioneer Press Dispatch and broadcast station WCCO found that strong majorities of Roman Catholics _ upwards of 60 percent _ disagree with the church's position prohibiting contraception, marriage of priests and ordination of women.

A new Jewish seminary is planned as a bridge between Orthodox and Conservative wings of Judaism by a group of Jewish educators. It will be ``a haven from polarization and sectarianism of all extremes,'' says Rabbi Ronald D. Price, dean of the new school, the Institute of Traditional Judaism, to open this fall in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

A study monitoring television preachers finds that on the average they devote about a fourth of their time to fund-raising and promotion. But major shifts in that area have occurred in some TV ministries. The study made by Stephen Winzenburg, communications professor at Grand View College, found that both Pat Robertson and Oral Roberts had sharply increased time used seeking support. Roberts now uses 53 percent of his air time in fund-raising and promotion, compared to 22 percent in 1987, while Robertson spends 44 percent of his programs asking financial help, up from 22 percent three years ago, the report said. However, the Rev. Jerry Falwell has reduced fund-raising appeals in that period from 52 percent to 37 percent, it said. Winzenburg said the decline in viewership that saw audiences for syndicated religious programs fall 30 percent in the 1987-89 period after the Jim Bakker and Jimmy Swaggart sex scandals appeared to have leveled off.

DOC.HEAD: Two Normandy Villages Fight Over Piece of De Gaulle History
DOC.TEXT: COURSEULLES-SUR-MER, France (AP) _ Eight days after Allied soldiers stormed ashore in Normandy, the destroyer La Combattante carried Gen. Charles de Gaulle across the choppy, gray English Channel to a beach at Courseulles-sur-Mer. Or was it next door at Graye-sur-Mer? Forty-six years later, the communities still argue over whose sand bore the imprint June 14, 1944, of the general's first footprint of the liberation. The dispute has regained the stature of controversy in this special year of de Gaulle _ the 100th anniversary of his birth, the 20th anniversary of his death and the 50th anniversary of his ``appeal of June 18'' from London in 1940, urging the French to resist the German occupation. A veterans' group, the Normandy Landing Committee, decided to commemorate the year by erecting a 60-foot-high metal cross of Lorraine. De Gaulle took the double-barred cross as his personal symbol and it remains the symbol of Gaullism. For what the committee members called ``aesthetic reasons,'' they decided to install the cross on Graye's beach, which enraged the folks at the Courseulles city hall. De Gaulle's own war memoirs are not much help. ``On the morning of June 14, we cast anchor as near as possible to the French coast and landed together with a Canadian regiment on the beach between the communities of Courseulles and Sainte-Mere-Eglise,'' he wrote. Courseulles and Sainte-Mere-Eglise are about 45 miles apart. Canadian soldiers liberated Courseulles-sur-Mer and Graye-sur-Mer on D-Day _ June 6, 1944. At one time or another, de Gaulle told officials of both towns he had fond memories of landing on their beach after four years in London. ``I'm sure de Gaulle himself did not know exactly where he set foot,'' said Remy Simon, a councilman assigned by Courseulles Mayor Jean-Louis de Mourgues to gather documents and build the case for their town, which has about 3,000 inhabitants. ``In the end, all this business is very painful,'' said Mayor Michel Grimaux of Graye, whose population is about 600. He hinted that Courseulles' interest was commercial as much as historic. Adding to the problem is the fact that no one in either town saw the general arrive. For security reasons, only military commanders were told in advance. Later on June 14, after giving a speech at Bayeux, de Gaulle returned to Courseulles and reboarded the destroyer. There is no shortage of photographs of his departure from Courseulles. ``In 1946, de Gaulle came back, and he came back to Courseulles,'' said Simon, who has a foot-thick file of documents on the matter. ``All of the eyewitnesses of the time confirm it was Courseulles.'' The Courseulles documentation includes letters from several people who accompanied de Gaulle, including Adm. Andre Patou, who was a captain at the time and skipper of La Combattante, and Gen. Pierre Koenig. All say Courseulles was the landing place. ``We are fighting for the historical truth, and that's all,'' Simon said. He denied any other motives. Courseulles is a tourist town that grows to between 18,000 and 20,000 people in summer and during school holidays. It has a marvelous beach, hotels, swimming pools, tennis, stables and a chateau, as well as a thriving oyster business and boat-building. Graye, rich in charm, has remained a sleepy country village. Mayor Grimaux, a boy of 12 at the time, said his certainty that de Gaulle landed in Graye came from Lt. Col. W.J. Humphrey, a Briton who was beachmaster on the Graye-Courseulles sector of the Juno Beach landing area. According to Grimaux, Humphrey said all VIPs to the newly liberated sectors of Normandy, including Winston Churchill and King George VI, landed directly in front of the beachmaster's headquarters, which was clearly in Graye. It also was Humphrey who provided de Gaulle with a Jeep, the mayor said. Grimaux has clippings from the local newspaper in 1946 quoting de Gaulle as telling a previous Graye mayor: ``I will never forget your community. It is there that I landed.'' La Presse de Calvados added editorially: ``A decisive word that puts an end to certain controversies.'' When a site was chosen for the Lorraine cross, the town boundary of Courseulles was moved 65 yards west so the monument straddles it. Simon, the Courseulles councilman, found that a ``grotesque'' solution, but said: ``We gave in to a compromise to be reasonable, not because it's right.'' Grimaux said: ``All that interests me is the truth.''

DOC.HEAD: Spill May Have Stalled Alaska Oil Development for Years to Come
With BC-Valdez-Spill Revisited, b0716-b0717
DOC.TEXT: The wreck of the Exxon Valdez forced more scrutiny and higher costs on Alaska's oil industry and may have delayed for years the exploration for new oil in the state's vast arctic wilderness. In the six weeks from the tanker disaster to the Legislature's mandated adjournment, lawmakers raised industry taxes and spill fines, strengthened plans for spill prevention and cleanup and set up an independent investigatory commission. This year, even as the reform momentum slows, they are considering more ``spill bills,'' including a package by Gov. Steve Cowper that would allow the state to inspect tankers and increase liability requirements for companies transporting or storing oil. Such enthusiasm for reining in Alaska's largest and most lucrative industry would have been inconceivable before March 24, 1989, the day of the Big Spill. Alaska depends on oil like no other state, deriving about 85 percent of its revenues from oil taxes and royalties. Its 531,000 residents pay no state sales or income taxes, yet the state leads the nation in per-capita spending. At the same time, the thick flow of crude has helped the state amass a $10.5 billion savings account. Its earnings yield an annual ``dividend'' to every Alaskan; last year's was $873. ``For a decade, we had seen nothing but the up side, which was state revenues with no pain to the public,'' said Senate President Tim Kelly, a Republican. ``What we saw from the Exxon Valdez was the down side of the oil business.'' The oil stains and smears left on the treasured landscape of Prince William Sound angered Alaskans, who felt betrayed by their favored industry and by their legislators. No one was spared the finger-pointing. ``We got slapped around,'' said House Speaker Sam Cotten, a Democrat. So did the industry. ``It was almost the oil industry vs. the state of Alaska,'' said Bill Webb, general manager of the pro-oil Alaska Support Industry Alliance. ``That's a dangerous position for a state to be in with its largest industry.'' The emotion in which eight spill bills were swiftly passed last spring has dissipated. But it's an election year, and environmental protection remains a priority. Legislators predict passage of three or four more oil-related bills by May. ``We were the Legislature on watch when this thing happened,'' Cotten said. ``So it's really up to us to get it all done.'' But some say much remains to be done. Sue Libenson, executive director of the Alaska Center for the Environment, said the state's response has been overrated. Last year's spill bills were ``stopgap measures'' that dealt only with the immediate disaster, she said. ``We didn't see anything that would really prevent future spills,'' she said. `We have yet to create any new policies to give real long-term incentives to polluters not to pollute.'' And lawmakers, with more time to reflect, no longer are rushing to vote against the oil industry. ``The lynch-mob mentality has left the Legislature and cooler heads are starting to prevail,'' said Rep. Robin Taylor, House minority leader. That is welcome news for Jim Palmer, a spokesman for BP Exploration (Alaska) Inc., an arm of giant British Petroleum. ``Last year, if any piece of legislation had `oil spill' on it, it was automatically assumed correct and needed without as much scrutiny as normally is given,'' Palmer said. ``This year that has changed. All different views on the thing are being heard ... including ours.'' Legislators also worry about the spill's effect on oil exploration. The disaster held up legislation in Congress that would have opened the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge for exploration. The huge fields at nearby Prudhoe Bay supply about 25 percent of the nation's domestic oil, but production is declining. The best hope to maintain production and keep revenues flowing may be the wildlife refuge, known to Alaskans by its acronym ANWR. Support for opening the refuge to exploration remains strong in Alaska, despite the Exxon Valdez spill. ``The majority of the Legislature and the majority of Alaskans continue to support the safe and orderly development of ANWR,'' said Kelly, the Senate president. ``On the national level, the spill probably held it back a year or two.'' Alaska's sole congressman, Republican Don Young, is optimistic Congress eventually will act on the refuge. ``The nation needs ANWR opened because we're importing over 50 percent of our oil, a position that is much more precarious than during the 1973 oil embargo,'' when the United States imported 36 percent of its oil, Young said. But the wreck of the Exxon Valdez gave environmentalists a new weapon against opening the refuge. ``It's made everyone sit up and say: `Gee, is it really worth the risk? Are the oil industry's assurances that everything will be fine something that we can rely on?''' said Mike Wenig, attorney for the environmental group Trustees of Alaska. As the spill has focused attention on Alaska's oil dependence, the state has continued efforts to diversify its economy. Exports of seafood, timber and minerals were up sharply last year, and Anchorage got a boost when Federal Express chose the city as its international cargo hub. But economic diversification will be tough to achieve in this remote state. ``We're just not close enough to the marketplaces to compete in software, high technology or something of that nature,'' Kelly said. ``So with the exception of tourism, in the foreseeable decades we are going to be a resource-development state.'' And the most profitable resource in Alaska remains oil. ``Nobody wants to get out of the oil business in Alaska,'' Kelly said. ``It's just too lucrative.''

DOC.HEAD: Religious Leaders Pressuring Politicians on Abortion
DOC.TEXT: When a Roman Catholic bishop banned a candidate for the California Senate from receiving communion because she supports legal abortions, the voters delivered her an upset victory. And when New York Gov. Mario Cuomo was threatened with the fires of hell, he shrugged off a bishop's attempt to change his stand on abortion. Despite such failures, religious leaders _ particularly Roman Catholics _ have increased their efforts to influence politicians on abortion, according to abortion-rights activists. The pressure tactics have touched off a debate in political and theological circles about the role of the church in modern politics. It is a revival of the controversy John F. Kennedy had to quiet before winning the presidency 30 years ago, and that presidential nominee Al Smith faced as a Catholic before him. ``The prelates seem to imply that Al Smith and John Kennedy were wrong in contending that Catholics in politics are as free as communicants of other faiths,'' historian Arthur Schlesinger Jr. wrote in the New York Times. ``... If they had spoken then as they speak now, John F. Kennedy would never have been elected president.'' The anti-abortion pressure from religious leaders is not coming solely from Catholics. A state representative in New Hampshire, Republican Stephanie Micklon, was barred from membership in the charismatic American Baptist Church that she grew up in after she sponsored a bill to put a woman's right to an abortion into state law. Micklon was told she was ``not religiously acceptable'' to her church and that she ``brought disgrace upon the name of Jesus Christ,'' she said. ``This is religious blackmail,'' she said. ``If I had changed my vote, I was religiously acceptable.'' The salvation of Cuomo, a Catholic and potential 1992 Democratic presidential candidate, was called into question when Auxiliary Bishop Austin Vaughan in January said the governor ``takes a very serious risk of going straight to hell'' for supporting abortion rights. Cuomo gives Roman Catholic bishops credit for helping foster national debate on abortion but he says they can expect a backlash when they attempt to influence elections. ``I don't think we can exempt them from the demands of prudence in the political arena,'' he wrote in a letter to the Catholic lay journal Commonweal Magazine this month. Some other political analysts agree. ``When the church gets too heavyhanded, they have problems,'' said Charles Cook, author of a Washington-based political newsletter. ``They can work quietly and it's effective, but when they go too far it's going to hurt them.'' A state Senate race in California last fall is cited as one example. Democrat Lucy Killea, running in a special election, was barred from taking communion because of her support for abortion rights. Her subsequent victory was widely credited to the attention and sympathy generated by the ban imposed by Bishop Leo Maher of San Diego. Catholics for Free Choice, a private group that supports abortion rights, said it knows of cases where Catholic public officeholders or candidates have been pressured by church leaders over the abortion issue in at least eight states. Frances Kissling, president of the group, cited cases in Montana, Connecticut, Pennsylvania, Alaska, Washington, New York, New Jersey and California. She said Killea is the only known case where a Catholic politician has been denied communion because of abortion views. But others, she said, have felt ``more subtle threats.'' ``They're afraid _ afraid they're going to get up one morning and be refused communion, afraid they're going to be embarrassed by church officials,'' she said. The efforts have not not changed minds on the issue, Kissling contends, but have caused some officials to shrink from leadership roles, such as sponsoring legislation. Although Kissling worries about a ``chilling effect,'' some political leaders say they see no evidence that church activity is hurting the abortion-rights cause. ``It can be a powerful tool, but I think it's backfiring,'' said Kate Michelman, head of the National Abortion Rights Action League. ``There's a great sensitivity in this country to separation of church and state.'' The National Right to Life Committee, the leading anti-abortion lobbying group, works with church groups but distances itself from the actions of religious leaders. ``We just don't really get involved in religious issues,'' said spokeswoman Nancy Myers. The complaints about religious meddling in the politics of abortion come as Catholic leaders appear to be asserting themselves more on public policy issues, said the Rev. Richard Neuhaus, a Lutheran who is director of the Institute on Religion and Public Life in New York. ``I think there is a new consensus among the bishops that there is a new level of agreement and urgency in making the church's teachings credible ... with public officeholders,'' he said. Catholic bishops approved a resolution last November that put a priority on lobbying against abortion rights. It urged public officials, ``especially Catholics, to advance these goals in recognition of their moral responsibility.'' Cardinal John O'Connor, chairman of the bishops' Committee for Pro-Life Activities, wrote each member of Congress this month to state opposition to a bill that would write the Supreme Court's abortion guarantees into federal law. He sent each congressman a picture of an 18-week-old fetus to illustrate ``the insanity of our nation's current policy sanctioning abortion on demand.'' Kissling sees evidence Catholic leaders are pursuing ``an overall strategy'' to pressure officeholders that goes beyond mere lobbying, an activity she does not question. But Bob Wonderly, a spokesman for the U.S. Catholic Conference, the public policy and lobbying arm of the church, said there was no agreement to sanction churchgoers whose public actions are at odds with the church on abortion. ``Each bishop is doing what he feels is necessary to fulfill his ministry,'' Wonderly said.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Finds Valdez Oil Hard To Wash Off Corporate Image
With BC-Valdez-Spill Revisited, b0716-b0717
DOC.TEXT: A year after the Alaska oil spill, some experts still point to Exxon Corp.'s reaction as a virtual primer on how not to handle a disaster. ``To be nice, I'd say they did not distinguish themselves,'' said Gerald Meyers, former chairman and chief executive officer of American Motors and author of a book on corporate crisis control, ``When It Hits The Fan.'' ``To be more blunt, they screwed up,'' he said. ``For whatever reason, the company appeared to be indifferent or uncaring or unconcerned while hundreds of sea otters and all kinds of wildlife were washing up on shore.'' Marilou Hedlund, managing director of the Hill & Knowlton public relations firm in Chicago, said several new clients came to her saying, in essence, ``We don't want to have what happened to Exxon happen to us.'' Reporters had trouble getting comment from Exxon about the March 24 spill, and company Chairman Lawrence G. Rawls stayed away from the area and didn't appear before reporters until April 18. Within hours of the spill, a local group volunteered to mobilize fishing boats to help move in equipment to keep the oil from spreading. But, in another example of what critics label Exxon's clumsiness, the company never returned their call, the group's members said. By the time Exxon responded with its own equipment, a storm had moved through the area and spread the oil over a wider region. The Associated Press called Exxon asking to discuss its handling of spills, but officials at the corporation's New York headquarters, its subsidiary's headquarters in Houston and its Bayway refinery in Linden, N.J., all declined comment. Ms. Hedlund and other crisis managers, a burgeoning sub-field of public relations, live by a simple maxim: There's no substitute for practice. ``We do crisis training with our clients, actually create an incredible crisis and simulated news and radio reports and see how they handle them,'' she said. Ms. Hedlund said she also refers clients to several ``textbook examples'' of good crisis management, including United Airlines' handling of the crash of Flight 232 in Iowa last summer and Johnson & Johnson's of the nightmarish Tylenol poisonings of the early 1980s. ``The key to the success of both cases was the company's immediate release of everything they knew and their handling of victims' families,'' she said. Meyers said British Petroleum's recent oil spill off Huntington Beach, Calif., provides another good example. ``They learned from Exxon, no doubt,'' he said. ``BP's chairman, Jim Ross, flew there almost immediately and showed a take-charge attitude. That was a very bad scene _ an oil spill right in the cradle of the environmental movement. But they weathered the storm.'' Exxon recently halted oil loading and unloading operations at its only East Coast refinery after three spills in two months in New York City-area waters, even though only one of the spills was directly tied to Exxon property. The shutdown illustrates Exxon's tension over its public image in the year since its tanker split open in Alaska's Prince William Sound, said Simon Trimble, international oils analyst for the investment firm Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York. These days, Trimble said, ``it doesn't take 10 million barrels of oil spilled into American waters for there to be a negative impact on Exxon.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, March 18

DOC.TEXT: The government said the deficit in the broadest measure of U.S. trade sank to a five-year low last year, but the $105.9 billion imbalance still pushed the country deeper into the hole as the world's largest debtor nation. America's current account balance narrowed by 16 percent over a $126.6 billion deficit in 1988, reflecting growth in exports, higher overseas earnings of American businesses and increased spending by visiting foreign tourists, the Commerce Department said Tuesday. The year ended on a positive note as the October-December trade deficit declined to $20.57 billion, down 10.2 percent from its third quarter level. It was the smallest quarterly imbalance in almost six years.

Retail sales in February took their steepest fall in four months, the government reported, but analysts said the decline was due almost entirely to sagging automobiles sales. The Commerce Department said Tuesday that retail sales totaled a seasonally adjusted $146.5 billion. The decline was the biggest since a 1.3 percent drop in October and followed a strong 2.8 percent gain in January. The January number originally had been reported at 1.6 percent.

A group of powerful investors, including the owners of Mary Kay Cosmetics and a Getty family trust, has come through on its promise to launch a proxy battle seeking four seats on the board of Avon Products Inc. In a full-page advertisement in Wednesday's New York Times, Chartwell Associates L.P. said its directors, if elected, would work to ``maximize shareholder value'' by selling Avon.

R.H. Macy & Co. lost $39 million in its most crucial quarter following a disappointing Christmas shopping season, increasing the financial pressures on the debt-burdened retailing chain. Macy, which went private in a leveraged buyout in 1986, said Tuesday that the markdowns the company was forced to take to compete with price cutting at Campeau Corp.'s department stores took a heavy toll on its balance sheet. The second-quarter loss, which translated to $27.67 per share, compared with the $72.6 million, or $39.85 per share, Macy earned in the same period a year earlier.

The Securities and Exchange Commission would get new authority to curb program trading in stock market emergencies under a bill cleared by a congressional committee. The Securities Markets Stabilization Act, approved Tuesday by the House Energy and Commerce Committee, would allow the SEC to limit program trading and other activities ``during periods of extraordinary market volatility.''

Rorer Group Inc. said it will work jointly with the consumer products giant Procter & Gamble to develop and market prescription and over-the-counter pharmaceutical products. The move Tuesday comes one day after the suburban Philadelphia-based company announced a $1.7 billion agreement to merge with the pharmaceuticals operations of Rhone-Poulenc SA of Paris. The alliance with Cincinnati-based Procter & Gamble gives Rorer a major worldwide distribution system for its main product, the antacid Maalox. Procter & Gamble also obtains U.S. marketing and distribution rights to Rorer's line of over-the-counter pharmaceuticals.

Brazil's Central Bank said the nation's banks would close the rest of the week in anticipation of a series of emergency economic measures to be announced by President-elect Fernando Collor de Mello. Central Bank spokesman Pedro Kleinberg said Tuesday the three-day bank holiday was ordered at the request of Zelia Cardoso de Mello, the nation's new economic minister, who is to take office with the new president on Thursday.

Nabisco Brands Inc. agreed to discontinue three advertising campaigns that authorities complained were misleading, including the Fleischmann's margarine ``healthier heart'' promotion. The company also agreed Tuesday to pay $135,000 in legal costs associated with the campaigns for the margarine, Shredded Wheat and 100 Percent Bran. Nabisco signed the agreement with 10 states whose attorneys general had complained about the ads.

Saatchi & Saatchi Co. PLC said it is cutting salaries by 30 percent for its founders, naming two Americans to its board and trying to sell its consulting businesses in an attempt to rebound from financial problems. Maurice Saatchi, who founded the company with his brother Charles and serves as its chairman, made the announcement Tuesday to about 400 shareholders at their annual meeting.

Prices slumped on Wall Street Tuesday as the stock market, taking another cue from the bond market, succumbed to concerns about rising interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 12.16 to 2,674.55. The dollar finished slightly lower in moderate trading. Bond prices fell sharply. Gold futures dropped; silver futures rose; copper plunged; grains and soybeans slumped; cattle futures gained, and energy futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Macy Reports $39 Million Loss After Disppointing Christmas
DOC.TEXT: A disappointing Christmas shopping season resulted in a $39 million second-quarter loss for R.H. Macy & Co. Inc., increasing the financial pressures on the debt-burdened retailing chain. Macy, which went private in a leveraged buyout in 1986, said Tuesday the markdowns it was forced to take to compete with price cutting at Campeau Corp.'s department stores took a heavy toll on its balance sheet. The loss, which translated to $27.67 per share, compared with the $72.6 million, or $39.85 per share, Macy earned in the same period a year earlier. Sales during the quarter ended Jan. 27 totaled $2.44 billion, up from $2.28 billion a year earlier. Pamela Stubing, a retail industry analyst with Moody's Investors Service Inc., said many of Macy's stores in the Northeast had stiff competition from Campeau's Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores units. Macy, choosing to defend market share rather than profit margins, cut prices to keep its customers, she said. Federated and Allied, which were on the brink of a Chapter 11 bankruptcy court filing, slashed their prices during the holiday season to bring in cash. The loss could not have come at a worse time. Macy's second quarter _ the fourth quarter for most other major retailers _ is when the company hopes to earn half its annual profits. The company also is dependent on its cash flow to pay down the remaining debt from its leveraged buyout. Macy's earnings statement reported nearly $4.54 billion in long-term debt as of Jan. 27, and $189 million in interest charges during the second quarter. Walter Loeb, a retail consultant and analyst, said Macy also was hurt by overstocking its private label merchandise. To reduce inventory, the company again was forced to cut its prices, he said. But the company succeeded in cushioning the shock about the dismal quarter, having signaled to investors and its suppliers some time ago that it expected to report a sharp loss, Loeb said. Loeb said Macy's will continue to have problems in the near term, but he said there were signs the retailer would fare better during the spring because of warmer weather and because the company is going into the season with a leaner inventory. In a letter to its investors dated Monday, Macy said it was prepared for the economy to remain flat during the spring and fall seasons, indicating the retailer does not expect a burst of consumer spending. Ms. Stubing predicted the retail environment would be less promotional _ meaning fewer markdowns to draw customers _ during Macy's second half, although the company still faces tough competition. For the first six months of its fiscal year, Macy lost $72.2 million, or the equivalent of $51.58 per share, compared to earnings of $53.6 million, or $24.75 per share, in the same period a year ago. Sales for the first half rose to $4.15 billion from $3.9 billion. Loeb said the financial and retail industries have confidence in Macy Chairman Edward Finkelstein, who shaped the company's buyout and its retailing strategy. Besides its flagship Macy stores, located mainly in the East and Texas, the company owns I. Magnin and Bullock's stores in California and the West. It also owns specialty stores including Charter Club and Aeropostale, which are stocked with Macy's private label apparel brands.

DOC.HEAD: Exports At Record Level in '89
DOC.TEXT: Exports of U.S. paper products rose 9.1 percent last year to a new record, while paper imports declined for the first time in seven years, the American Paper Institute Inc. reported. The industry exported 17.2 million metric tons of paper products, which were worth $15.4 billion. The value of the exports rose 15.4 percent from the previous year. API vice president Irene Meister, who released the report Tuesday at an annual industry conference here, noted that the industry's strong performance resulted from ``years of productivity gains and the high level of capital investment in new capacity.'' Exports of newsprint and printing-writing paper posted the biggest categorical gains, jumping 46 percent and 66 percent, respectively. The institute noted, however, that the gains came on the heels of a relatively low year. Imports of paper goods declined slightly to 16.6 million metric tons _ valued at $11.5 billion _ after rising every year since 1982. Wood pulp and newsprint, mainly from Canada, accounted for 70 percent of the imports. Newsprint consumption in the United States held relatively steady at 12.3 million tons in 1989, according to Virgin Horton, vice president of the API's paper group. U.S. paper mills shipped 5.52 million tons of newsprint, up 100,000 tons from the previous year. Horton noted that demand for newsprint is dependent upon newspaper advertising linage and circulation, which should hold steady in coming years. Circulation has been flat over the past decade, he said, adding that consumers generaly do not alter their newspaper reading habits during a recession. And the amount of advertising dollars allocated to newspapers has also held relatively steady in recent years. The U.S. paper industry is celebrating its 300th year. The API is sponsoring the 113th annual paper week this week at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

DOC.HEAD: Baseball Lockout Forces Media Companies to Make Alternate Plans
DOC.TEXT: If the baseball lockout never ends, what will the sports media write and talk about this summer? Some media companies already are juggling their plans even as they hope they will never have to answer that question. The lockout has blocked the opening of spring training camps for nearly a month, and it already has cost the ESPN cable network five of the 10 spring training games it planned to televise this year. Potential problems loom for CBS, which is to begin broadcasting baseball in April; The National, the new daily sports newspaper, and The Sporting News, the sports weekly. ``It hasn't affected us yet, but baseball is the only game in town in the summertime,'' said Tom Osenton, president and chief executive of The Sporting News Publishing Co. in St. Louis. ``If you take the game away, you have nothing to write about.'' ESPN is in the first season of its $400 million contract to carry up to 175 games in each of the next four years. ``Getting that contract was such an exciting moment for us,'' said Mike Soltys, manager of programming information for ESPN. ``To start out in this manner is certainly discouraging.'' The network filled the gaps created by the lost games with live tennis, auto racing and other programming it had originally planned to tape for later replay, he said. Plans are to substitute a college basketball playoff game, a college baseball game and college wrestling, among other events if the remaining spring training games are canceled, Soltys said. He said the network is sticking with its plans to run a baseball show, Baseball Tonight, seven nights a week starting as scheduled next Monday. If the lockout continues, the show will deal with developments in negotiations between the players and owners and may feature coverage of minor league baseball, he said. But ESPN faces a more serious problem in April, when it planned to begin carrying six games a week. The network has hired 19 commentators to handle the nightly baseball show and the games, Soltys said, and has sold more than 60 percent of its season's advertising inventory in the games. Soltys said the advertisers are being given the options of appearing on the replacement programs, holding off until the games start or getting refunds. But he said the lockout has hurt the climate for selling advertising. ``There is no way of knowing where we would be without this,'' he said. Soltys said ``there are provisions for lost games'' under the network contract with baseball, but he refused to describe them. A source familiar with the contract said ESPN and CBS will be given additional games in the next three years for games lost this year. The lockout has posed a less serious problem so far for CBS, which agreed to pay $1.06 billion for the right to broadcast 16 regular season games, the All-Star game, the playoffs and World Series every year for four years. CBS' first baseball broadcasts are scheduled for April 14 and April 21, but its third broadcast is not scheduled until June 16. CBS Sports spokesman Tony Fox said the network has not decided what sports programs will replace the April game broadcasts. Fox said more than half of CBS' advertising inventory for baseball had been sold, but he declined to discuss what plans were being made for advertisers if games are canceled. The network plans to run its baseball season preview show on March 31 as scheduled no matter what happens with the lockout, Fox said. As at The Sporting News, the lockout has had little impact so far on The National, according to editor-in-chief Frank Deford. The newspaper debuted Jan. 31 in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles. Deford said readers of The National usually are interested in several sports, and there has been plenty of activity recently in college and professional basketball, boxing and hockey to interest them. But if the baseball lockout continues into mid-summer, ``that would be a real blow to us, there is no question.'' At The Sporting News, Osenton said plans are being made to beef up basketball and hockey coverage over the next few weeks and said if the lockout persists, the tabloid may increase coverage of minor league baseball. Deford said it was unlikely The National would start covering minor league or Japanese baseball because he doen't think readers want it. ``You can't give people something they don't want,'' he said. He said if the lockout continued into June, there probably would be more coverage of major tennis, soccer, golf and swimming events. He said the paper also could be trimmed to 32 pages from the 40-48 pages it has been running. Deford professes to be unconcerned and has made no contingency plans. ``My best judgment is I cannot conceive of a situation where they will not be back by June,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Program Trading Curb Clears Another Legislative Hurdle
DOC.TEXT: A bill giving the Securities and Exchange Commission authority to curb program trading in stock market emergencies has moved a step closer to law despite objections from the Treasury Department. The Securities Markets Stabilization Act was approved unanimously on a voice vote Tuesday by the House Energy and Commerce Committee. The bill would allow the SEC to limit program trading and other activities ``during periods of extraordinary market volatility.'' But the scope of that power was narrowed in an amendment to the bill, which now goes to the full House for approval. The Treasury Department made public a letter from Undersecretary Robert R. Glauber to the committee opposing a program trading restriction, stating the department believed the reform bill was ``too important to be jeopardized by a controversial and unnecessary provision to shut down program trading.'' Meanwhile, a member of the panel said he plans to introduce legislation _ with a member of the House Agriculture Committee _ to unify jurisdiction for hybrid financial instruments under one agency. The SEC, which regulates securities, and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, which oversees the futures markets, have been waging a turf battle over new financial products tha fall in the middle. Often called hybrids, they have characteristics of both securities and futures. A federal appeals court ruled last year that securities with any aspect of a futures contract should come under the CFTC's jurisdiction, prompting the SEC and the exchanges it regulates to seek reform. Rep. Dennis E. Eckart, D-Ohio, said he and Rep. Dan Glickman, D-Kan., would introduce ``comprehensive institutional reform between the SEC and the CFTC to give jursdiction for all these hybrid instruments to one agency.'' Glickman said said he didn't want to give the jurisdiction to either the SEC or CFTC but sought to ``establish a new federal regulatory body to oversee futures options, securities and related instruments.'' He said the proposed legislation was still in the formative stages and a long way from being introduced. ``Until we see something of a concrete nature, we really can't comment. It would be premature,'' said CFTC spokesman David Gary. He added: ``We continue to support the concept of exclusive jurisdiction.'' The proposed bill with the program trading reforms was an outgrowth of the 1987 stock market crash. It also would require securities firms to keep and supply information to federal regulators about the financial health of their parent holding companies. A similar market reform bill, but without a program trading provision, is pending before the Senate. The program trading amendment would limit SEC control powers to activities previously determined to cause or contribute to extraordinary volatility _ that is, sharp rises and drops in stock prices. Such a determination would be made through the SEC's often time consuming rule-making procedure of public hearings, comment letter and staff review. The change satisfied Rep. Norman Lent, R-N.Y., whose objections to anti-program trading language in a previous version of the bill prevented its quick approval by the full committee last fall. At that time, he and other members of the telecommunications and finance subcommittee, argued that language introduced by Rep. Edward J. Markey, D-Mass., the subcommittee chairman, was vague and ambiguous. Originally Markey wanted to limit activity that was ``disruptive, abusive or manipulative.'' Markey said the new language was worked out after three months of negotiations among committee Democrats and Republicans, the SEC and the securities industry. ``I can't say I'm thrilled with the version we have before us, but it's a long way from the original version,'' said Lent. The bill also empowers the SEC to obtain information and monitor large securities transactions and to halt trading, with the president's assent, during market emergencies.

DOC.HEAD: Aid Agency Goes into Investment Banking
LaserPhoto NY16 of March 13
DOC.TEXT: CARE, famous for donating food, digging canals and building hospitals in the Third World, has devised a new form of aid for the 1990s: debt relief, investment banking and venture capital. The New York-based nonprofit organization has formed a subsidiary aimed at assisting heavily indebted developing countries devise innovative ways to reduce dependence on foreign loans. CARE's Small Business Assistance Corp. also can help foreign lenders recover some of the money they have sunk into Latin America and other black holes of debt over the years, subsidiary president Donald Nicholson said. The subsidiary invests in small and medium-sized businesses, from fruit canners in Honduras to shrimp farmers in the Philippines, when invited by the host country. It also is exploring business ventures in other countries undergoing profound political change, including Poland and Nicaragua. Philanthropy and finance experts said the CARE subsidiary is the first investment banking venture formed by an international relief group to help developing countries become more self-reliant. Still, with total Third World foreign debt of $1.2 trillion, CARE's effort is expected to have only a symbolic impact at first. ``I've never heard of a relief group doing this,'' said an official at the World Bank in Washington, who asked not to be quoted by name. ``But we've always said that anything helps. Any sensible approach with the interests of all parties at hand, building small bridges, is welcomed.'' The CARE subsidiary will hold a minority stake in companies it invests in and will concentrate on businesses worth $250,000 to $2.5 million. Foreign banks and other creditors that contribute to the subsidiary's investment fund will receive dividends if the businesses are profitable. ``We're not going to solve the problems of heavily indebted Third World countries,'' Nicholson said. ``But we bring a unique approach to the Third World crisis because we're not for profit.'' Nicholson said he has talked with Citibank, Chase Manhattan Bank and Bankers Trust about restructuring part of their Third World debt through the CARE subsidiary. He said CARE's clean reputation and cultural sensitivity in foreign countries give it advantages that larger, for-profit companies might never obtain. ``We are identifying existing, viable businesses in the developing world and investing in them, especially those that can earn hard currency through exports,'' he said. ``Profits realized from this will be used to fund CARE development projects around the world.'' The CARE venture coincides with economic shifts making it more difficult for developing countries to get aid from their industralized counterparts, putting increased pressure on philanthropies and volunteer groups to fill the breach. Many large Western banks, for example, burned by billions of dollars in bad loans to Latin America, are toughening terms for extending more credit. The United States, historically a leading source of aid to the developing world, is becoming more stingy because of its large federal deficit. A number of banks have sought to reduce Third World debt exposure by converting some debt into local currency to be invested domestically. Others have tinkered with ways of repackaging or swapping debt for other types of securities, such as the stock of a company based in a debtor country. ``What CARE has done has in effect set up its own specific mechanism to carry out these type of transactions,'' said Peter J. Davies, president and chief executive officer of InterAction, a New York-based coalition of 120 private voluntary relief organizations. James McDermott, a banking analyst at the New York investment firm Keefe Bruyette & Woods, said most major banks already have taken steps to protect themselves from Third World loans. But he said they are always looking at other ways to reduce the risk. ``The whole process is chipping away at exposure,'' he said. ``This (CARE subsidiary) seems to be part of that process.'' Nicholson, a 51-year-old American raised in Peru, long has been active in Third World investment banking. He founded Axion Group, a venture capital firm that invests in developing countries. CARE, the acronym for the Cooperative for American Relief Everywhere Inc., is is one of the biggest international aid groups, formed at the end of World War II to send emergency supplies to refugees. Its 7,200 employees and thousands of volunteers worldwide now distribute more than $300 million worth of aid annually.

DOC.HEAD: Reynolds Metals' Annual Report Offers More than Charts and Tables
DOC.TEXT: Investors who get tired of looking at the endless charts and tables in corporate financial reports will find some relief in Reynolds Metals Co.'s annual review: coupons for the company's supermarket products. For the shareholder who also pushes a grocery cart, Reynolds is offering savings up to $1.50 off its Reynolds Wrap aluminum foil and two new products. Tucked between the listings of ``shipments and net sales by year'' and ``equity, interest and other income'' in the company's 1989 annual report released last week are three 50-cents-off coupons for the foil, Sure-Seal plastic storage bags and ``Crystal Color'' plastic wrap. The plastic wrap comes in clear, blue, green, yellow and rose. The colors satisfy the desires of consumers ``to enliven mundane work,'' the company said in a summary of its consumer products business, which had $723 million in sales last year, up from $591 million in 1988. T $6.2 billion Richmond-based company put its coupons in a pull-out insert along with a message from William O. Bourke, Reynolds' board chairman and chief executive officer.
