Reynolds ``would appreciate your support of our new products,'' Bourke's message said. ``We believe you will appreciate the Reynolds quality that has made our consumer products so successful.''

DOC.HEAD: Group Launches Proxy Battle For Avon
DOC.TEXT: A group of powerful investors, including the owners of Mary Kay Cosmetics and a Getty family trust, has come through on its promise to launch a proxy battle seeking four seats on the board of Avon Products Inc. In a full-page advertisement in today's editions of The New York Times, Chartwell Associates L.P. said its directors, if elected, would work to ``maximize shareholder value'' by selling Avon to a buyer who can develop the company's ``true potential.'' The group noted it may propose merging with Avon itself. Chartwell said it currently holds 9.9 percent of the company's outstanding stock, making it one of Avon's largest shareholders. The proxy battle does not come as a surprise. Chartwell outlined its plans for a contest in a filing last month with the Securities and Exchange Commission. At the time Chartwell controlled 9.1 percent of Avon's stock. Partners in Chartwell Associates include the Fisher real estate family of New York as well as the family trust of oil heir Gordon P. Getty and a subsidiary of Dallas-based Mary Kay Corp., the parent of Mary Kay Cosmetics. Avon Chairman James E. Preston had met Chartwell representatives last month and told the group New York-based Avon is not for sale. In its ad, Chartwell said it will seek four seats on Avon's 11-member board. In criticizing Avon management, Chartwell noted that the company's stock price declined 39 percent from a high of $56 a share in 1979 to $34 at the end of last week. Earnings per share fluctuated from $4.17 in 1979 to $2.10 last year, the group said. In addition, Chartwell complained that Avon spent more than $1.2 billion to expand into heathcare and specialty chemical businesses but then was forced to dispose of some of those businesses after losing more than $1 billion. ``We believe that Avon's current board and management simply do not understand their core direct-selling business and its enormous potential and will not be able to deliver the performance they have promised,'' Chartwell said in the ad. Preston recently told securities analysts that Avon expects profits to improve ``substantially'' this year on a modest increase in sales. Preston had emphasized in his meeting with Chartwell that Avon's sales representatives wouldn't welcome any link to Mary Kay whatsoever. He said Mary Kay had become ``the enemy'' to Avon representatives. Chartwell has maintained that it would not propose combining Avon and Mary Kay. Chartwell said in its SEC filing that ``in no event ... will Mary Kay or Mary Kay Cosmetics Inc. merge with the company nor will the sales forces of the company and MKCI be integrated or combined with each other in any manner whatsoever.'' Last year Avon earned $54.6 million after a deficit of $404.5 million in 1988 when it had $545.6 million in losses from discontinued operations. Among other Avon shareholders with significant holdings are Minneapolis investor Irwin Jacobs and Texas financier Robert Bass.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Says It Will Talk With Union At Mediator's Request
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound Lines Inc. agreed to resume talks with the union representing its bus drivers for the first time since the violence-marred walkout began nearly two weeks ago. The Dallas-based company said Tuesday it had agreed to begin the talks Saturday in Phoenix at the request of Bernard DeLury, head of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service. The company's announcement seemed to catch union officials off guard. ``If this is true, we welcome the opportunity to talk to the company. This is what we have been seeking all along,'' said James La Sala, international president of the Amalgamated Transit Union. At least seven shooting incidents have been reported since the strike began March 2, including one in Florida where eight people were injured. A picketing driver was crushed to death by a bus on the second day of the strike. On Tuesday, a sniper shot at a moving Greyhound bus in Chicago. In Fresno, Calif., a Greyhound-owned Trailways bus parked in a storage yard was set on fire Monday night, police said. No one was injured in either episode. Greyhound had refused to resume negotiations unless the union offered new proposals. Spokesman George Gravley had said Tuesday he did not know if the union had changed its offer. ``There's no point in our speculating what may happen,'' Gravley said. ``We are going back to the bargaining table and that speaks for itself.'' Greyhound, the only nationwide bus company, has been operating on a reduced schedule to the 9,600 communities it serves, using permanent replacements and union members willing to cross the picket line. Greyhound has said it cannot afford more than the $63 million, three-year pact it offered. The company valued the union's last offer at $207 million, although the union said it would cost much less. The differences apparently stem from questions over the cost of measures such as benefits, safety pay incentives and productivity raises. In the shooting, at 1:15 a.m., two bullets hit the front end of the bus, one hit the door and one went through a window and ``just missed a fellow's head by a couple inches,'' said Master Sgt. John Meduga of the Illinois State Police. ``Everybody started to scream,'' Meduga said. Gravley said he had no evidence to connect the latest shooting to the strike, but added, ``We don't have buses shot at when we're not negotiating a contract.'' Union officials have condemned the violence, which has included three shootings in Chicago and shootings in Ohio, Arizona, Florida and Connecticut. Greyhound spokeswoman Liz Hale said a $25,000 reward remained in effect for information on a sniper who shot a bus Sunday in Jacksonville, Fla., injuring eight passengers with shrapnel and other debris. In Pittsburgh, meanwhile, the city council issued a resolution encouraging residents to boycott Greyhound buses until the strike is over. The council accused Greyhound of an ``utter lack of good faith toward its employees.''

DOC.HEAD: Nabisco Will Not Revive Ads Considered Misleading
DOC.TEXT: An actor playing a heart attack victim tells the TV camera that Fleischmann's corn oil margarine commercial ``does your heart good.'' You won't be seeing him any more. The attorneys general of 10 states, including New York, complained that the ad doesn't do consumers good. It's confusing, they said. Nabisco Brands agreed Tuesday not to revive that ad, as well as commercials that tout the health benefits and nutrition of Shredded Wheat and 100 Percent Bran Cereal. New York Attorney General Robert Abrams said Nabisco advertisements ``misled consumers to believe that its Fleischmann's margarine could, by itself, reduce cholesterol and prevent heart disease.'' He said Nabisco also misrepresented the fiber content of Shredded Wheat and implied that 100 Percent Bran is sweetened exclusively with natural fruit juices. The corporation agreed to shelve the commercials but admitted nothing. Hank Sandbach, a spokesman for Nabisco, said: ``Consumer Reports said Shredded Wheat had `plenty of fiber,' and our advertising said that a leading magazine called the cereal `high in fiber.''' As for 100 Percent Bran, Sandbach said the Nabisco advertising claim that the product was ``sweetened with two natural fruit juices'' in no way implied the absence of other sweeteners. Nabisco signed the agreement with the 10 states and agreed to pay $135,000 in legal costs. Under the agreement, Nabisco promised: _not to broadcast television commercials for Fleischmann's corn oil margarine that use the phrase ``head start to a healthier heart'' and ``does your heart good''; _not to state or imply that the products will ``cure, mitigate, treat, prevent or reduce the risk of heart disease or cause a reduction in cholesterol;'' _not to advertise that ``a leading consumer magazine'' has concluded that Shredded Wheat is ``high'' in fiber; _not to advertise 100 Percent Bran as ``flavored with two naturally sweet fruit juices'' unless or until such sweeteners are used exclusively. The agreement also was signed by the attorneys general of California, Florida, Illinois, Iowa, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Missouri, Texas and Wisconsin. Hank Sandbach, a spokesman for the New York-based company, said that under the agreement, Nabisco did not admit to any wrongdoing. He also said the advertisements, on television and on box tops, had not been used for nearly a year. ``They were retired for market reasons,'' he said. ``They'd done their job and ran their course.'' The Nabisco agreement came a week after the federal Food and Drug Administration announced plans for sweeping changes in food-labeling laws that would require information on fat and cholesterol on many foods.

DOC.HEAD: Christies Auction House Posts Higher 1989 Profit
DOC.TEXT: Christies International PLC, the British auction house, said Wednesday that strong sales in its major art categories helped push its 1989 profit up 60 percent from a year ago. Christies said last year's net profit totaled $64 million, compared with $40 million in 1988. Sales soared 71 percent to $2.1 billion from $1.25 billion, it said. ``These results mark an outstanding year at the end of a remarkable decade,'' said Christies Chairman Lord Carrington. Impressionist and modern art, the single largest area of sales, recorded an 88 percent rise to $844 million last year. Contemporary art increased 143 percent to $188 million, while Old Masters jumped 125 percent to $153 million. The company didn't break out quarterly or six month results. It isn't required to under British law.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Mulling Verdict in Challenge to S&L Bailout
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf pvs, The judge ..., to restore dropped `not.' A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge is taking a constitutional challenge of President Bush's savings and loan bailout under consideration after acknowledging the tremendous impact of a ruling against the government. Olympic Federal Savings and Loan Association of Berwyn, Ill., asked U.S. District Judge Royce C. Lamberth on Tuesday to block any federal takeover of the weakly capitalized S&L. Its attorneys argued that the top federal S&L regulator is holding his position unconstitutionally and thus any move by him to seize Olympic would be illegal. Government attorneys disputed the argument, but said that in any case the public interest in seeing the S&L bailout progress overrides any points Olympic might be able to win. ``A ruling that no one in the Office of Thrift Supervision has authority to act would be an invitation to chaos,'' said Aaron B. Kahn, a lawyer for the agency. He said a decision favoring Olympic would open the floodgates to scores of similar suits. The government has seized 393 failed S&Ls in the past year, 131 of them since the Aug. 9 enactment of President Bush's bailout bill, which Olympic is challenging. Lamberth, after listening to more than two hours of oral arguments, said he would rule by March 21. That is when his March 7 temporary order blocking immediate seizure of Olympic expires. The judge did not indicate which way he was leaning. But he said the public interest issue was the most difficult in the case, which if decided as Olympic urged, would have a ``tremendous impact.'' Former Justice Department attorney Charles J. Cooper, representing Olympic, said, he recognized the far-reaching implications, but added, ``It's not as wildly devastating as the (government) would have you think.'' He argued that the Constitution protects the rights of individual citizens, or in this case a savings institution, even at the expense of taxpayers and the public in general. In any case, the added expense of delaying the seizure of Olympic, when compared with the overall cost of the S&L bailout, ``takes something which is a raging inferno and tosses a cigarette into it,'' Cooper said. Olympic is disputing the constitutional authority of acting thrift office director Salvatore R. Martoche as well as the director he replaced, M. Danny Wall. The new S&L law provided that Wall, who was chairman of the old Federal Home Loan Bank Board, would inherit the directorship of the thrift office without being reappointed by the president and reconfirmed by the Senate. However, Cooper said Wall's appointment, in effect, died because the agency he headed was abolished. He said Martoche's temporary appointment, after Wall quit earlier this month, would have been valid had Wall been properly appointed. But in this case Martoche is filling a new position, a situation not covered by the temporary appointments law, Cooper said. Olympic, with $1.1 billion in assets, was created in 1982 by the merger of two weak thrifts. Its home base, Berwyn, is a Chicago suburb. In another case, filed Monday in U.S. District Court in Topeka, Kan., Franklin Savings Association of Ottawa, Kan., also challenged Wall's constitutional authority. The government seized Franklin, with about $9 billion in assets, last month.

DOC.HEAD: Recently Merged SmithKline Beecham's Profit Sinks 65 Percent
DOC.TEXT: SmithKline Beecham PLC reported Wednesday that its profit for 1989 declined 65 percent over a year ago due largely to heavy costs associated with the recent merger of the health, household products and pharmaceuticals company. The company said its net profit totaled $209 million, compared with $591 million in 1988. Sales, however, rose 14 percent to $7.9 billion from $6.9 billion. The full-year results were the first for the company since its merger in July 1989. Britain's Beecham Group PLC and Philadelphia-based SmithKline Bechman Corp. merged through an exchange of shares, creating the world's second-largest pharmaceuticals company after Rahway, N.J.-based Merck & Co. SmithKline Beecham said the year-earlier financial statements were presented as if the merger had taken place at the beginning of January 1988. The 1989 results included an $805 million restructuring charge as a result of the combination for closing some of its facilities, cutting staff and writing down certain assets. SnithKline Beecham said it also took a $124 million extraordinary loss due to merger transaction costs.

The stock market gained ground today, rebounding from Tuesday's mild setback. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 12.61 to 2,687.16 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 8 to 7 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 467 up, 406 down and 533 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 21.39 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. The market retreated Tuesday as interest rates came under new upward pressure in the credit markets. But rates levelled off or declined slightly in early activity today, giving some encouragement to stock traders. Most analysts agree that stocks have benefited lately from hopes that the economy could emerge from its recent period of weakness without having to undergo a full-blown recession. Brokers say that kind of optimism would be buttressed if interest rates do not go much higher than their current levels. Gainers among the blue chips included General Motors, up \ at 47]; DuPont, up \ at 39[; International Business Machines, up { at 106}, and Philip Morris, up [ at 37}. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .30 to 185.55. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .41 at 361.20. On Tuesday the Dow Jones industrial average fell 12.16 to 2,674.55. Declining issues outnumbered advancers by about 8 to 5 on the NYSE, with 555 up, 899 down and 502 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 145.44 million shares, against 114.79 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Japanese Firms to Participate in Boeing 777 Project
DOC.TEXT: A consortium of three Japanese companies plan to invest about $825 million in the development of Boeing Co.'s proposed 777 jet, according to a published report. The nationally circulated newspaper Asahi Shimbun reported Tuesday that the three companies, led by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd., will inform Seattle-based Boeing by the end of the month of their intention to participate in the project. The newspaper identified the two other companies as Kawasaki Heavy Industries Ltd. and Fuji Heavy Industries Ltd. Officials of the companies were not immediately available Wednesday to comment on the report. Asahi said Boeing had asked the three Japanese firms to undertake 25 percent of the estimated $3.3 billion development cost of the project, or about $825 million. The Boeing project calls for development of a new jet with a 300- to 350-passenger capacity. The Japanese firms plan to ask the Japanese government for financial assistance if they participate in the project, Asahi said. Japan's government already has spent about $46 million since 1986 in a development project involving the three companies and Boeing of a separate jet, the B7J7, which would have a capacity of 150 passengers, Asahi said. The costs and risks of development of new airliners have become so great that single companies can rarely undertake such projects alone.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 435.27 up .69 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil Closes Banks In Advance of Inauguration
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 16 grafs for 8-16 pvs, Ms. Cardoso ... million workers, to ADD newspaper accounts of measures, delegations arriving. No Pickup. A version moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Two days before President-elect Fernando Collor de Mello takes office, the nation's banks were ordered closed to try to stabilize markets in advance of his emergency economic package. Analysts said the three-day bank holiday, announced Tuesday night, was in response to large-scale withdrawals from banks. The Central Bank also announced the cruzado, the national currency, would be devalued 10.7 percent effective Monday, when banks reopen. By Tuesday evening, lines stretched for blocks at automatic bank machines in major cities with people trying to get cash for the next several days. Withdrawals were limited to the equivalent of $47 per person per day. Collor de Mello, Brazil's first directly elected president in almost 30 years, has promised free-market economic reforms to try to bring down a 2,700 percent inflation rate. He takes office Thursday and plans to announce his emergency economic plan to Congress the next day. The three-day bank holiday was decreed by Zelia Cardoso de Mello, the nation's new economic minister. ``The bank holiday was declared to preserve the stability of markets until the whole package of measures is announced,'' she said. ``In the past few days, there has been a great deal of speculative activity and we wanted to calm the market down.'' Ms. Cardoso de Mello, no relation to the president-elect, offered no further information about the new economic proposals, which are expected to include selling off inefficient state companies, firing thousands of public employees and making huge spending cuts. Newspaper reports in all major dailies said today the economic measures were expected to include: _A wage and price index, which would increase by a set amount each month, perhaps preceded by a brief wage-and-price freeze. _An increase in utility and fuel rates. This was expected to include a 30 percent jump in electricity prices and a 70 percent increase for fuel. _A new tax on bank profits and corporte earnings. _Elimination of the estimated $2.2 billion in government subsidies, and suspension for one year of all fiscal incentives, which cost the federal treasury $5.5 billion yearly. _A devaluation of the new cruzado by 30 percent, an effort to make Brazilian exports more competitive. _The introduction of a new national currency _ the fourth in as many years _to replace the new cruzado. Investors, uneasy about Collor de Mello's economic plans, have withdrawn money from short-term deposits to speculate in gold and the illegal but tolerated black market for dollars, causing wild swings in their values in recent weeks. Brazil's government is operating with a $31 billion deficit and has a $114 billion foreign debt, the world's largest. Business leaders have expressed concern about a possible wage-and-price freeze, the basis of four failed anti-inflationary plans by the outgoing administration of Jose Sarney. Both the president-elect and Ms. Cardoso de Mello have denied they will implement a freeze. The devaluation was much larger than normal. Officials have devalued the cruzado about 2 percent daily to keep up with inflation. Brazil, with about 150 million people, has been wracked for years by persistently high inflation that has outpaced wage increases. An active labor movement has struck frequently for higher salaries and benefits. Of Brazil's 60-million-member work force, the leftist Central Workers Union and the more moderate General Workers Center claim to represent close to 35 million workers. Foreign delegations began arriving on Wednesday for Collor's inauguration. Cuban President Fidel Castro was among the first to arrive. In all, 121 countries will be sending delegations and 27 heads of state o government have said they will attend.

DOC.HEAD: Steel Maker Merges With French Company
DOC.TEXT: J&L Specialty Products Corp. has agreed to be acquired by the French stainless steel producer Ugine ACG. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. J&L, which announced the merger on Tuesday, said it would keep its Pittsburgh headquarters and Paris-based Ugine would appoint a new board of directors. ``The change in ownership should have no adverse effect on our employment levels or the continued operation of J&L's steelmaking and finishing facilities,'' J&L President Claude Kronk said in a statement. J&L was spun off from steel giant LTV Corp. of Dallas in 1986 and purchased by Citicorp Capital Investors. It employs 1,300 and had sales of $848.7 million for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30. Kronk said the deal is expected to be completed June 15, subject to approval of the board of directors of Citicorp Capital and Ugine and federal regulators.

DOC.HEAD: U995
DOC.TEXT: The spot month contract for West Texas Intermediate crude was $20.15 per barrel at 12 p.m. EDT Wednesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Extend Losses
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were modestly lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade. The declines extended the previous session's losses in response to improved U.S. crop weather. Stormy conditions and unseasonably warm temperatures prevailed in the eastern half of the country, bringing moisture to the wheat fields of the Great Plains and the still-unplanted corn and soybean regions of the Midwest. A sharp drop in soybean oil prices, reflecting adequate supplies, put additional pressure on soybean futures prices. Soybean oil for March delivery was down 23 cents at $21.68 per hundredweight in early trading. The beginning of the Brazilian soybean harvest, which will bring new supplies to market, also is weighing on the soybean market. In early trading, wheat futures were \ cent to 2{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $3.78{ a bushel; corn futures were 1\ cents to 2{ cents lower with March at $2.42{ a bushel; oats were } cent to 1{ cents lower with March at $1.44} a bushel; soybean futures were 2\ cents to 3\ cents lower with March at $5.75{ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were narrowly mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle futures were .25 cent lower to .25 cent higher with April at 78.15 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .25 cent lower to .02 cent higher with March at 83.15 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent lower to .18 cent higher with April at 53 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .30 cent lower to .10 cent higher with March at 52.55 cents a pound. Cattle futures advanced on Tuesday while pork futures retreated.

DOC.HEAD: TWA Pilots Say No To Secret Talks
DOC.TEXT: The first meeting between leaders of the pilots union at Trans World Airlines Inc. and the company's new chief operating officer collapsed Tuesday because of a dispute about the confidentiality of their discussions. Kent Scott, chairman of the TWA branch of the Air Line Pilots Association, said Chief Operating Officer William Hoar unexpectedly demanded that the union's executive council keep all remarks secret from the rank and file. ``We simply couldn't live with that kind of a gag order,'' Scott said. Although Scott offered to keep some information confidential, Hoar and two TWA officials who accompanied him decided to leave the union's headquarters in St. Louis and fly back to New York. TWA has corporate offices in Mt. Kisco, N.Y. Scott said he was puzzled by the turn of events and added that he did not know what Hoar might have been planning to tell the union leaders if they granted his request. ``He agreed to this six weeks ago and then five minutes before the meeting he wanted to change the ground rules,'' Scott said. Hoar said Monday that he planned to appeal to the pilots for concessions and to outline specific measures that managers were taking to strengthen TWA. Union leaders invited Hoar to come to St. Louis and discuss the outlook for TWA when he was appointed chief operating officer in January. Hoar's actions Tuesday should not damage relations between the pilots union and TWA, Scott said, but they could delay a presentation to the executive council until June. On Monday, the 12 members of the executive council elected Scott to a two-year term as chairman. He had been acting chairman since late August, when his predecessor, Tom Ashwood, was recalled. The council members who voted to oust Ashwood were concerned that his deteriorating relationship with TWA owner Carl Icahn had undermined his ability to negotiate with the company. But Scott also has taken a relatively hard line in his dealings with Icahn, criticizing the investor's management of TWA and his call for further concessions from workers. Scott said Monday that the $80 million in concessions that Icahn is seeking from the pilots would do little to resolve TWA's problems. ``TWA's financial woes in no way relate to the pilots' wages and working conditions,'' he said. ``They are instead the predictable result of Icahn's 1988 privatization transaction, which crippled the company with more than $2.6 billion in debt, much of it through `junk borrowing,' and simultaneously extracted more than $650 million in cash from the airline.'' Scott has maintained that Icahn intends to dismantle TWA and is trying to make it appear as though the pilots are forcing him to sell assets by refusing to accept concessions.

DOC.HEAD: Layoffs Expected in Reorganization
DOC.TEXT: Georgia-Pacific said it will reorganize its pulp and paper business along product lines in a move that will include some layoffs, and expects to sell some assets this year. ``Surely there will be some reductions in force,'' A.D. Correll, executive vice president of Georgia-Pacific's pulp and paper unit, said Tuesday. Correll said Georgia-Pacific has not determined how many people will lose their jobs. He said the reductions would be at both Georgia-Pacific and Great Northern Nekoosa Corp., which Georgia-Pacific acquired for almost $4 billion earlier this month. Correll made the comments after meeting with securities analysts in New York to discuss the acquisition. The restructuring is intended to help Georgia-Pacific improve profits as it tries to reduce debt from the takeover. T. Marshall Hahn Jr., Georgia-Pacific's chairman and chief executive, told the analysts that all businesses, plants and timberland are being reviewed and that sales of some ``non-strategic assets'' were expected. Hahn said the merger of the two companies would save more than the $80 million annually that Georgia-Pacific had estimated.

DOC.HEAD: Rostenkowski Calls on Public to Support His Plan to Slash Budget Deficit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 5th graf pvs `The Bush... to UPDATE with Bush comment; PICKS UP 6th graf pvs, `House Speaker...
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Dan Rostenkowski called on the American public today to voice support for his plan to slash the budget deficit by raising taxes and cutting federal spending. ``What the American people have to do is show their reaction to their representatives,'' the chairman of the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee said on NBC-TV's ``Today'' show. ``There's a timidity on Capitol Hill that is somewhat frightening,'' he said. ``You worry about the next election but I don't think you should be committed to it to the point where you're going to lose the national interest.'' Rostenkowski, D-Ill., read one telegram he received that said, ``I'm 83 years old. I don't care if you're an old dog, you have courage. Go for it, you're doing the right thing.'' The Bush administration has shown interest in negotiating about Rostenkowski's plan, but Democratic leaders have shown only luke-warm support for it. Bush, asked today about conflicting signals the White House has sent on the Rostenkowski plan, told reporters, ``Read all the tea leaves. Listen to the nuances. It's out there very clearly.'' He made the comment after touring a power plant in Aquasco, Md. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley says White House interest in Rostenkowski's proposal is meaningless unless President Bush joins with the lawmaker and supports a tax increase. ``The president is the key and indispensable participant in any effort to reduce the deficit, and that includes taxes,'' Foley, D-Wash., said Tuesday. Unless Bush renounces his no-tax pledge, ``Chairman Rostenkowski's proposal cannot be enacted,'' he said. Rostenkowski, D-Ill., on Sunday proposed to eliminate federal deficits by raising federal income and excise taxes, freezing domestic programs for one year including Social Security benefits, and cutting defense spending. ``We face big problems that can't be solved with nickel-and-dime solutions,'' Rostenkowski said Tuesday. ``Nothing less than our childrens' future standards of living are at stake.'' Bush, meantime, continued his administration's positive reaction to Rostenkowski's proposal. He called it a bold initiative with ``evident good will and determination to try to break the ice and move the process forward.'' But the president also reiterated his opposition to raising taxes, and steered clear of endorsing any specific element of the proposal. White House budget director Richard Darman, speaking at a news briefing, emphasized the seriousness with which the administration was taking the plan, and even hinted there might be new fees beyond those already in the president's budget which Bush might not consider tax hikes. The comments by administration officials made clear they would much prefer to negotiate on the budget with Rostenkowski than with other, more partisan congressional Democrats. But Foley said he intended to proceed with the normal budget process in the House. A great deal of the White House response ``had to do with friendship between Mr. Rostenkowski and the president. That doesn't speak of any substantive change on the part of the president to consider new taxes,'' Foley said. Other Democratic leaders echoed Foley's sentiments toward Bush. No one came forward to endorse the deficit plan except as a serious proposal. Congressional Republicans, meantime, took advantage of the administration ability to keep the Rostenkowski plan in the news by issuing statements attacking Democrats on its politically toughest points. ``I see this as simply affirmation of the basic Democratic agenda: raise taxes, continue the growth of Democratic programs and if necessary cut Social Security to do it,'' said Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas.

DOC.NOTE: $adv18
For release Sunday March 18
DOC.HEAD: Economic Boom of 1980s Ends With Closures, Unemployment
Graphic, LaserPhoto
First of a Three-Day Series
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: It's the Year of the Horse, but the turtle might be a more fitting symbol for China's economy as it enters the 1990s with millions of factories shutting down and workers idled. Boomtown China, with its ubiquitous construction cranes and conspicuous consumption, has given way to a cash-starved economy pushed to the brink of recession by a government determined to curb inflation. Inflation is falling: retail prices were up about 7 percent by yearend, about a third of the official inflation rate for the previous two years. But the process of curbing it has brought new problems equally troubling the government, which showed through its violent suppression of a pro-democracy movement nearly a year ago that it values stability above all. Unemployment and indebtedness have grown sharply and productivity has fallen. The 1980s entrepreneurial spirit has subsided, replaced by renewed emphasis on central planning and political correctness. The government began its attack on inflation in late 1988 by ordering sharp cuts in construction, official spending and loans. But the full impact hit in the last quarter of 1989, when industrial output grew at an annual rate of less than 1 percent, vs. nearly 21 percent for all of 1988. In a series of emergency moves, the government loaned state companies nearly $27 billion at the end of the year and ordered factories to recall laid-off workers even if they had nothing to do. This month, Premier Li Peng hinted at an early end to the retrenchment, which was to have lasted three years, when he called for development to be brought ``back to a reasonable pace.'' More significant economic shifts may be disclosed at the upcoming National People's Congress session. ``They were running into a recession, but they pulled up at the last minute,'' said a Western economic analyst, speaking on condition of anonymity. She said local governments also cushioned the shock by loaning money to the worst-hit companies and helping others merge or restructure. ``There seems to be a lot of flexibility in the system to create safety nets,'' she said. But others believe restarting the engine will not be that easy. ``Before people were on a roll. They were willing to say, `Let's do it.' It took 10 years for people to forget,'' that making decisions could be risky, said a Western diplomat. Now, they've been reminded, and ``everyone wants to wait for the central government's say-so.'' So far, the economic slowdown is less apparent in the shops, which remain full, than in the warehouses. Televisions, refrigerators, electric fans, bicycles, rugs and dozens of other products in high demand a year ago are piling up in storehouses as consumers heed the government's call to spend less and save more. The result has been to idle millions of workers making the no-longer-popular items. In January, China made 40 percent fewer color TVs than in January 1989 and about half as many cars, washing machines and refrigerators, state statistics show. Government officials say privately that unemployment among urban workers is 4 percent and growing, but the figure would be much higher if it includd the millions who spend their days doing unproductive work _ cleaning workshops, studying political documents, playing cards. Rural authorities have organized tree planting and water conservancy projects to occupy the millions of peasants sent home from city construction teams or laid off from tiny rural factories that were the first casualties of the austerity. Workers with jobs also have felt pinched. Wages have failed to pace even the reduced inflation. The Foreign Employment Service Corp. in Shanghai, which supplies personnel for foreign employers, stopped paying wages for months. A shoe factory in Shanghai paid its workers in shoes, which they tried to hawk on the main shopping street. Angry workers have sought permission to demonstrate in several cities, Chinese sources say, and unconfirmed reports describe actual marches in the northeast, China's heavy-industry heartland. Authorities deny the reports. They acknowledge, however, that many factories are in trouble. Nationwide, companies owe each other a total of $21 billion because cash-poor banks won't release funds. Yao Fugen, president of the Shanghai No. 1 Sewing Machine Factory, doesn't ship any machines now unless he's paid first. Denied credit by banks, he also borrowed more than $3 million from customers, swapped sewing machines for pig iron and began test-manufacturing fishing rods as a hedge against the soft sewing machine market. The government says manufacturers who show ingenuity will survive and inefficient ones will fail, ultimately benefiting the economy. In practice, the survivors are state-owned factories, notorious for inefficiency, while millions of private, collective and other non-state factories have closed. Banks refuse them loans, and they find it harder than ever to get raw materials because the government has recentralized distribution. Authorities are trying to improve productivity at the state factories by stepping up Marxist education among the workers and reviving the past art of elevating labor heros. But at three large state factories in Shanghai, the industrial heart of China, Communist Party secretaries said Marxist study was mainly limited to party members. Western analysts agree that action was needed to cool inflation, but they worry the government will hit the pump again without correcting any basic problems, such as irrational prices and taxes. A Western diplomat predicted, ``They may go through all this pain with nothing to show for it.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Sunday March 18
$adv19
For release Monday March 19
DOC.HEAD: Foreign Businesses Increasingly Frustrated
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Second in a three-day series.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: A faltering economy and resurgence of anti-capitalist sentiment are adding to China's already formidible reputation as a difficult place to invest. The government is wooing foreign investment and technology as fervently as ever, and most analysts agree that China needs and wants Western help to modernize. But its efforts to curb inflation and shortages of key raw materials have reversed free-market reforms of recent years, once again miring foreign businessmen in socialist red tape. Moreover, the conservative backlash to last year's mass protests for democratic reform has revived official suspicion and resentment of foreigners. ``There's a faction ... that believes the foreigners have been getting too good a deal and should be controlled,'' said a Western lawyer resident in Shanghai, speaking on condition of anonymity. Another lawyer said Chinese bureaucrats told him they could not process foreign business quickly because ``they're afraid of being seen as Zhao Ziyang's running dogs.'' Zhao was ousted in June as Communist Party chief, blamed for excessive liberalism that helped spawn the democracy movement. Authorities sent one foreign company a letter admonishing it not to look for profit in China. ``Every penny you make as a foreign investor (the Chinese) look at as a penny out of their pocket,'' said a Western diplomat. Several major American companies say they are thinking of pulling out. ``We're not here on a welfare basis,'' said one American manager, who did not want his company named before a decision is made. He said efforts to mend problems with the Chinese partner reminded him of ``a child trying to keep his parents together when maybe it's the best thing for them to divorce.'' Another joint venture's foreign board members voted to dissolve the venture but the Chinese side refused. A small U.S. family-owned company simply walked away in frustration from its China joint venture, not bothering to formally dissolve ties. New investment contracts have been signed since June, when the army attack on student protesters in Beijing chilled Chinese-foreign relations, but they are down sharply from the pre-June pace. One problem is that government signals are confusing. The National People's Congress, China's legislature, is expected to amend the joint venture law to pledge not to nationalize them and to let foreigners to serve as chairmen. Businessmen call these positive moves. But an even more welcome proposal, to extend the 50-year limit on the life of joint ventures, faces stiff opposition and is not expected to pass. The government also has tightened controls on joint venture prices, imports and exports and purchases of domestic supplies _ treating them, in the words of one foreign expert, more and more as if they were state-owned companies. Shanghai Volkswagen was still waiting in early March for Beijing to decide its 1990 production quota and prices. Before last year, it needed only Shanghai city approval to change prices. The new controls are not just from the center of power. Shanghai approved new regulations last year giving the Communist Party-controlled unions the right to join in joint ventures' long-term planning sessions, and to intervene whenever a worker is disciplined or fired. Foreign businesses also have been hurt by last year's dramatic slowdown in Chinese economic growth, accompanied by a dramatic cut in bank loans and severe shortage of cash for even normal transactions. ``Our accounts receivable have gone right out the window,'' said the American manager of a Shanghai joint venture. ``We've sent teams out collecting. I know of a company that sends two people to sit in debtors' offices and tells them not to leave until they are paid.'' Some joint ventures have borrowed from foreign parent companies or from union funds, or have mortgaged assets in what amounts to a hand-to-mouth existence. But local authorities, equally desperate for funds, have hit on the joint ventures like piggy banks. Seacliff Limited, for example, a U.S.-Japanese partner in a new luxury hotel and office complex in Shanghai, has been told that for every car it imports for the hotel, it will have to donate two cars to local authorities. The center's general manager, Michael Kalyk, said the issue is under negotiation.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Monday March 19

DOC.HEAD: City Called a `Capitalist Tail' Still Wagging
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Last of a three-day series.
DOC.TEXT: Every year 20-year-old Sun Lili travels three days by bus and train to a factory near Canton to buy cartons of brightly colored hair trinkets and plastic jewelry. She hauls them back to Wenzhou, a port city midway up the Chinese coast, and resells them from her own private stall. Not many women her age in China have that much spunk, but not many young women earn 10,000 yuan or more than $2,100 a year either _ about five times the average worker's wage. In Wenzhou, however, Sun is far from extraordinary. Private business is the city's lifeblood and has been for generations, to hear residents talk. ``Since the Song dynasty Wenzhou has had a commodity economy,'' said Ma Jinlong, referring to the 10th century rulers of China. Ma is deputy director of the city Systems Restructuring Commission, another oddity _ not many cities as small and remote as Wenzhou have think-tanks to encourage private and other non-state enterprise. As a result, while private factories account for less than 5 percent of the nationwide industrial output, in Wenzhou they produce more than 32 percent. Most of the shops and restaurants are private, and tens of thousands of Wenzhou residents hit the road each year as traveling salesmen. Wenzhou, 250 miles south of Shanghai, seems to lack the requirements of a commercial center. It has no airport, although one is nearing completion, and no rail link. Visitors endure a 24-hour ferry ride from Shanghai or 10-hour drive from Hangzhou, to the northwest. ``You've heard of `capitalist tails'?'' asked a visiting Shanghai woman. That was what the radical leftists during the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution called anything that smacked of capitalism. ``Well, Wenzhou was a capitalist tail.'' During the mid-1980s, the city briefly became the tail that wagged the dog, as top officials and delegates from around China visited to observe the ``Wenzhou model'' for prosperity _ encouraging household-based small businesses. Then-premier and later Communist Party secretary Zhao Ziyang, a leading proponent of market reforms, visited in 1985. But Zhao was ousted last June, accused of embracing dangerous liberalism. His successor as party chief, Jiang Zemin, has made a point of visiting major state factories and revolutionary war bases. With the dual aim of curbing inflation and reviving Marxist spirit, the central government has cut off loans and supplies to non-state enterprises. It also has ordered deep cuts in spending and construction, pushing the national economy almost into recession. Wenzhou again is under a shadow. Authorities have begun policing its private businessmen more closely for tax evasion and smuggling, and some have been arrested or forced to close. Late last year, a Wenzhou man who ran a private credit union was executed. He apparently misused funds to build and furnish his home, but official reports of the case broadly criticized all private credit unions as ``speculative undertakings meant for reaping windfall profits.'' Yang Jiaxing, chairman of Wenzhou's Lucheng City Credit Cooperative, gets a frustrated look when he talks about profits. His credit union, founded in 1986 as China's first private banking operation, earned 1.3 million yuan or about $276,000 last year. But after taxes, it had $15,300 left to distribute among shareholders. ``We originally thought we'd make more,'' Yang said. But the number and size of taxes keep growing _ three more were added last year. Some Wenzhou residents have adjusted to the change. Others have shut down to wait for bitter times. More than half a million traveling salesmen have come home because of poor business, Ma said. But Wenzhou's private business sector has by no means folded. Hundreds of open-front family shops still line the narrow streets, their displays of shoes, stylish clothes, leather belts, buttons and toys pushing onto the sidewalks. A steady steam of tiny Polish-made Fiats navigate the streets with tinny horns beeping, most with private businessmen at the wheel. At night, noisy parties set off firecrackers outside a popular private restaurant, its sidewalk jammed with the motorcycles of well-off diners. ``They're too small and there's too many of them for the government to shut down,'' said one young woman. Private businessmen have little overhead, and many have enough savings to weather a few bad years, as long as they're not hounded and harassed out of existence. Sun Lili, too young to remember the Cultural Revolution, said she's not worried. ``I'm not selling anything bad,'' she said, fingering a velvet-covered headband.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Tuesday, Adv 20

DOC.HEAD: Digital Displays, Socialist Principles and Pingpong: Shanghai's Money Market
LaserPhoto
With BC-China-Capitalist Tail
DOC.TEXT: Faint murmurs rise from the floor. A voice intones, ``Now start trading.'' Figures flash on an electronic board: U.S. Dollars are selling for 5.91 yuan, the previous day's closing price and 1.2 yuan over the official exchange rate. Sellers are hawking $5.4 million and buyers want $5.3 million. A bank trims its sales offer, and the figures match. The price stays unchanged. It took two minutes. Within an hour, all the transactions have been processed and the clients have left the Shanghai currency exchange. Market employees relax with a noisy game of pingpong on a table in front of the big board, housed in an imposing former bank from the pre-Communist days when Shanghai was an Asian financial center. ``Our market is elementary, one could even say primitive,'' said Qiu Jirong, a young worker at the Shanghai Foreign Exchange Transaction Center. Nonetheless, it is the most sophisticated tool China has for matching up Chinese and foreign companies that need dollars with those that have dollars and need the local currency, renminbi. A yuan is the basic unit of renminbi. The renminbi, like most socialist countries' currencies, is not convertible on world markets, and Chinese banks hoard hard currencies because they are needed to buy foreign goods. Before China opened its first currency exchange markets in 1986, most foreign companies that earned renminbi on investments had no way to repatriate their profits. Shanghai's market is a model of what Chinese leaders hope to do generally as they reform the economy: borrow Western tools but keep socialist principles of central control. The center uses price as a balancing tool, but has little else in common with Western financial markets. Playing the market for profit is not allowed. Prices are set in isolation from world markets, and even from markets in other cities in China. Still, it's come a long way since 1986. Then, businessmen had to find their own partners to buy or sell currency. The center was just a place to register the deal, and prices varied widely. The currency exchange markets in other cities still stick to this model, but in 1988 Shanghai advanced to a more systematic and auction-like way of trading. Four mornings a week, banks and companies that are registered as members bring their buy and sell orders to the center. The center tallies them up. When dollar supply exceeds demand, it lowers the price of a dollar by one fen _ one-hundreth of a yuan _ every two minutes until some sellers withdraw or buyers enter. When demand for dollars exceeds supply, the price is raised. The price is fixed when buy and sell offers balance, and all trades are made at the same price. ``Now it's more fair,'' said the center's deputy manager, Wang Deshun, a thin, talkative man who once worked for China's central bank. ``Information is open, and everyone can watch the movement of prices and decide whether to enter the market or not.'' That's the theory. In practice, the government tightly controls who can trade and for what purposes. New regulations _ such as a ban on importing luxury cars _ directly affect dollar demand and therefore the exchange rate. The center also can reject traders if the gap between supply and demand is too large, or the central bank can step in and make up the difference. Wang said it has done so about 10 times. Historically, dollars have gone from a high of 7.8 renminbi in September 1988, when import spending was freer, to a low of 4.98, reached last November when the government's tight loan policy forced many companies to sell dollar reserves. ``We have to consider the interests of buyers and sellers,'' Wang said. ``If the price (for dollars) goes too high, many companies won't be able to buy dollars they need. And if it falls too sharply, then...sellers won't be able to pay their debts.'' Because the center invariably devalues the renminbi from the official exchange rate, economists say it at least achieves a rate closer to the real buying power of the two currencies. For years, China has kept its renminbi artificially high. But some foreign businessmen say all the controls just make the center rate a second official rate, set to serve the interests of state trade companies. They are the main dollar sellers and benefit from the center's high dollar price, while foreign joint ventures buy dollars to repatriate profits or import parts. ``It dilutes our profits. All we want is for them to let us exchange our renminbi at the official rate,'' said the disgruntled American manager of one joint venture factory, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Like some other joint ventures, he tried another way of getting dollars _ by buying a Chinese product to sell abroad. He made his purchase and lined up a Hong Kong buyer. Then the buyer disappeared. Now he has several tons of frozen Chinese jelly fish sitting in a warehouse. He's back to the currency market.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Tuesday March 20
$adv18
For release Sunday March 18
DOC.HEAD: Volkswagen Has Big Plans _ If China Shifts From Park to Drive
With BC-China-Slump
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Volkswagen's joint venture autoworks in Shanghai produced nearly 16,000 cars last year _ the equivalent of four days output for the headquarters factory in West Germany. Still, Volkswagen has big plans for the Shanghai factory _ if China will just release the brakes and put it in gear. When Volkswagen AG signed a 50-50 joint venture contract with the Shanghai Tractor and Automobile Corp. in 1984, it seemed a perfect fit. Volkswagen wanted a manufacturing base to win a share of the Chinese and Southeast Asian auto market. China, spending tens of millions of dollars annually to import Japanese cars, wanted to modernize its auto industry. Shanghai Volkswagen started with a capacity of about 100 cars per day, or 30,000 a year, then doubled capacity last year. But the most China has ever let it produce in one year is the 15,687 cars that rolled off the line in 1989. The problem is politics. While Chinese auto officials were approving Volkswagen's expansion and devising plans for three more joint venture autoworks over the next decade, top Communist leaders decided cars were a luxury. Last summer they banned practically all new car purchases, domestic and imported alike, by government units and state-owned companies. The slogan ``hard work and plain living'' was promoted to curb inflation blamed on ousted Communist Party leader Zhao Ziyang. Thousands of car orders were scrapped. Stocks grew. Shanghai Volkswagen finally halted production for 39 days, when its distributor complained it had nowhere to put more cars. The French automaker Peugeot's joint venture in Canton shut for two months. ``Auto industry careens toward a dead end,'' read a headline in the official China Daily at year's end. The crisis eased when the government intervened and bought the excess inventory _ 7,440 cars from five Chinese or joint venture factories, at a total cost of $269 million. Wang Rongjun, Volkswagen's managing director, said he believes most of the cars are still in government warehouses. By early March, Beijing still had not told Shanghai Volkswagen its production quota for 1990 or responded to a request for a price increase to offset last year's devaluation that makes imported parts more expensive. The top West German manager, Burkhard Welkener, said he expects the quota will be 17,000. Wang said Beijing has quietly relaxed its ban on car purchases, to allow replacement of old cars. But purchases still must be approved by local authorities, a long and difficult process. Moreover, the government markup in taxes and other fees is 126 percent, discouraging many potential buyers. Fees inclusive, the Shanghai plant's manual transmission Santana _ a model that once sold in the United States as the Quantum _ goes for 179,700 yuan, or roughly $38,230. Some provinces add more fees so the price exceeds $42,550. Welkener said per-car production costs could be cut 30 percent to 40 percent if the factory were allowed to produce at full capacity. As it is, the Shanghai Santana is too expensive to export competitively to Southeast Asia. But Welkener, a tall, mild-mannered man, seems philosophical about the government controls. ``Of course it is a little bit frustrating to produce only 17,000,'' he said. ``But our company follows the idea of (Chinese officials) that there has to be a readjustment. We totally agree that everything has to be slower.'' He said the factory still plans to send young Chinese engineers to West Germany for technical training, and bring them back to design a new Santana for export. ``Santana for me is not just a car. Santana is a philosophy to bring China modern management,'' he said. He used one of the few Chinese phrases he knows: ``We must do it yibu, yi bude -- step by step.''

DOC.HEAD: Terex President Takes Over as Fruehauf Trailer CEO
DOC.TEXT: Former Fruehauf Corp. chief execitve Neal Combs, who ran the company when it was dismantled to meet leveraged buyout debts, has been replaced as head of its truck-trailer operation. Combs was replaced Tuesday as Fruehauf Trailer Corp.'s chief executive by Terex Corp. President Woodward Baldus, officials said. Green Bay, Wis.-based Terex bought Fruehauf's trailer business last August as Fruehauf assets were sold off to meet debts from a $1.5-billion leveraged buyout by management. Fruehauf Trailer Corp. continues as a Terex subsidiary. Combs went to Terex with the trailer business. Combs could not be reached for comment Wednesday at Fruehauf or at his home. ``Combs was asked to resign,'' Terex spokesman Jeff Zilka said, but declined further comment. The last of the former Fruehauf's assets, Kelsey-Hayes Co., maker of auto parts such as aluminum wheels and anti-lock braking systems, was sold to Canada's Varity Corp. last November. Fruehauf Trailer employs about 5,100 people in its U.S. operations.

DOC.HEAD: WPPSS Plans Third Nuclear Power Bond Refinancing in Seven Months
DOC.TEXT: The Washington Public Power Supply System plans to sell bonds in the public market to refinance $600 million in debt, its third such move in seven months. Sale of bonds at 7 percent to 8 percent interest rates, compared with 12 percent to 15 percent now being paid, should be completed over the next four weeks, WPPSS officials said. Unlike $2.25 billion in bonds on which WPPSS defaulted in 1983, the debt being refinanced is guaranteed by the Bonneville Power Administration, which estimates the lower interest payments will save ratepayers about $75 million this year. John Britton of WPPSS said an interest rate for the bonds would be set by the underwriter this week, with the consortium's board of directors to vote on the plan Thursday. The bonds being refinanced cover work on WPPSS nuclear projects Nos. 1, 2 and 3. Work on Nos. 1 and 3 was halted indefinitely in the early 1980s, while No. 2 has been completed and is generating electricity. Two earlier WPPSS refinancings covered bonds for project Nos. 1 and 3. The 1983 default was on bonds for WPPSS projects Nos. 4 and 5, which were terminated when they were roughly two-thirds built.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Gasoline Pumps Run Dry Due to Strike
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline pumps ran dry in Rome and most southern Italian cities Wednesday as striking truckers set up blockades in front of supply centers at major oil companies. Nearly half of Italy's 200,000 truckers went on strike Monday to protest a proposed law they contend denies trucking businesses sufficient tax breaks. The strike is scheduled to last until Monday. The strikers on Tuesday began pressing their demands by using trucks to block deliveries of gasoline to stations by non-striking truckers. Worried car drivers lined up in front of the rapidly decreasing number of operating pumps as word of the fuel shortage spread. Roberta Della Casa, a spokewoman for the ESSO Italiana oil company, said the situation was better in northern Italy, where a lower percentage of truckers had joined the strike. Transportation Minister Carlo Bernini met with police and ministry officials Tuesday and said later that authorities would enforce anti-picketing measures to free the flow of gasoline. However, Ms. Della Cassa said that supply centers were still blocked Wednesday by striking truckers.

DOC.HEAD: Nostalgia Channel Hires Program Syndicator as Exclusive Ad Sales Rep
DOC.TEXT: The Nostalgia Channel, a cable network aimed at viewers age 45 and older, said Wednesday it has signed a five-year exclusive agreement to have the syndication company LBS Communications Inc. sell its advertising time. Officials said the agreement was the first such arrangement between a television syndicator and a basic cable network. The network owners said the agreement should help the channel grow by giving it readier access to national advertisers than if it were to assemble its own sales force to solicit them. To date, the 5-year-old network has sold advertising time mainly to direct marketers, who display a product and urge viewers to call in with orders, but has made no concerted effort to sell time to traditional national advertisers. Founded in 1976, LBS has specialized in identifying target audiences, helping develop programs that will appeal to them and selling advertising time. Among the syndicated TV shows in which it sells time are Family Feud and The Real Ghostbusters. It also sells time in the syndicated radio show Flashback that features music and interviews from the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s. This fall, LBS will handle advertising sales for the syndicated TV show that the National Broadcasting Co. and Memories: Then and Now magazine are putting together based on the magazine. Henry Siegel, chairman and president of LBS, said the agreement with The Nostalgia Channel means LBS will be able to create an advertising package through media all aimed at the over-45 market _ including time on broadcast, cable TV and radio as well as space in a magazine. The Nostalgia Channel is carried on 450 cable systems with more than 8.5 million subscribers nationwide. Another 2 million homes receive the channel via satellite dishes. The network provides a variety of programming aimed at the over-45 audience, including classic movies, vintage TV series such as Burke's Law, Dick Powell Theater and The Rogues, and shows featuring big bands or Liberace. It also offers news, financial advice and travel programs geared toward the over-45 audience, gardening and home improvement shows, and Jack LaLanne exercise programs.

DOC.HEAD: Expects Call for Leave for Parents, Billions More For Child Care
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with comments at news conference; Edits to tighten; No pickup; A longer version moved on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: A National Research Council panel today called for billions more in government spending on child care, mandatory one-year leaves for parents of newborns and a program to establish strict national standards for day care-centers. ``Every American child not only deserves quality care, the future vitality of our nation depends on it,'' said John L. Palmer, chairman of the committee that produced the report, ``Who Cares for America's Children?'' The report said that by the year 2000 about three out of every four American children will have mothers in the work force and that even now the majority of American parents entrust care of their young children to others. Palmer, a professor at the Maxwell School of Citizenship and Public Affairs at Syracuse University, said the committee found ``substantial scientific evidence'' that good quality child care can have serious effects on the future life of every child and the influence that child has in society. Committee member Barbara Bowman of the Erikson Institute in Chicago said there is no good research to reflect how many of the thousands of child care arrangements in this country meet the minimum standards of quality. She said limited research showed that only about 20 percent of care arrangements ``meet the standards of good or better.'' Ms. Bowman said that more than half of all children of working parents are cared for in facilities that are unregulated, and as a result, national data on the specifics of quality child care are lacking. The report spelled out a future in child care in which virtually a whole generation will be cared for by persons other than parents. The report said that in 1988, more than 10.5 million children under age 6 had mothers in the labor force. Another 18 million between the ages 6 and 13 had working mothers, it said. Within five years, the study said, about two-thirds of all new workers will be women and 80 percent of them are expected to have children at some point during their careers. Forecasts suggest that by the year 2000 about 80 percent of school-age children and 70 percent of preschool children will have mothers who are working or looking for work outside their homes, it said. The report said that by 1995 the amount spent annually for child care in the United States will reach $48 billion. But to provide ``adequate care'' for all children under age 13, it said total costs for parents and the government could rise eventually to about $126 billion. Child care expenses absorb an average of 23 percent of the income of poor families, the report said. It noted, however, that one study shows that for families earning under $5,000 a year, the child care expense can represent up to 50 percent of the income. Higher income families pay about 9 percent of their income for child care. The quality of child care facilities varies from state to state, community to community, and is affected by the parents' income level, the panel said. Enforcement of day care quality ranges from none in some states that lack license requirements or state inspections, to other states with mandatory standards that are strictly enforced, it said. Child care center employees are almost universally poorly paid and worker turnover is very high, it said. The panel said studies show there is an important need for parents to establish strong relationships with their children in the early months of life. As a result, it said, the federal government ``should mandate unpaid, job-protected leave for employed parents of infants up to one year of age.'' Among large companies, about 47 percent provide some form of paid maternity leave, but only 10 percent of the companies with fewer than 100 employees had such a policy, the report said. Five states _ California, Hawaii, New Jersey, New York and Rhode Island _ and Puerto Rico include wage and position protection in pregnancy disability leave programs. In New Jersey, for example, workers are entitled to 26 weeks' leave and up to $200 a week in compensation. Other recommendations: _The federal government and the states should increase subsidies to low-income families for quality child care programs. The added costs, either through taxincentives or grants, the report said, could be as high as $10 billion. _Establish a uniform national standard for child care. This could include minimum safety and health standards, along with acceptable ranges for staff-to-child ratios, group size, caregiver qualifications and physical space in the facility. _Expand Head Start and other preschool programs for children of poor families. _Strengthen ``the infrastructure of the child care system'' by improving wages and training for caregivers, expanding voucher programs to give poor families more opportunities to choose centers, and encouraging organization of family day care systems. The National Research Council is an organization of the National Academy of Sciences, a private society of scholars chartered by Congress with a mandate to advise the federal government on scientific and technical matters.
