DOC.HEAD: European Parliament Votes for Total Ban on Tobacco Ads
DOC.TEXT: The European Parliament voted Wednesday for a total ban on tobacco advertising throughout the 12 nation European Community. But the ban will not take effect because the European Community's Executive Commission refused to accept the Parliament's addition of the ban to proposed legislation to regulate tobacco advertising. The Parliament had added the tobacco advertising ban as an amendment to legislation proposed by the executive commission that would allow advertisers to show only the tobacco package and nicotine and tar yields in ads. Under EC law, parliamentary amendments must be approved by the commission before they can be adopted on a majority vote by the EC governments. If the commission fails to approve the amendments, they can only be adopted on a unanimous vote by the EC governments. A unanimous vote to ban tobacco advertising is highly unlikely because at least two members, West Germany and Britain, oppose such a ban. However, Vasso Papandreou, the EC commissioner for social affairs, said she would introduce new proposals after 1992 to ban tobacco advertising. The current proposal should go into force at the end of 1991. Under the legislation proposed by the commission, every tobacco advertisement would be required to carry a health warning covering at least 10 percent of the advertising space and more if the warning were in more than one language. In addition, tobacco advertisements in magazines aimed at those under 18 years old would be prohibited and indirect advertising such as putting tobacco brands or symbols on non-tobacco products would also be banned.

DOC.HEAD: British Airways Adds Fourth Class
DOC.TEXT: British Airways PLC has introduced a fourth class for airline passengers. A British Airways spokeswoman said Wednesday the initial response to Economy Select, available on flights between London and Dallas or Houston, has been ``very positive.'' Economy Select, for passengers paying the full economy fare, has a separate cabin, separate check-in, advance seat reservations and seats that recline 3 inches more than those in regular economy class, the airline said. The eight-month trial program began Feb. 1 after extensive research, said the spokeswoman, who declined to be identified by name in accordance with British custom. British Airways is the first airline to introduce a fourth class, she added. ``Today, companies send their executives on full economy fares, which cost more than promotional fares but which have the full flexibility they need for business,'' said Liam Strong, British Airways' marketing director. ``The expectations of passengers who pay 794 pounds ($1,290) for a round- trip ticket to Dallas ... will obviously differ from those of leisure passengers traveling on these routes for as little as 299 pounds ($484) round trip,'' Strong said. British Airways' business class fare between London and Dallas or Houston is 2,122 pounds round trip, or $3,435. Stephen Clapham, an airline industry analyst at brokerage Hoare Govett, said it remains to be seen if the new fourth class will be a success. ``If they (British Airways) were sure of a big demand they would have introduced it across the board,'' he said. Pan Am spokesman Steve Heckscher said the fourth class experiment bears watching. ``Maybe there is a niche that everybody else has missed, but I'm a little skeptical that it really has a place in the range of tickets available today,'' he said. ``Most companies will let you fly with a business (class) ticket so there's no reason to buy an economy ticket. Business seats are more comfortable, there's a little more status and there's added flexibility with cancellations and re-booking,'' Heckscher said. Continental Airlines spokesman Steve Preston did not rule out the possibility of a fourth class for that carrier. ``We are looking at totally restructuring our business class and totally revamping our front-end products,'' he said, referring to first class and business class. ``A number of things are under review at the moment.'' An American Airlines spokeswoman said the largest U.S. carrier does not see an immediate need for a fourth class, but added, ``We are always looking to see what the industry is doing and if it seems the consumers are interested we might consider it.'' British Airways' fourth class is limited to 31 non-smoking seats between the business class and economy class sections on flights from Gatwick Airport outside London to Dallas and Houston.

DOC.BYLINE: OPEC Ministers Hold Talks; Will They Tamper With Winning Formula? ^By SALLY JACOBSEN
DOC.TEXT: OPEC oil ministers will gather this week to discuss the world oil market but are unlikely to tamper with a formula that has brought them higher-than-expected prices. ``There will be talks about the future, but no decisions,'' predicted Pierre Terzian, editor of the Paris-based newsletter Petrostrategies. Peter Gignoux, director of the international energy department for Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in London, expects little from the meeting. ``They're going to come and go,'' he said. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' monitoring committee will begin meeting Friday in Vienna. Talks are expected to center on the group's pricing strategy and current production levels. Although only eight oil members comprise the panel, all 13 OPEC ministers are expected to attend. The discussions will be the first since the cartel met last November and set a crude oil production ceiling of 22 million barrels a day for the first six months of 1990. The previous ceiling was 20.5 million barrels for the final quarter of 1989. Analysts estimate that OPEC countries, spurred by persistent cheaters Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, have been producing at least a million barrels a day above their cap. Even so, prices have remained above OPEC's benchmark of $18 a barrel, reflecting strong demand by the United States and other consuming nations. Between November and February, OPEC's basket of seven crudes has averaged more than $19 a barrel. Prices appear to have softened slightly in March but remain above the target price, averaging $18.45 in the first week of the month. West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark American grade of sweet crude, is currently priced in the $20 to $21 range, down from $22 to $23 in January. Analysts say prices could ease further in the second quarter when demand for oil declines with the onset of warm weather. Nick Antill, analyst at the London-based County NatWest, forecasts demand for OPEC oil will run about 22 million barrels a day in the April-June quarter, below current production of 23.2 million barrels estimated by the International Energy Agency. Nonetheless, a flurry of reports in advance of the meeting suggests that the two main items likely to garner the most attention will be prices and quotas. Iraq's Oil Minister Issam Abdul Raheem al-Chalabi was reported to be pressing privately for a higher target price but was unable to muster support from Kuwait and Saudi Arabia for such a change. Kuwait, with little support, is said to be advocating a rise in the production ceiling to keep prices in check. Some analysts believe Kuwait wants to keep prices at $18 to encourage sales and discourage non-OPEC countries, attracted by higher prices, from taking away some of the cartel's market share. Kuwait's Oil minister Ali Khalifa al-Sabah reportedly has said Kuwait does not feel bound by its quota when prices remain above $18 a barrel. Al-Sabah also was quoted in the Middle East Economic Survey as calling for OPEC to abandon the quota system as soon as possible. He is reported to have said the system is outdated and often ignored by members. The cartel sets an overall production ceiling for its members and then slices the total into individual allotments for each producer. With little pressure to change a formula that for now is working, ministers are likely simply to air their views and leave decisions for the full conference of ministers in May. OPEC Secretary-General Subroto has said no decisions are likely at this week's meeting and that the discussions would provide ``important input'' for the May conference, according to the organization's news agency OPECNA. OPEC members are: Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: Sotheby's, Christies Report Profit Gains
Precede BC-Earns-Christies
DOC.TEXT: Sotheby's Holdings Inc. said Wednesday its earnings for 1989 climbed 82 percent from a year earlier, while another fine arts auction house, Christies International PLC, reported a 61 percent earnings increase. Sotheby's, which announced its earnings in New York, said its net income came to $113 million, or $1.96 a share, in 1989 compared with $62 million, or $1.10 a share, in 1988. Sotheby's said its revenue rose 40 percent to $445 million from $317 million in 1988. For the fourth quarter, net income increased 94 percent to $62 million, or $1.07 a share, from $32 million, or 56 cents a share, a year earlier. Fourth-quarter revenue rose 48 percent to $200 million from $135 million. Michael Ainslie, Sotheby's president, said in a statement that the results showed ``we have further strengthened our leadership postion in the international art market.'' Sotheby's auction sales rose 62 percent to $2.95 billion for the year and 76 percent to $1.49 billion for the quarter. Christies said in London that its net profit for the year came to 40 million pounds, or $64 million, compared with 24.8 million pounds in 1988. Earnings per share came to 23.4 pence, or 38 cents, compared with 14.8 pence. Christies said its pre-tax profit rose 57 percent to 66.9 million pounds, or $108 million, from 42.5 million pounds. Sales soared 71 percent to 1.33 billion pounds, or $2.1 billion, from 777 million pounds in 1988. Christies Chairman Lord Carrington said sales in 1990 are ahead of a year ago. Growth in the breadth of interest in art, he said, allows the company to ``look forward to the 1990s with optimism.'' Christies didn't break out quarterly or six month results. It isn't required to under British law.

DOC.HEAD: Microsoft Declares 1-for-1 Stock Dividend
DOC.TEXT: Microsoft Corp., a computer software developer, has declared a 100 percent stock dividend that amounts to a one-for-one stock split. Microsoft said Tuesday the new stock would be issued to shareholders of record March 26, doubling the number of shares outstanding to about 112 million. Microsoft stock closed Tuesday at $106.25, down $2 in over-the-counter trading. Raymond B. Ferguson, Microsoft's director of administration, said it was the second dividend the company has declared since it went public in March 1986. The first, also a 100 percent stock dividend, was issued in September 1987. ``It's not common to have a cash dividend in our industry,'' Ferguson said. ``There is a greater requirement for cash to continue to grow the business.'' Microsoft President Jon Shirley said the dividend was declared to make the stock more attractive to a broader range of investors. Scott McAdams, an analyst with Ragan and MacKenzie Inc. in Seattle, said making the stock more affordable also could boost the value of current stock holdings in the long run. ``The market tends to like nominally priced stocks,'' McAdams said. When prices get too high, he said, ``there's a little bit of a psychological edge operating there that may keep the value of the stock down a little bit.'' Microsoft reported a profit of $74 million, or $1.25 a share, on revenue of $300 million for the three months ended Dec. 31, compared with profit of $47 million, or 85 cents a share, on revenue of $210 million for the same period a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: MCA Buys Geffen Records
DOC.NOTE: Eds: An AMer expected by 6 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: Entertainment colossus MCA Inc. today bought the last big independent music label, Geffen Records, the home of such strong rock acts as Guns N' Roses, Don Henley, Cher, Aerosmith and Whitesnake. Geffen's sole owner, David Geffen, will receive MCA preferred stock worth about $550 million at today's share price. He may sell it only over a four-year period, and thus will benefit if its price goes up and suffer if it falls. He will stay on as chairman and chief executive of Geffen, which he founded a decade ago in a deal in which Warner Bros. Records distributed his recordings in return for half the profits. That deal expires at the end of the year. Geffen had been negotiating with Warner, the British Thorn-EMI and other companies. Geffen Records did about $225 million in business last year. Asked why Geffen selected MCA, MCA President Sid Sheinberg said, ``I would suspect that the difference here is that he's dealing with people he's known for many years, people with a broad basis in entertainment, not just music. Sheinberg noted that Geffen is known as a brilliant businessman. ``I'm flattering myself, but I think he also felt this was a very good security to own,'' he said in a telephone interview. In addition to Geffen's music business, his Geffen Films has produced movies such as ``Beetlejuice,'' ``Little Shop of Horrors'' and ``Risky Business. Geffen Theatre co-produced ``M. Butterfly,'' which earned nine 1988 Tony Awards, ``Cats,'' ``Dreamgirls'' and ``Little Shop of Horrors.'' MCA is not buying those businesses. But the Universal City-based giant will acquire rights to Geffen's related music publishing business, founded in 1987 as a vehicle for Geffen Records-related projects. It has since expanded and its stable of songwriters now includes Stephen Sondheim. As part of the deal, Geffen signed a 20-year ``standstill'' agreement that bars him from acquiring more MCA stock or engaging in proxy wars. West Hollywood-based Geffen Records' artists also include Tesla, Peter Gabriel, Edie Brickell and the New Bohemians, Rickie Lee Jones, Pat Metheny, Joni Mitchell, Robbie Robertson, Jimmy Page, Olivia Newton-John, Kitaro, Ric Ocasek, XTC, Christopher Williams and Kylie Minogue. MCA, unlike other major labels, does not distribute its own records overseas. Its foreign distribution agreement with Warner Bros. runs out in March 1991, and Sheinberg said, ``Where we go from here in the foreign area remains to be determined.'' He acknowledged, however, that MCA's roster of country and black artists is far stronger than its list of rock acts. ``Having Geffen certainly gives us a stronger package'' while negotiating, he said. Geffen's salary wasn't revealed. The preferred stock he was issued is the equivalent of 10 million shares of MCA common stock. Each share paid a dividend of 68 cents last year. Geffen, who got his start as a talent agent, was 27 in 1971 when he founded Asylum Records, the home of Joni Mitchell, the Eagles and Jackson Browne. Within two years he sold Asylum to Warner Communications, becoming chairman of Warner's resulting Elektra-Asylum label.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Unveils Proposal to Cut Tariffs by At Least One Third
DOC.TEXT: The United States on Wednesday unveiled a proposal to drastically reduce or eliminate import tariffs as its contribution to an ambitious international trade-liberalizing agreement planned for the end of the year. U.S. deputy trade representative Rufus Yerxa said the offer was contingent on the United States receiving corresponding concessions from its trading partners in the 96-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. In an 800-page document, to be submitted to GATT members on Thursday, the United States proposes the elimination of tariffs on imported agricultural products. For a second group of goods including wood products and paper, steel, aluminum, certain chemical products and selected construction equipment, it proposes duty-free access to U.S. markets provided trading partners remove tariffs and all trade barriers from matching U.S. exports. For all other products, the U.S. proposal allows for tariff reductions up to a maximum of 50 percent, again subject to reciprocal concessions by other countries after bilateral talks. This third category includes the sensitive U.S. textiles sector, traditionally protected by high import tariffs. Yerxa told a press conference that cuts in textile duties were unlikely to reach the 50 percent ceiling, although this was ``theoretically'' possible under the U.S. plan. ``Textiles is a very tough category for us to make concessions on,'' he said. Despite high import duties in sectors such as textiles, clothing and footwear, the United States has a low overall level of tariffs. A tariff, or tax levied on imported goods, is one of the main ways of shielding domestic industry from foreign competition because it makes imported goods more expensive and therefore less competitive than domestic products. Yerxa said U.S. import duty levels averages 6.6 percent for agricultural products and 5 percent for industrial goods, in contrast to much higher protection in other countries. In Brazil, for example, tariffs average 47 percent of the value of traded goods, according to figures listed in the U.S. document. In India the average is 99 percent, and in Pakistan 106 percent. ``It would be a great travesty for the United States to have to reduce its already low tariffs if others don't make reductions,'' Yerxa said. At a meeting in Montreal in December 1988 trade ministers agreed on the overall target of 33 percent for tariff cuts. A deal reached in January allowed GATT members to select their own method of achieving this target. Proposals have to be submitted by Thursday. GATT is a multilateral trade agreement first established in 1947 and designed to establish rules, reduce tariffs and provide a setting for a solution to international trade problems. Members of the market-orientated organization, account for more than four-fifths of world trade. The current Uruguay Round of trade talks is expected to end in December with an ambitious new agreement to liberalize trade in areas such as agriculture and textiles.

DOC.HEAD: Sprint In Joint Venture in Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: US Sprint on Wednesday announced a joint venture with two Soviet organizations to provide Sprint's international data network services in the Soviet Union by late 1990. Kansas City, Mo.-based Sprint said it had signed a preliminary agreement with the Central Telegraph of the Soviet Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications and the Institute of Electronics and Computer Science of the Latvian Academy of Sciences to form a new company known as Telenet USSR. Voice communications are not involved in the agreement. The pact calls for Telenet USSR to operate a switching center in Moscow to be connected with the SprintNet International data network. It also will provide domestic and international electronic messaging services, and distribute Sprint's Telenet product line of data communications equipment in the Soviet Union. Details of the joint venture, including financing, will be agreed on by midyear, the company said, with Telenet USSR operations expected to begin by the end of the year. The pact requires approval by Soviet and U.S. government authorities. Sprint International President Paolo Guidi said his company was ``delighted'' to be part of the perestroika process that is building ``economic bridges between East and West.'' Sprint declined to disclose the cost of its involvement in the venture. Wednesday's announcement follows one in December in which Denver-based US West said it would join with the Soviet phone ministry and seven other international companies to build a fiber-optic telecommunications line across the Soviet Union at a cost of about $500 million. Commerce Department Secretary Robert Mosbacher, whose department shares responsibility for issuing export licenses to U.S. companies, has indicated the adminstration would look favorably on US West's request as long as the Soviets do not receive the very latest in U.S. fiber technology. The United States historically has taken a hard line on exports of products that may be used militarily by Soviet Bloc nations. But with the recent decline of communism in Eastern Europe, President Bush has said he's willing to review export contraints contained in the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls. Central Telegraph serves 120,000 Soviet telex subscribers and 4,000 international customers. The Latvian group is involved in computer data communications. Syd Courson, a Sprint spokesman in Kansas City, said it was too early to predict how much money would be generated from the Soviet venture. In addition, it is not known how the Soviets will overcome their shortage of Western currency to pay for Sprint's services and equipment. Sprint, which created its Reston, Va.-based Sprint International division on Jan. 1, plans to establish switching centers in 20 foreign markets this year. Its trans-Atlantic traffic is carried by the PTAT-1 fiber cable that Sprint co-owns with Britain's Cable and Wireless PLC. PTAT-1, which began operating last fall, was the first privately funded trans-Atlantic fiber cable system. Its ability to handle 80,000 simultaneous transmissions is double the capacity of the TAT-8 fiber cable owned by the American Telephone & Telegraph Co. and state-owned phone companies in Europe, Canada and Australia. In another announcement Wednesday, Sprint also said it intends to be part of a group of companies planning to build a $260 million fiber-optic cable linking Japan, China, Hong Kong and Singapore. It has not been determined whether Sprint will have an ownership position or purchase capacity on the cable, which will carry voice, data and video signals. Sprint's international ambitions reflect the growing financial strength of United Telecommunications Inc. of Westwood, Kan., Sprint's majority owner. United Telecom posted operating income of $910 million in 1989, up from $252.8 million in 1988. Sprint's international telecommunications revenues are growing 20 percent a year, considerably faster than domestic revenues.

DOC.HEAD: Repeating for all needing
DOC.TEXT: The stock market turned upward today, rebounding from Tuesday's mild setback. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 12.16 points on Tuesday, rose 18.69 to 2,693.24 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 6 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 765 up, 628 down and 527 unchanged. The market retreated Tuesday as interest rates came under new upward pressure in the credit markets. Rates levelled off or declined slightly in early activity today, giving some encouragement to stock traders. Most analysts agree that stocks have benefited lately from hopes that the economy could emerge from its recent period of weakness without having to undergo a full-blown recession. Brokers say that kind of optimism would be buttressed if interest rates do not go much higher than their current levels. Worries persist, however, that borrowing costs in this country would keep increasing if rates climb further in such other prominent industrialized nations as Japan and West Germany. Gainers among the blue chips included Exxon, up 1[ at 46}; American Express, up \ at 28[; General Electric, up 1 at 63; Philip Morris, up { at 38[, and Procter & Gamble, up 1] at 65{. Procter & Gamble has acquired the U.S. marketing rights to Rorer Group's over-the-counter pharmaceutical products, including the antacid Maalox. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .74 to 185.99. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .51 at 361.30. Volume on the Big Board came to 122.42 million shares with an hour to go.

DOC.HEAD: Rush of Joint Ventures Turns Usually Drab Fair Into Business Beehive
DOC.TEXT: A rush to reach business agreements with East Germany is livening up the current Leipzig trade fair, with a Bonn Cabinet minister predicting an ``avalanche'' of German-German joint ventures will emerge from this year's event. West German carmakers Volkswagen, General Motors-owned Opel, and Daimler-Benz, the Stuttgart-based maker of luxury cars and heavy trucks, have jumped on the bandwagon, detailing joint venture deals with East Germany's IFA automobile works. Others among the 1,000 West German companies vying for joint-venture agreements and other deals at the weeklong fair include the Thyssen AG industrial concern, electronics company Siemens and precision optics firm Zeiss _ which reportedly is negotiating a ``reunification'' with its East German counterpart Carl Zeiss. The West German rush to sign preliminary agreements underlines the confidence of managers that German unification is near and there are profits to be made in rebuilding East Germany, which is in economic shambles after 40 years of Communist rule. Last fall's peaceful popular revolt that ousted hardline leaders has set the stage for the new age of German-German business relations. The Leipzig fair is the oldest international trade fair in the world, dating back more than 800 years, and is one of the biggest. Some 60 countries are participating in the spring edition of the twice-annual event, which focuses on industrial equipment and electronics, with the number of West German companies up by 25 percent from last year. West German Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann has predicted ``an avalanche of joint ventures'' following East Germany's first free elections Sunday, after which the unification process is expected to quicken. A day after the fair opened last Sunday, Volkswagen announced details of the biggest deal so far at the current gathering, a 50-50 joint venture agreement with IFA. The companies plan to start modernizing IFA's antiquated Trabants, which use two-stroke engines and became famous as the smoke-belching transport of for the hordes of East Germans that moved westward when the borders opened. IFA's factory at Zwickau already is producing engines for the West German company. Later, Trabant production will be phased out and VW's Polo and Golf models will be built at Zwickau, VW president Carl Hahn said. VW plans total investments of $2.94 billion by 1994, when about 1,000 cars per day should be coming off the assembly line, Hahn said. Initial investments of $35.3 million are planned for the plant, which hopes to be making about 50 Polo models a day by December. Daimler-Benz and IFA also signed an agreement at the fair Monday to build heavy trucks, but details of the planned joint venture were still being worked out. The same applies to Opel, which said it was working on a preliminary agreement with IFA's Wartburg automobile plant located in the East German city of Eisenach, near the border with West Germany. Other deals at the fair include preliminary agreements between Siemens and a state electronics combine in Dresden to produce industrial robots. Thyssen will join with another East German congolomerate, Takraf, to produce building elevators and waste processing plants. One of East Germany's largest combines, the 60,000-worker Carl Zeiss company of Jena, reportedly is in secret negotiations with the West German Zeiss company, set up by the former owners of Carl Zeiss after the East German Communists expropriated them. The two companies are holding talks at the fair on joint manufacture of computer chips and optical equipment, a ``reunification'' that could create one of the world's largest producers of high-tech electronics, the Munich newspaper Sueddeutsche Zeitung said Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Big Three Sales Dip
With BC-Auto Sales-Table
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT to 6.8 percent sted 2.6 percent decline. Picks up 2nd graf, General Motors ...
DOC.TEXT: Early March sales of cars and light trucks made by the nation's Big Three automakers dipped 6.8 percent compared with slow sales a year ago, the companies said Wednesday. General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. said they sold cars and light trucks at an average daily rate of 27,289 during the March 1-10 period this year, compared with 29,281 during the same time last year. Car sales fell 7.7 percent, and truck sales were down 5.4 percent. March and April usually usher in a more bouyant car and truck buying season as Americans shake off the winter and take to the highways. But incentives offered during January and February of last year had attracted would-be March and April buyers, depressing the sales rate for the latter two months. The March 1989 sales rate was the lowest during the first nine months of the year. Sales hit the skids during the final three months of last year, but the pace picked up slightly after the first of the year. Despite comparison with a slow sales period a year ago, early March sales were lower this year. Through March 10 of this year, the car and truck selling rate was running 2.6 percent behind last year's rate. Car sales were off 5.6 percent but truck sales were up 2.2 percent, mainly because of strong Chrysler minivan sales in January. Chrysler said its early March car and truck sales were running 11.3 percent behind last year's pace, with car sales down 9.1 percent and truck sales off 13.4 percent. But for the year, Chrysler's car and truck sales were running 0.2 percent ahead of last year, with car sales down 6.9 percent and truck sales up 6.8 percent. Ford said its early March car sales were down 8.1 percent and truck sales were down 3.1 percent, combining for a 6.1 percent sales decrease from year-ago levels. For the year, Ford's vehicle sales were running 6.5 percent behind last year, with car sales down 8.6 percent and truck sales down 3.5 percent. GM's combined car and truck sales for early March was down 5.7 percent compared with last year, as car sales fell 7.1 percent and truck sales dropped 3.1 percent. So far this year, GM's car sales were down 3.2 percent and truck sales were up 4.7 percent, combining for a sales rate 0.7 percent below last year.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Sues Brokerage House For Illegal Sales Tactics
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission accused a New York brokerage firm Wednesday of using illegal sales practices to induce investors to buy over-the-counter securities. A civil lawsuit brought by the SEC alleged that Wellshire Securities Inc. operated as a penny stock ``boiler room'' from July 1988 to the present, selling speculative over-the-counter securities through high-pressure sales pitches and illegal means that violated securities laws. The lawsuit, in U.S. District Court in Manhattan, charged that Wellshire made exorbitant price predictions, gave out false information about stocks, made unauthorized sales and tried to stop clients from selling securities. In one case listed in the complaint, a 68-year-old retiree was persuaded to borrow money from a home equity loan to buy securities. Wellshire's president, Robert Cohen, and executive vice president, Carol Martino, were accused of knowing about and encouraging the illegal sales practices. Three of Wellshire's present and former brokers also were named in the lawsuit. ``We are reviewing the allegations and we have no comment,'' Cohen said when reached by telephone in his office. Wellshire _ with six branch offices in Long Island, New Jersey, Florida, Georgia and Germany _ has about 50,000 customer accounts and employs 100 brokers, the SEC said. The lawsuit also names two companies whose stock Wellshire promoted _ Ventura Inc. of Needham, Mass., which had entertainment and insurance subsidiaries, and Environmental Landfills Inc., the owner of a landfill site in upstate Plattekill. The SEC said Ventura chairman Robert Beck and its director, Richard Sand, misrepresented Ventura's profitability and made fraudulent earnings predictions. This information was given to Wellshire, whose brokers passed it on to investors, the lawsuit alleges. Sand said he had no comment on the lawsuit. Beck was said to be unavailable. Environmental Landfills and its chairman, Paul V. Winters, were accused of making false and misleading statements about the legal status of the landfill, regulatory approval of its cleanup and the likelihood of the landfill's opening. This information was published in Wellshire's in-house market letter and used to spur investments, the lawsuit said. Efforts to obtain comment from Environmental Landfills were unsuccessful because the company had no telephone listing. A temporary restraining order that bars Wellshire, Cohen and Martino from any further securities law violations was signed Wednesday by U.S. District Judge Kevin Duffy. The order also freezes the defendants' assets and requires they produce an accounting of their finances.

DOC.HEAD: Prudential Reports Drop in 1989 Profit; Sees Future Layoffs on Wall Street
DOC.TEXT: Prudential Insurance Co. of America said Wednesday that its 1989 profit slipped 10 percent from a year earlier due largely to two major acquisitions that expanded its real estate and securities businesses. Meanwhile, the head of its Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. subsidiary, disclosed there would be layoffs later this year in response to the sluggishness on Wall Street. George Ball, Prudential-Bache chairman and chief executive officer, did not specify the number of jobs that would be cut but said the firm wanted to avoid ``the bludgeon approach.'' Prudential said losses in its securities and residential real estate operations were largely to blame for a drop in 1989 earnings to $743 million from $829 million the previous year. Revenue, however, rose 15 percent to $43.03 billion from $37.50 billion. Prudential, which is a mutual insurance company, said income from operations before policy-owner dividends and income taxes totaled $3.56 billion in 1989, down from $3.71 billion in 1988. The company said it had solid earnings gains in its insurance and asset management businesses. The losses in its securities and real estate businesses came mainly from Prudential's acquisition last year of Merrill Lynch & Co.'s residential real estate operations and the branch offices of the Wall Street firm Thomson McKinnon Inc. At its annual media briefing, Prudential Chairman Robert C. Winters called the approximatley $300 million real estate acquisition the most significant strategic development for the company last year. Prudential currently has more than 900 brokerage offices with nearly 25,000 sales associates in 40 states. Winters said the Thomson McKinnon acquisiton would ``position the firm to take full advantage of the potential we see down the road for the securities industry.'' ``Right now individual investors are staying away from the marketplace,'' Winters said. ``We believe ultimately this period will end. It's a cyclical business.'' Several Wall Street firms, including Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., have been contracting in recent months in part because of the slowdown since the 1987 stock market crash and a decline in mergers and acquisitions due to a sharp decline in the junk bond market. Ball, who also spoke at the annual briefing, said Prudential-Bache was evaluating where future staff cuts would be made. The firm currently has around 19,000 employees. ``I do expect our head count to be lower,'' he told reporters. Prudential-Bache recorded a net loss of $51 million in 1989, compared with a $111 million profit the previous year. In its individual insurance sector, Prudential posted a 4 percent increase in new business premiums to $3.4 billion. Life insurance sales slipped 15 percent to $806 million but annuity sales rose 23 percent to $2.1 billion, it said. New property and casualty insurance sales were up 23 percent to $342 million, but earnings were hurt by Hurricane Hugo and the San Francisco earthquake, it said. The group insurance earnings also improved, Prudential said. Premium and fees from new sales of group life and health coverages were up 23 percent to $2 billion. Prudential said its institutional asset management group, which manages a wide range of investments for pension funds and other large institutional investors, had an 88 percent decline in sales to $7.8 billion.

DOC.HEAD: GM Recalls 147,200 Cars
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. on Wednesday recalled about 147,200 cars and vans in five separate actions for problems that include the possibility of parts breaking in rear suspensions of some Corvettes. The recall included 46,000 1988- and 1989-model Corvettes with rear-wheel tie rod assemblies that may break, causing a loss of control. GM spokesman Tom Pyden said the automaker wasn't aware of any deaths or major injuries because of any of the problems. The automaker also recalled: _About 1,100 1990-model Pontiac Grand Prix SE Turbo cars for removal of a rear spring heat shield which may puncture the fuel tank in a collision. _About 84,000 1987-89 Chevrolet Corsica sedans because of door hinge problems which could affect the car's ability to withstand a side-impact crash. _About 10,000 1990 Buick Riviera and Cadillac Eldorado and Seville cars with potentially sticky rear shoulder safety belt assemblies. _Nearly 6,100 1987-89 Chevrolet and GMC Step Vans built for commercial delivery for replacement of a seat pedestal which may not be able to hold the seat or a passenger during a crash. GM said owners were being notified by mail. Inspections and repairs will be performed for free.
